Being tired of the summer, Garson Kanin has done something about it by staging a comedy of his own. "The Live Wire" he calls it. It opened at The Playhouse last evening to an audience looking brown and in good health. The number of requests from retail merchants to the Hat Research Foundation for detailed presentation of the promotional program for National Hat Week, Oct. 15 to 21, indicates enthusiasm for allout drives in key cities, the foundation announced yesterday.

Good Time, the 4-year-old bay from the Good Time Stable of Goshen, N.Y., had a really good time last night at Yonkers Raceway. Second choice in the twelvehorse field, Good Time captured the $25,000 Yonkers Pacing Derby in world-record time, a sizzling 3:08 for the mile and a half before 16,945 harness racing fans.
A twin-engined airliner that can climb to 4,500 feet, fully loaded, with one of its power plants inoperative, was displayed at La Guardia Airport yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 24-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has signed Tay Garnett to direct the projected screen version of Rudyard Kipling's "Soldiers Three," which will go before the cameras about Oct. 1, with Stewart Granger as Private Mulvaney, the Irish trooper, ...

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 24--The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine refugees in the Near East reported today that 4,600 refugees of the Palestine war were now employed on works projects in Jordan. Another 250 persons are engaged in relief activities in the same country.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 24-- One of two wills in which Miss Elizabeth N. Ayres, 74-year-old Danbury spinster, left her entire estate to Dr. Donald F. Gibson, her physician, was invalidated here today because it was drawn improperly.

Among railroad and industrial officials in New York and other key centers throughout the country There was a strong feeling yesterday that the threatened railroad strike would be averted at the last minute, as it was in 1948.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 24--Denmark has fallen off the European recovery train with consequences that bode no good for this country or for economic cooperation in the West.

Two well-known liquor companies here revised their methods of distribution yesterday. National Distillers Products Corporation named Peel Richards, Ltd. as exclusive wholesale distributor for all but four lines, and W.A. Taylor Co., a division of Hiram Walker G. W. Ltd., will sell directly to retailers.
Two teams of industrial specialists from Western Europe visited metal industry plants in the New York area yesterday in tours sponsored by the Economic Cooperation Administration.
Dissatisfaction with the leading Democratic possibilities for Governor was expressed yesterday by a spokesman for the State Congress of Industrial Organizations.

On June 27th this year, President Truman of the United States of America announced the decision of the United States Government to prevent with armed forces the liberation of Taiwan [Formosa] by the Chinese People's Liberation Army.
The Metropolitan Life Isurance Company has decided to accept Negroes as tenants in its Stuyvesant Town housing project.

TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 25--One of the well-known generals of the Chinese civil war has now appeared as a corps commander in the North Korean Communist Army, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's Intelligence Section said today. He is Kim Mu Chong--to use his ...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24-- About fifty tons of critical molybdenum concentrate, worth $45,000, has slipped into the hands of the Soviet Union in contravention of United States export control regulations.
TRENTON, Aug. 24--A state investment council, including a Trenton woman banker, was named today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to supervise handling of New Jersey's $300,000,000 in trust funds.
MIAMI, Aug. 24 (U.P.)--Four friends of Frank Costello and a sheriff accused of taking $200 a week protection money were rounded up today in a suddenly accelerated war on Florida's gambling empire.

The third Woodstock Art Conference will be held Sept. 1 and Sept. 2 at the Summer School of the Art Students League in Woodstock. Artists and museum directors from all parts of the country will attend the conference on "The Artists and the Museum," discussing how the museum can best serve ...

While negotiations with spokesmen for sixty striking employes were in progress, vandals slashed furniture, rugs and draperies of the Fourteen Hotel, 14 East Sixtieth Street, yesterday morning, causing damage estimated at $5,000.

Michael Grace, 34 years old, a member of the Grace steamship family, who isn't actively connected with maritime affairs, but prefers to devote his time to music publishing, is becoming a theatrical producer.

THE train was enormous. At the front were the luxury cars where the passengers en joyed every comfort, beautiful surroundings, scented air, music, magnificent food and perfect service. In the middle were the secondclass coaches and the bakery car, the laundry car, the storage cars.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 24 (UP) --A lieutenant colonel who survived the Bataan death march died trying to prove he was physically fit to be a paratrooper, officials said today.

LONDON, Aug. 24--The stock markets here were undecided today. British Government securities became slightly dull after the recent sharp advance. Losses, however, were small, especially in comparison with the gains of the last few weeks.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 24-- Communist China called upon the United Nations Security Council today to order the United States to withdraw the Seventh Fleet from its protective patrol of Formosa.

The long-standing contract dispute between the Todd Shipyards Corporation and Local 15, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., is expected to reach another crisis today as their present agreement expires at midnight.
Opening this morning at the Criterion is "The Desert Hawk," an adventure romance filmed in Technicolor by Universal-International. Yvonne De Carlo, Richard Greene and Jackie Gleason head the cast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--President Truman, emphasizing that he had been assured only an hour before the nation-wide railroad strike was called yesterday that it would not materialize, gave an implied rebuke to the unions today for their actions.
A number of manufacturers and distributors of many lines of metal products are falling behind in their delivery schedules as a result of a record volume of orders.

Listing sixty-one new playgrounds and recreation centers for construction next year, the Park Department submitted to the City Planning Commission yesterday a 1951 capital budget of $17,197,798, including a $4,578,000 carry-over from 1950.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24--Clint Hartung came out of the anonymity of the dugout tonight at Sportsman's Park to club the Giants to victory over the Cardinals before 12,812 disillusioned onlookers, and lift Leo Durocher's troupe closer to the first division.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)-- The House of Representatives by a vote of 361 to 0 today passed legislation setting up Governmentpaid family allowances of $45 to $85 a month for all enlisted men in the armed forces.

The Communist invaders have been placing less pressure on the R.O.K. (Republic of Korea) First Division, where they have been attempting to make a breakthrough to Taegu for the past few weeks, and have shifted pressure to the R.O.K. Sixth Division on the right of the R.O.K. First-Division. Pressure has been heavy, but no material gains made.
TRENTON, Aug. 24--The New Jersey Retail Gasoline Dealers Association authorized its president, John Dressler, today to organize picketing of refining companies that resort to unfair selling tactics.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 24--The City of Mount Vernon and the New Haven Railroad are feuding as to which should put a fresh coat of paint on the highway bridge that carries automobiles and pedestrian traffic over the railroad cut at Fourth Avenue and First Street in the heart of the city.

MONTREAL, Aug. 24--Nathanael V. Davis, president of Aluminium, Limited, announced here today that ordering of equipment and detailed engineering planning would commence immediately for the first alumina plant in the British West Indies.

In recent years the railroad unions have shown a steadily diminishing sense of responsibility in their wage disputes with the carriers. They have invoked the machinery of the Railway Labor Act repeatedly in cases which should and could have been handled by direct negotiation across the table ...
The Peace Information Center and its officers have bean directed by the Department of Justice to register as the agents of a foreign principal.
MADISON, N.J., Aug. 24-- John B. Ehrhardt of Kings Road may be paddling his home-made canoe toward an honorary chieftainship of a Canadian Indian tribe.
MONTREAL, Aug. 24 (AP)--Two United States professionals and one from Quebec shot 5-under-par 67s today to share the first-round lead in the Canadian Open golf championship.

The Newark Fireproof Sash Door Company has purchased from the Campbell Chain Company the one-story factory building on twoacre plot at 109 Meeker Avenue, Newark, N.J., in a cash transaction negotiated by the Charles F. Novel Comoany.
In a flurry of blueberry pie, the Boys Club of New York wound up its seventy-fourth season of summer activities yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 24--British and French defense and finance officials held a conference in two sessions today in an effort to coordinate the economies of the two nations for the impact of their respective defense programs.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 24-- Peru asked the United Nations General Assembly today to consider removing its ban on Spain's membership in the specialized agencies and also its recommendation calling on member states to curtail diplomatic representation in Madrid.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)-- The Commodity Credit Corporation reported today it had a net loss on its farm price support operations of $249,230,000 for the year ended June 30.

Mexico-bound Mayor O'Dwyer met representatives of the Latin American press yesterday, conversed with some in unfaltering Spanish, and seemed to dazzle them all with his interest in hemispheric amity and his knowledge of bullfighting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--President Truman sent to the Senate today the nomination of five delegates and five alternates to represent the United States at the forthcoming meeting of the General Assembly of the United Nations in New York.

The United States Government is considering a proposal to purchase over a three-year period approximately 440,000,000 pounds of primary aluminum from Canada for this country's emergency stockpile of critical materials.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24 (AP)-- Emory (Bubba) Church scattered five Pittsburgh hits today to pitch Philadelphia to a 4-2 victory--the fourth in a row for the National League leaders. It was Church's sixth victory against two losses.

OTTAWA, Aug. 24--Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent today summoned union and railway chiefs to confer with him and two of his key Ministers tomorrow on the railway strike that is crippling Canada's economy.

The special treatment and services needed by premature babies, crippled children and youngsters suffering from rheumatic fever are outlined clearly in three new films previewed yesterday at 1600 Broadway under the auspices of Film Program Services, 1173 Avenue of the Americas.

OMAHA, Aug. 24 (UP)--The Army said today that an Omaha doctor was making an average of $450 a day X-raying draftees and recruits, and that a doctor in Wisconsin was reported to be making more than $1,000 a day. The Army added, however, that it is "all perfectly legal."

Color in furs presents one of fashion's most fascinating stories for fall. No longer is broadtail merely black or mole unfailingly taupe; they turn up in chrome yellow, green and navy. Furs have developed into a fantasy of wonderful colors that match or contrast the ensemble.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Aug. 24 --The United States, according to a considerable and influential section of the Egyptian press and of opinion here in Egypt's summer capital, has a new policy of friendliness toward the Arab states.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 24--Dr. Clyde C. Hamilton of Rutgers University's department of entomology had reassuring news for jittery residents of nearby Raritan Township today.

Fruit and vegetable counters offer both variety and abundance this week-end, with many items lower in price. In its weekly survey of retail food prices, the City Department of Markets noted yesterday ten declines on vegetables and four on fruits.
Ohrbach's opened its Grey Room yesterday with a press preview of a collection of fall suits and coats to fit every type of woman, from the petite to the half size to the regular miss.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--Uniformly favorable comment followed the President's appointment of Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith to succeed Rear Adm. Roscoe N. Hillenkoetter in October as Director of the Central Intelligence Agency.
Distinguished newspaper editors from Western Europe, South America and Asia will come to this country to meet with leading editors here on a month's visit beginning Sept. 18.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24--Despite a slight drop in the volume of freight shipments, business in the Pittsburgh district showed a moderate gain last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Industrial production and the volume of trade were up a little.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 24-- (AP)--A buyer's market in homes will come in 1951, a group of building experts reported today. The prediction was made at a forum held as part of the National Gypsum Company's twenty-fifth anniversary celebration.

"We worked on the railroad in Korea, all day and all night long." That song echoed through the Martinique Hotel yesterday as veterans of the 749th Railway Operating Battalion, organized by the New Haven Railroad, held their first reunion here.

Early action by the City Council to approve pending bills that provide for reduction of pension fund payments by the city's 30,000 policemen and firemen while retaining the present scale of benefits was urged last night by Mayor O'Dwyer.

The acquisition of additional property for Long Island University was greeted-yesterday by public officials, business men and educators as a step in the development of educational facilities in Brooklyn.

Net income of Federated Department Stores, Inc., for the thirteenweek period ended July 29, 1950, rose 114 per cent over earnings in the second quarter of 1949, according to the quarterly report released yesterday by Fred Lazarus Jr., president.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 24--In a report to Dean Acheson, United States Secretary of State, made public today, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner, declared that in the Soviet zone "alert units" of the People's Police were being trained in fifty camps, indicating a large expansion of the east zone military training program.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ralph R. Perry of 440 Riverside Drive of the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Mitzi Ferol, to Albert Davidson Miller of New York, son of Thomas William Miller and the late Mrs. Charlotte Duffy Miller of Worcester, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)-- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that under present safeguards it would be imposible for plutonium to be stolen from an atomic project without its loss being known.

Paced by 17--year--old Larry Evans, grand-master Samuel Re shevsky and George Kramer, all of New York City, the United States team gained third place in the international team tournament at Dubrovnik last night, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

MANILA, Aug. 24--Charges involving the brother of President Elpidio Quirino and a member of his Cabinet in the sale of a landed estate of the Roman Catholic Church to the Government for 5,000,000 pesos ($2,500,000) were made in Congress today by Senator Lorenzo Tanada.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 24-- Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Frost have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Whitney, to John David Rusack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albrecht F. Rusack. The wedding will take place in the spring.
Mayor O'Dwyer took time, in the midst of clearing his desk for departure, to call public attention to one piece of important unfinished business started in his administration.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24--Up to today Eddie Arcaro, in his two decades of racetracking, never had ridden a winner of the Saratoga Cup. With the aid of Brandywine Stable's gray 4-year-old colt, Cochise, he remedied the oversight.
For a few fleeting moments at the Stadium yesterday our Yankees had a badly harassed Tiger by the tail. Then, to the dismay of 38,929 onlookers, they let the prize slip away.
Credit requirements of the cotton, textile and paper industries produced last week the twelfth consecutive increase in bank loans in the New York area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24--Congress had ready for imminent action tonight $50,000,000,000 in appropriations meeting every military request of the President but striking hard at the nonmilitary parts of his foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced today that after July 1, 1952, air traffic controllers will use the hautical speed and distance terms--knots and nautical miles--in all communications with aircraft. Military planes already use them.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 24--The Russians at the European track and field championships refused tonight to accept an official decision to rerun a disputed relay race. As Russians do everywhere, they referred their quarrel with meet officials to Moscow "for instructions."

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 (AP) --Firing with a borrowed gun and shooting in competition for the first time in ten years, Alvin Hextell of Newark, Ill., today won the preliminary handicap, second biggest event on the Grand American trapshoot program, with a perfect score.

Officials of the world's largest securities exchange yesterday confirmed reports which have been prevalent for the last few months. Mr. Schram was not ...

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 25--Andrew C. Petersen's Volo A.C., 3year-old bay filly by Nibble Hanover from West Hartford, Conn., turned in a world's record performance of 2:04 4-5 to win the junior free-for-all mile trot before 14,667 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Gene Pownall drove the filly.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) --Oscar Scheske Jr., 48-year-old trapshooting unknown from Belleville, Ill., came from nowhere in the closing minutes today to win the biggest clay target prize, the Grand American Handicap.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 25--The Middlesex grand jury, in a presentment handed up to County Judge Charles M. Morris today, urged the Legislature to change the law in regard to deaths caused by automobile.
The market for new capital issues promises to be enlivened over the final week of August by three bond flotations.
The cotton futures market of the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 1 point lower to 14 points net higher than on Thursday.

DETROIT, Aug. 25--The Chrysler Corporation today voluntarily gave its 120,000 employes wage increases that will cost the company $25,000,000 a year. The action is without parallel in the history of the automotive industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UP)-- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, and Admiral Forrest P. Sherman, Chief of Naval Operations, returned today from a personal inspection of the Korean battlefront with high praise for Gen. Douglas MacArthur's forces.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--Average primary market prices advanced 0.7 per cent in the week ended on Aug. 22, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
A series of five small fires during the last two weeks, all evidently of incendiary origin, was under investigation yesterday at Bruckner Houses, the Bronx.

HONG KONG, Aug. 25--To the skirling of bagpipes played by a kilted regimental band that threatened to mutiny if it were left behind, 1,500 British troops boarded two naval vessels here today and sailed for Korea.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 25--Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Ladds of Shaker Heights have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary, to Dr. William Ellery Sedgwick James, son of Mrs. Ellery Sedgwick James of New York and Berrywold, East Hampton, L.I., and the late Mr. James. The wedding has been planned for the autumn.

THE Montauk tuna continue to hold the spotlight in coastal angling, and in view of the number of fish brought in from Rosie's Ledge, compared with the average number of anglers fishing, this area is unquestionably the number one tuna spot on the coast.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense, denied at some length today reports that have frequently been published concerning alleged personal friction between himself and Dean Acheson, Secretary of State. Mr. Johnson's comments were made as he left President Truman's weekly Cabinet meeting.

Little wonder the Browns are in the American League cellar, thirtyfive lengths off the pace, When a big league club (?) makes as many errors as it does base hits, which Zach Taylor's outfit did against the Yankees at the Stadium last night, that's the tip-off.

The Festival Theatre, organized for presenting repertory plays on Broadway during the hot weather months, announced yesterday that it had canceled the fourth and final bill, "Crimes and Crimes," originally scheduled to open at the Fulton Theatre on Sept. 4.

The rayon and silk printing and dyeing industry appealed to Washington yesterday to do all in its power to end the strike of soda ash workers and keep the industry operating.
MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 25--Plans to build a potential $40,000,000 paper mill at Naheola, Ala., were announced by Paul D. Hammacher, president of the Choctaw Pulp and Paper Company of Butler, Ala.
MONTREAL, Aug. 25 (AP)--Stan Leonard of Vancouver shot a record-breaking 6-under-par 66 today to take the lead with 134 at the halfway mark in the Canadian Open golf championship.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25--Kent Miller's 12-year-old Elkridge, the most remarkable race horse this side of Tierra Del Fuego, showed 'em again today who's the boss of the steeplechasers. He led all the way, for two and a half miles over sixteen jumps, in the $11,600 Saratoga Steeplechase.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--There is no immediate danger of a serious shortage of replacement parts for television and radio receivers, Robert C. Sprague, president of the Radio-Television Manufacturers Association, said today.
European-made hardware and tool lines are for the first time being ordered by large New York distributors for regular stock inventories.

OTTAWA, Aug. 25--Negotiations to end Canada's four-day railroad strike were resumed at 8:15 o'clock tonight but after a two-hour-and-20-minute session the talks were adjourned until 11 A.M. tomorrow.
A "substantial" jail term awaits Ramon Scheer when he returns from his honeymoon.

A young automobile thief, escaping in a new automobile, was shot and critically wounded by a patrolman amid heavy vehicular and pedestrian traffic near Grand Central Terminal late yesterday afternoon.

The United States has dropped from third to sixth place among the world's principal shipbuilding nations, with only twenty-one vessels totalling 327,120 gross tons on the ways at the end of the quarter on July 31.

The Associated Fur Manufacturers will continue its opposition to the measure now before the Senate calling for labeling of fur products, it was declared yesterday by Manfred H. Benedek, counsel to the organization.

LANDSBERG, Germany, Aug. 25--Friedrich Flick, one-time steel lord of the Ruhr, and Otto Dietrich, Hitler's press chief, were among the nineteen war criminals released from Landsberg Prison today, after having served two-thirds of their sentences.

The Hencey Realty Corporation, representing Harlem operators, has purchased the building containing two stores and twenty-two apartments and occupying a lot 26 by 100 feet at 1447 Boston Post Road, the Bronx, in a deal negotiated by the A.J. Clarke Management Corporation, broker.

BOSTON, Aug. 25--The United States should be willing to pay any price to achieve a world at peace, "even the price of instituting a war to compel cooperation for peace," Secretary of the Navy Francis P. Matthews said tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 --The Screen Writers Guild avoided action on the question of mandatory anti-Communist loyalty oaths for all members at a membership meeting last night at the Beverly Hills Hotel.

President Truman rests his order, issued yesterday, for Government seizure of the railroads on the argument that "in the strike situation that is confronting us" this action "is imperative for the protection of our citizens."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--Deadlocked over wage-price-rationing controls, the Senate-House conference committee, meeting on the Defense Production Bill, adjourned tonight until Tuesday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 25 (AP)-- Fernando Fernandez displayed a dazzling exhibition of saddle work at the Atlantic City race track today when he drove home five winners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--The Government acted today to restrict sugar speculators who might attempt to export domestic supplies in order to profit from selling sugar in places abroad where prices are higher than at home.

The innovation of passing a general appropriation bill providing for all functions of government in one fell swoop has much to defend it in theory.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 25--Jacob A. Malik, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, told the United Nations Security Council today that he had received more than 3,000 telegrams from all parts of the world accusing the United States of having started aggressive action in Korea.

A big, blond Norwegian shipmaster fidgeted nervously on the bridge of the Ivaran Line freighter Reinholt at a Brooklyn pier yesterday while the United States Government expressed its deep appreciation for the help he gave American women and children evacuees from Korea early in the war.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25-- The Navy hospital ship Benevolence sank this evening off the Golden Gate after being in collision with the freighter Mary Luckenbach in a dense fog.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--A House committee investigating lobby activities will decide tomorrow whether to ask contempt citations against Dr. Edward A. Rumely, executive secretary of the Committee for Constitutional Government, and two other persons who have appeared before the committee as witnesses.

Woman suffrage became law thirty years ago today. The Democratic party has been in office eighteen of these thirty years; there has been a marked increase in government control and in social legislation, reflecting the importance which security plays in the minds of the voters.

Conferences on human relations for college and high school students from the five boroughs and from Westchester County and Long Island will be started next week under auspices of the New York Region of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25-- Twentieth Century-Fox today announced that it had bought an original story by Robert Thoeren to be made into a screen comedy under the title "Mabel and Me," which the studio registered three weeks ago.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 25-- Secretary of the Army Frank Pace Jr. today denied published reports of a timetable calling for an end to the fighting in Korea by Thanksgiving Day. He said he considered "dangerous" the announcing of such a timetable, and that even if one did exist, he would not make it public.
Four officials of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., charged with leading a three-day unauthorized bus strike, went on trial yesterday before a four-man union board.
Slated for high-school corridors and classrooms this fall, according to Gimbels, will be many clothes of bright corduroy, gray flannel, wool plaids and jersey worn with school coats of chinchilla.

LAFAYETTE, N.J., Aug. 25-- Joseph Stagg Lawrence, vice president of the Empire Trust Company of New York and an economic consultant, died of a heart attack while swimming in a private pond near his home here today. His age was 54.

Mayor O'Dwyer refused again yesterday to comment on the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's disclosure that it had leased "some" apartments in its Stuyvesant Town housing project to "qualified Negro families."
Behind the tedious hours of yesterday's session of the Security Council there was awareness of another Communist maneuver and of the American reply to it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25--Malachy J. Coghlan, Republican candidate for Sheriff of Cook County, who was regarded as the spearhead of the G.O.P. county ticket in the fall elections, died of uremic poisoning today in Mercy Hospital. He was 50 years old.
BELFAST, Tenn., Aug. 25--Dr. Harcourt Alexander Morgan, a Canadian who became one of the South's greatest leaders in agriculture, died today in his home here at the age of 82.
WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, in Korea, Saturday, Aug. 28--Three badly mauled enemy divisions are withdrawing out of American artillery range on this front.

Retail sales here continued to be higher than figures established last year, according to estimates made yesterday by trade observers. Department store sales were estimated to be about 8 per cent ahead of the corresponding week last year. Sales last week were 6 per cent ahead of last year.
Dr. Robert J. Wiseman has been appointed vice president and chief engineer of The Okonite Company, Passaic, N.J. He formerly was chief engineer.

GERMAN, Aug. 25--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer has proposed to the Western Allies a three-point program for the defense of Germany, including the establishment of a "protective police force" patterned after that of the Weimar Republic.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 25 (AP)-- The Rev. Thomas Carroll of Boston, director of the Catholic Guild for the Blind, today described a proposed garden apartment project of the American War Blinded Veterans, Inc., of New York, as a "ghetto for the blind."

The combined operation of a Coast Guard cutter, seaplane, helicopter and launch that lasted through the night resulted in the successful removal yesterday of a seriously ill merchant marine engineer from a Greek freighter 500 miles east of New York to the United States Marine Hospital at Stapleton, S.I.
A new quota of 16,500 Army veterans of the Enlisted Reserve will be recalled to service in September and October in the First Army Area. Of these 10,560 will come from New York State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (U.P.)-- If you lived mainly on fresh vegetables and fruits during the first half of August, your food bills should have been somewhat lower than those of last month, the Government said today.

I have today issued an executive order providing for taking over the country's railroads at 4 P.M., Eastern standard time, on Aug. 27, 1950, and providing for their operation by the Secretary of the Army in the name of the United States Government.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--The House of Representatives approved today a $36,141,590,425 omnibus appropriation, of which more than $16,000,000,000 is for defense of the Western world, and voted to make Spain a beneficiary of the Marshall Plan.

Harcourt A. Morgan, who died yesterday in Belfast, Tenn., a few days before his eighty-third birthday, had one great ambition. That was to make the land of the Tennessee Valley green and fruitful, producing better and more abundant harvests and more happiness for the people who live in it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP)--Capt. Agostino Straulino of the Italian Navy today hit rough seas which put him out of the leadership in the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association's world championships.
STRASBOURG, France, Aug. 25 (AP)--The European Consultative Assembly approved unanimously today a proposal to set up a European supreme court to enforce a bill of human rights in member states.

The Senate Crime Investigating Committee headed by Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee began yesterday a preliminary investigation of the attempt by the Peoples Express Company of Newark to get long-term control of the Port of New York Authority's union terminal in Newark.

Donald Picard, 24-year-old Pennsylvania balloonist, son of Jean Picard, aeronautics professor at the University of Minnesota, sailed on the French liner Liberte yesterday to represent the United States in the international balloon races at Amsterdam, Holland.

BACLIEU, Indo-China, Aug. 25--One of the main arenas of the struggle between the Vietminh rebels and the French-Vietnamese forces lies inland from here in a flat water-logged triangular slab of territory known as the TransBassac.

With the exception of one game between Argentina and Chile, six rounds of the international chess team tournament were completed last night, when all other adjourned games pending were played off in Dubrovnik, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

Merger of the manufacturing facilities of two of the city's oldest printing concerns, resulting in the largest combined letterpress and offset commercial printing plant in the metropolitan area, was announced yesterday.

With vacations nearly over and families settling down at home once more, the spotlight seems to center again on the children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-The Interstate Commerce Commission today took steps it said would expedite disposition of problems of classifying freight, which have been before it formally for consideration since 1939.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP)-For the second time in as many days Boston's Red Sox refused to roll over and play dead for Cleveland as they overcame a 12-1 Indian lead today for a stormy 15-14 victory before 28,328 fans.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28-Dr. Ralph Walter Plummer, a retired captain in the Navy Medical Corps and a surgeon for fifty years, died today in Hahnemann Hospital, where he had been medical director from 1930 to 1948. His age was 75.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--Lee Pressman, former Government attorney and former general counsel for the Congress of Industrial Organizations, identified under protest today three early New Deal key men who, he said, had served with him in a Communist party group assigned to the Department of Agriculture.

Mayor O'Dwyer told his Committee on Management Survey at a farewell meeting yesterday that it was the most important committee in the city and that its work would show where the city was going in the next fifty years.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Aug. 28-Dr. George L. Gabler, retied physician and surgeon, who contributed to the devising of basketball, died today in Holyoke Hospital, where he had been under treatment for-two weeks. He was 81 years old.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28-The National Encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today received in silence the information that Gen. Douglas MacArthur had been directed to withdraw a message addressed to it, then voted unanimously and heartily to "express complete confidence in his integrity and ability."

DETROIT, Aug. 28-The Packard Motor Car Company today reached a settlement with the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O., on a five-year contract calling for annual pay increases, a cost-of-living provision and $125 monthly pensions for 8,000 production workers.

ALBANY, Aug. 28--Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein rejected today an appeal from a state ruling affirming the right of the New York City Board of Education to establish the post of "special consultant" to serve as trial examiner for eight teachers who were suspended for refusing to say whether they were or had been Communists.
The "Pen of America" is particularly busy this week counteracting Communist propaganda in the Iron Curtain countries on the meaning of Labor Day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--President Truman today signed the Social Security bill bringing Federal old age insurance to 10,000,000 more persons and additional benefits to millions already covered. He also asked Congress for $134,170,300 to carry out its provisions.

The Fordham football picture for 1950 on Rose Hill is rosier than it has been since 1941. With twentyseven lettermen included in the group, Fordham opened pre-season practice yesterday when a squad of sixty varsity men reported to Head Coach Ed Danowski.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28-The Dodgers' pennant hopes bogged down in the Mississippi badlands today when the Cardinals made it two straight over them behind the unbeatable pitching of Gerry Staley before 21,383 fans. The score was 3-1.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 28-The Australian Government, through its External Affairs Minister, Percy C. Spender, made it known today that it wants to be consulted before any change is made in the political status of Western New Guinea, now held by the Netherlands but claimed by Indonesia.

MYRTLE BEACH, S. C., Aug. 28 (UP)-An off-duty policeman wearing the robe of the Ku Klux Klan over his uniform was killed in a 300-shot battle between the Hlan and a group inside a Negro dance hall, the police reported today.

ALBANY, Aug. 28-Despite record--making revenue exceeding $850,000,000, the state's general fund showed a deficit of $9,084,337.03 for the fiscal year ending last March 31, Controller Frank C. Moore reported today.

To open the Crusade for Freedom, a ten-ton bronze Freedom Bell is on its way to the United States, Gen, Lucius D. Clay, chairman of the crusade, announced yesterday.

A group of youthful seafarers, their faces bronzed by nearly three months of off-shore duty and their biceps and forearms reflecting the degree to which they had applied "Norwegian steam" in their daily tasks, returned to local waters yesterday after completing a Mediterianean cruise.

GLOVERSVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 28 (AP)--The board of directors of the Kiwanis Club here canceled tonight an invitation to Owen Lattimore to speak at the regular luncheon meeting tomorrow. The board gave no reason for its action.
KENT, Conn., Aug. 28-Spencer Baird Nichols, artist and member of the National Academy of Design, died at his home here last night after a long illness. His age was 75.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28-- The Federal Government late today filed a damage suit for $14,000,000 against the Luckenbach Steamship Company as an aftermath of the sinking of the Navy hospital ship Benevolence by the freighter Mary Luckenbach.

PARIS, Aug. 28--The executive board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today unanimously committed the agency to a positive program in support of the United Nations action in Korea.

LONDON, Aug. 28--Hesitancy of buyers in the London stock markets was reflected in small price declines in most sections today. SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 28 (AP) --Gov. Luis Mufioz Marin said today he had reached agreement with a representative of Michigan on terms for paying Puerto Rican farm workers now in that state. The Governor advised the workers to remain and harvest the sugar beet crop from September to November.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 28Franklin K. Mathiews of 180 Walnut Street, for the last twentythree years associate editor of Boys' Life magazine, published by the Boy Scouts of America, died here today in Mountainside Hospital, where he had been for a month. He was--77 nears old.

Malik of the Soviet Union demanded today that the Security Council omit from its report to the General Assembly--which is to cover the period from July 16, 1949 to July 15, 1950--any reference to its decisions on Korea or to any other actions taken after Mr. Malik's walkout on Jan. 13.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--Congress approved and sent to the President today a $36,153,490,425 omnibus appropriations bill, the first of its sort in this country's history.

Net income of Crown Zellerbach Corporation and its subsidiaries for the quarter ended on July 31, subject to annual audit and year-end adjustment, rose 51 per cent over the 1949 July quarter, it was announced yesterday. Net sales were 27 per cent over the same quarter a year earlier.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, Aug. 28-The First Presbyterian Church here was the setting this morning for the marriage of Miss Janet Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George McClelland Foster, to Thorndike Saville Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Saville of Riverdale, New York.

EAST GREENWICH, R.I., Wednesday, Aug. 30 (AP)--Police Chief Charles R. Johnson said early today that Edwin H. Reynolds, 27, would be charged with murder in the deaths of five persons found in the burned ruins of a home here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)-- The problem of what to do about color television was complicated further today when Color Television Incorporated of San Francisco announced a "wholly new and unique" method called "Uniplex."

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Aug. 29 (AP)--West Germany and Japan probably will be permitted to come back into the Olympic Games fold in 1952, at Helsinki. SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29-- The master of the freighter Mary Luckenbach, involved in collision with the Navy hospital ship Benevolence which sank with a loss of at least eighteen lives on Friday evening, testified today that he had no intimation for almost an hour and a half after the impact that the Benevolence was in trouble.

The Oxford University Players, who have been visiting campus theatres at Eastern universities for the last two months, began last night a three-evening stand at the Master Institute Theatre before returning to England.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 29 --Gerard Beekman Hoppin, New York broker and civic leader, died today in Southampton Hospital after a long illness. His age was 80. He had homes at 19 East Seventy-second Street, New York, and Syosset, L.I.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 29--The Socialist Trade Union Federation has begun a campaign to enlist the world's nonCommunist workers in a moral battle against Communist power, which, it says has betrayed the working class. It also accuses Communist power of starting open warfare in Korea.

The newest collection of upholstered furniture to be presented here seems to offer further proof that chairs and sofas today tend to go to extremes when it comes to scale.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 29 (AP) --James E. (Sonny) Fraser, nationally known amateur golfer and speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, died today of Hodgkin's disease at his home. He was 33 years old.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 29--The United Nations Security Council decided today to take up Communist China's charges that the United States has committed an aggression by stationing naval and air units in Formosa.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--The Senate unanimously approved today a bill to draft physicians, dentists, veterinarians and other medical specialists for the armed forces. A similar bill is expected to be brought before the House tomorrow, following recommendation today by its Armed Services Committee.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29--General short covering, which started in wheat and spread to other grains, carried prices higher on the Board of Trade here today.
The stock market staged a general rally yesterday, but the force diminished to such an extent in the afternoon that closing prices were well below the highs of the day.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--President Truman followed up today his rebuke to Gen. Douglas MacArthur by sending him a definitive copy of this country's policy on the troublesome Formosa issue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, exchanged undiplomatic notes today.

The thirteen-story apartment house for twenty-five families at 530 West End Avenue, southeast corner of Eighty-sixth Street, has been purchased by Knepper Levin from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in a cash deal negotiated by Joseph H. Nassoit, broker.
Opening this morning at the Paramount is "Fancy Pants," a Paramount comedy in Technicolor, starring Bob Hope and Lucille Ball, produced by Robert Welch and directed by George Marshall.

CHICAGO, Aug, 29--Big Don Newcombe put the Dodgers back on the winning highway today. His pitching, coupled with one explosive inning, gave the Brooks an 8-2 triumph over the Cubs at Wrigley Field on this unseasonably chilly afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--The Senate's Democratic leaders decided today to try to close the work of Congress by Sept. 9 for an election-year fall vacation of undetermined duration.

Fifty all-steel standard coaches of the New York Central System are being completely renovated and air-conditioned for use on suburban lines north of the electrified parts of the railroad's Harlem and Hudson divisions, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture forecast today that the nation's farmers will get $2,500,000,000 more cash income from their products during 1950 than it had estimated last April. But production expenses also are increasing.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 29--Following is the unofficial verbatim record of today's meeting of the United Nations Security Council:
Forty-four United States business men and leaders in Jewish philanthropic agencies will leave for Jerusalem tomorrow for a special three-day conference on Israel's economic and financial problems.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--President Truman strongly and formally asked Congress today to withhold until next January action on universal military training lest more urgent military matters be slighted.
DETROIT, Aug. 29--The Budd Company tonight became the latest automotive industry supplier to grant a voluntary wage increase.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 29-- Argentina again devalued the peso in respect to the dollar at noon today following the announcement at midnight of drastic changes in the specialized exchange rates that apply to imports and exports.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 29 (AP)-- Brookmeade Stable's Gnu scored his first victory of the year in the Ocean City Purse before a ladies' day crowd of 13,541 today. The 4year-old gelding received a strong ride from Joe Culmone to prevail by a neck over Justin Funkhouser's Aura Lee.
Francis J. Sinnott, Kings County Clerk, was re-elected yesterday as Brooklyn Democratic leader at the organization meeting of the newly elected district leaders. He will serve until September, 1952.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 29-- Amid criticism from various quarkters of the Government's progress in marshalling reserves of strategic war materials, Carl Rolle, stockpiling adviser of the Federal Munitions Board, acknowledged today that from the standpoint of balanced procurement "we are not in as good shape as we could wish."

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 29-- Lewis R. Gwyn of 1 Pinecrest Road here, retired vice president of the Railway Express Agency in charge of personnel, who had served that corporation for forty-six years at his retirement in 1938, died today in the White Plains Hospital at the age of 75.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Aug. 29-- A cold, steady rain which began at 7:30 o'clock this morning and lasted until noon forced the withdrawal today of more than 8,000 members of the National Guard from bivouac areas to their barracks in camp.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP)--Boston's blazing Red Sox pounded three pitchers for fifteen hits, including a pair of homers by Bobby Doerr, today to overwhelm the White Sox, 13--6.
Spokesmen for general trucking employers predicted last night there would be no strike in the industry.

The Yankees and Indian's, battling in the wake of the Tigers in the seething American League pennant race, strove for more than six hours at the Stadium yesterday to complete an afternoon doubleheader with the aid of flood lights and repeated tarpaulin operations by the ground crew.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)-- Washington's Sid Hudson further tightened the American League race tonight by beating Detroit, 5--4. President and Mrs. Truman, attending unannounced, saw the Senators shave the Tigers' margin over the second-place Yankees to 2 percentage points, with the rivals now even in games.
HONG KONG, Aug. 29--Large garrison forces of the Chinese Communist army are reported engaged in agricultural work on more than 550,000 acres of plowed land as part of the "army production" movement.
Three thunder squalls struck the metropolitan area late yesterday and added to the travail of soggy New Yorkers who had suffered through a day of uncomfortable heat and high humidity.

The Marines landed at the Red Cross Blood Donor Center at 70 West Fortieth Street yesterday along with the Army, Navy and Air Force in response to the second urgent SOS for O type blood needed in Korea. A hundred military persons and civilians responded to the call.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29--The Lorain (Ohio) Journal and four of its officers are guilty of an attempt to monopolize news and advertising in violation of the Sherman Anti-trust Law, Federal Judge Emerich B. Freed ruled here today.

Mid-summer or not, this is still Bach's year, and the Interval Concerts at the Carl Fischer Concert Hall last night took cognizance of the 200th anniversary of the master's death by presenting a concert devoted to his music.
PARIS has been so dearly beloved and so much written about by English and Ameri cans that sometimes we are in danger of forgetting that Frenchmen, too, feel strongly about their capital city.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29--Marx Leva, Assistant Secretary of Defense, today told the National Encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, which will entertain a resolution tomorrow calling for the removal of Defense Secretary Louis Johnson, that Government officials were accustomed to misrepresentations, and that most such misrepresentations were political.

Additional political pressure was brought to bear upon Lieut, Gov. Joe R. Hanley yesterday by Republican leaders in the metropolitan area in an effort to induce him to withdraw as a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor.
Health Commissioner John F. Mahoney said last night that the city planned to recruit teams of science teachers to serve as "radiation monitors" in case of atomic attack.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 29 --Edwin Mallery of Dunwoodie and his son, Edwin Mallery Jr. of Knolhwood, the latter a crack golfer in his undergraduate days, conquered the elements and a field of fifty-four other tandems to gain the Westchester father-and-son championship at the Knollwood Country Club today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Aug. 29--Australia's view that Indonesia has no valid claim to Dutch Nezv Guinea has been formally communicated to the Netherlands and Indonesia Governments during the visit here of Percy C. Spender, External Affairs Minister of Australia.
An increase in the retail price of milk of 1 cents a quart, the third in the last three months, was announced yesterday by the two major dealers in the metropolitan area.
THE suspense is now over, where migratory bird seasons are concerned, for President Truman signed the waterfowl regulations on ducks, geese, coots, woodcock and doves yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29--Prices of finished diamonds have been increased since the Korean war started, Benjamin Arnstein of the New York concern of Arnstein Brothers Co., said today in an interview at the National Jewelry Fair.

ATHENS, Aug. 29--Leading newspapers here will continue to report the abduction of Thassoula Petrakogiorgis by Constantine Kefalougianis despite a blackout on the story of the Cretan romance effective today.

Approaching the end of the most turbulent but also the most sterile month in its history, the Security Council yesterday administered another defeat involving another rebuke to Jacob Malik, Soviet delegate and Council President, who has been responsible for its paralysis.

The report of Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for the first six months of 1950, released yesterday by Robert E. Gross, president, showed that net profit was more than double that reported for the same period last year, while sales of airplanes, parts and services were sharply higher than in the corresponding period of 1949.

BECAUSE baseball standings can change more abruptly than a woman's mind, words of wisdom spoken as recently as a week ago often no longer hold water. Red Rolfe is a sincere, frank and intelligent young man who was believed when he said the other day that he feared only the Yankees.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 29-- Sixty of eighty stevedores who first balked at unloading a cargo of Russian goods from the Tornator, a Finnish Lines ship at the Bayway Terminal on the Arthur Kill here today, eventually went to work after being assured by their union that most of the cargo was required for national defense.

WADING RIVER, L.I., Aug. 29 --William G. Lipsey Jr., a 14-yearold Boy Scout who disappeared from Camp Wauwepex here last Saturday, was found today hiding in an abandoned lean-to on a little used part of the heavily wooded 600-acre camp site.

LAKE SUCCESSS, Aug. 29-- The United States today told the United Nations it would "welcome" an on-the-spot investigation of Communist China's accusations that American planes strafed Manchurian territory last Sunday.

If the 121 guests who voted against allowing Owen Lattimore to make a scheduled speech in a New Hampshire resort hotel last Sunday had been asked if they believed in the principles of democracy and the American Constitution, we are confident that all of them would have said yes.

Jumpers are double daters for college girls this semester. In sporty tweeds they are complemented with make-believe diamonds and worn on a date. The same dress goes to class the next day over a high-necked sweater or shirtwaist.

Miss Althea Gibson of New York, the first Negro player to compete in the national championship of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, was leading Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., Wimbledon titleholder, by 7--6 in the third and final set at Forest Hills yesterday when the match was interrupted by a cloudburst.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--Official counts today indicated an extremely close Senate vote on immediate imposition of an excessprofits tax on corporations, with the outcome wholly in doubt.
The Case of the Prospect Heights Housecats continued to baffle police and agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals late last night. And a new mystery was added:

OTTAWA, Aug. 29--Drastic back-to-work legislation to end Canada's nationwide railroad strike was before Parliament tonight amid reports that the strikers would call off the walkout tomorrow before the legislature acted.

Baby Comet had all the luck in the Bridal Flower, six-furlong race for fillies and mare that served as the feature at Aqueduct yesterday. The 3-year-old daughter of Teddy's Comet was the evenmoney favorite and she won, but only after a close battle wih the Warbern Stable's Fighting Fan, who finished second, and Lawrence Jennings' Winter Wheat, who was third in the field of six.

The H.C. Frick Coke Company, the coal mining subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, announced yesterday plans to bring into operation two mines in Pennsylvania with a total capacity of 8,000 tons a day "to help meet the continuing demand for additional coal required to make more steel for national defense purposes."

A virtual "purge" of radio and television actors, writers, producers and directors listed in the booklet called "Red Channels" appeared imminent last night as many sponsors and advertising agencies reexamined the records of their broadcasting personnel.

The City of Los Angeles, Calif., will offer $13,600,000 of various purpose bonds on Dec. 5. After sale of the issue, which will rank as a general obligation of the city, Los Angeles will have $3,458,000 in bonds that have been authorized but not yet sold.

Grocery inventories at all levels are strong but not top-heavy and buying has settled to "good but not abnormal" throughout the country, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, reported yesterday. Mr. Willis has just returned from a survey of food conditions in the western part of the country.
Whole tomatoes, so much more versatile than in the saucelike form, now may be canned at home with results as satisfactory as those obtained by commercial packers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--The $62,500,000 loan to Spain as provided for in the omnibus appropriations bill now before President Truman should be administered in the same manner as any other fund under the Economic Cooperation Administration in order to be fully effective, Paul G. Hoffman, the E.C.A. chief said today.
The ironic contradictions of war were again illustrated by the Korean campaign yesterday.
Housewives got official assurances yesterday that they would find the forms to be used in paying social security taxes for domestic help easy on the mind, if not on the pocketbook.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--A high State Department official asserted today that 60 to 90 per cent of the "captive populations" of the Soviet satellites were opposed to their Moscow rulers.

The demand for cattle hides, the raw material of the shoe industry, turned active yesterday as prices advanced 114 to 140 points in the hide futures market on the Commodity Exchange. Trading volume expanded to eighty-eight contracts, which constituted a total turnover of 3,520,000 pounds.
Union Bag paper Corporation authorized the payment of an extra dividend of 50 cents and a regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents, both payable on Sept. 15.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)-- The Delaware Power and Light Company, Wilmington, filed a statement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking registration of $12,000,000 of first mortgage and collateral trust bonds, due on Sept. 1, 1980.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 29 --Senator Robert A. Taft, cheerfully running a gantlet of jeers and boos from a group of steel workers who had left their jobs today in protest against his appearance, carried his campaign for re-election into the highly industizalized Mahoning Valley.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP)-- Senator Owen Brewster, Republican of Maine, angrily told the Senate today that "scandalous and utterly perjured testimony" has been leveled against him in the current Senate wiretapping investigation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 29-- The executive board of the Screen Writers Guild at a meeting last night took no action on the recent proposal that loyalty oaths be made mandatory for all representatives on the board and all new members.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29-- While a great deal of Indian public opinion leans toward the Soviet case, or at least is inclined against United States policy in the Far East, all indications are that despite this the Communist party of India is losing ground in most of the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29--One of the primary aims of the meeting of the Western Big Three foreign ministers next month will be to develop greater solidarity against the divisive propaganda techniques of the Soviet Union.

Big copper and brass distributors here have started putting in warehouse stocks of German, Swiss and French copper and brass finished products because demand is far in excess of deliveries offered by American mills.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 (AP)--Robin Roberts hurled four-hit ball for eight innings, but--Jim Konstanty had to stop a ninth-inning Cardinal rally to give the Phillies a 5-to-3 victory tonight. The triumph kept Philadelphia five and a half games ahead of the second-place Dodgers.

The race for the Democratic nomination for Governor appeared yesterday to have narrowed down to two candidates, Charles S. Desmond of Buffalo and Albert Conway of Brooklyn, both Associate Judges of the State Court of Appeals.

The Securities and Exchange Commission served notice on the $2,000,000,000 mutual investment fund industry yesterday that it intended to keep a sharp eye on any promotional literature issued in connection with the sale of shares in such companies.

A banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., is offering $9,500,000 of first mortgage 2 7/8 per cent bonds of Indiana Gas and Water Company, Inc., due Sept. 1, 1980, at 100 to yield 2.85 per cent.

For the first time since the end of World War II the United States Government will use the "auction" method to buy West Coast softwoods in Portland, Ore., on Sept. 12 and 13.

Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation and subsidiaries yesterday reported record consolidated earnings of $3,559,827 for the thirty-nine weeks ended Aug. 5. This compares with a profit of $2,256,718 for the corresponding period a year earlier.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 30-- Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation announced here today that its XP5Y-1, the world's first turbo-prop flying boat, has established a new world flight endurance record for turbo-prop aircraft.

The Yankees' long climb to reclaim the peak in the American League pennant standing rushed to a grand climax at the Stadium yesterday when, to the cheers of 30,516 onlookers, they toppled Lou Boudreau's Indians in both ends of a double-header.

Dealer orders to distributors of the Crosley division, Avco Manufacturing Corporation, for delivery from August through October total more than $100,000,000 at retail.

Jacodema of the Apheim Stable won the Astarita Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. Favored by the crowd of 15,292, the daughter of Jacopo gave an even performance in taking the $10,000 added sixfurlongs dash, which enjoyed its fifth running.

DWIGHT, Ill., Aug. 30--Frank Leslie Smith, banker, farmland owner and former Congressman who was denied the United States Senate seat to which he was elected in 1926, died today of pneumonia in his home here. He was 82 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30--Formal announcement was made today that Yugoslavia would receive another $15,000,000 loan from the United States. Secretary of State Dean Acheson made a statement to that effect and the Export-Import Bank announced its agreement in principle to make the fund available.

For the culinary department we propose a relatively laborless Labor Day week-end--a series of easy, moderately priced menus. Let us leave complicated cookery to such other holidays as Christmas, New Year's, Easter. The long week-end
Gil Hodges made baseball history as the Dodgers made merry with the Braves by beating them, 19--3, at Ebbets Field last night.

Homemakers stocking up on perishables for the Labor Day weekend will find that meats have taken another upward spurt. Seven cuts are up in price 2 to 6 cents a pound since last Friday, with pork advancing the most.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP)-- House Democratic Leader John W. McCormack of Massachusetts today warned the Republicans away from a "MacArthur Formosa gag" as an election campaign issue.

The five Democratic county leaders of New York City took formal action yesterday to recommend Associate Judge Albert Conway of the State Court of Appeals for nomination for Governor by the Democratic State Convention.

ALBANY, Aug. 31--Senator Thomas C. Desmond today submitted recommendations for a comprehensive legislative program designed to insure for the state's older residents fair employment opportunities and full health, recreation and education facilities.

TETERBORO, N.J., Aug. 31-- The "wildcat" strike of 3,000 hourly-rate employes of the EclipsePioneer division of the Bendix Aviation Corporation that started here with last midnight's shift will continue tomorrow to give all union members a chance to vote.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 31-- Frank Bessac, 28, a student from Lodi, Calif., has arrived in New Delhi after an eleven-month trek over the Himalayas from Sinkiang to escape capture by the Communists who took over the northwest China province last September.
Dr. John D. Silson, a 36-year-old physician, was injured seriously yesterday morning in a rush-hour subway accident.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (AP)--The rights of baseball players called into military service will be protected under the same plan observed during the last world war, it was decided today.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 31 --Miss Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood scored 41, 40--81 today to capture the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, New Jersey Division, for classes A and B, at the Crestmont Country Club course.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP)--Boston's Red Sox kept within reaching distance of the American League leading New York Yankees today by beating Chicago's White Sox, 4--3, in a game held up for 61 minutes by rain.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31--The national encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars today unanimously elected Charles C. Rails of Seattle, Wash., a World War II veteran, as national commander-in-chief for the coming year. He succeeds Clyde A. Lewis of Plattsburg, N.Y., also a veteran of World War II.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--Both Houses of Congress adopted today and sent to the White House a bill to provide dependency allowances for the families of enlisted personnel in the armed forces. A compromise reached... forces.
The little blue-and-white cards with the red numbers that identify the social security accounts of 35,000,000 American wage-earners become their passport to a richer old age, effective today.
OTTAWA, Aug. 31 (AP)--Canada today announced a sharp reduction in import controls on United States goods, restricted because of a dollar shortage. The new relaxations become effective Oct. 1.
FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 31--New York City's first 108 draftees turned out for 4:45 A.M. reveille here today as sleepy, straggling civilians.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)-- The sagging Detroit Tigers slipped another game out of first place by taking a 2 to 1 beating from Washington's Senators today.

Mayor O'Dwyer's farewell message to the people of the City of New York follows: In a few more days I will no longer be your Mayor. I am going in response to a call by the President to assume the duties of Ambassador to Mexico. But before leaving I want to talk to you, the people of the City of New York, officially for the last time.

It ought not be necessary for the United States Secretary of State to reiterate, again and again, that this country has no hostility toward the Chinese people and no aggressive intentions in the Far East.
Fresh enemy divisions were reported massing on the Korean front yesterday as the Chinese Communists again complained that our aircraft had violated the Manchurian frontier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--Huntington T. Morse, United States delegate, to the North Atlantic Planding Board for Ocean Shipping, will leave for London by air Saturday to attend a working group session of the board preparatory to its meeting here in November. Mr. Morse is special assistant to the Administrator of the Maritime Administration.

Although trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month dropped to the smallest total since February, the volume of business was the largest for a corresponding month in fifteen years, or since August of 1935.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)-- Plans for the sale to the public of all the 1,750,000 outstanding shares of common stock of the Pacific Power and Light Company were made public today.
In a transaction reported to involve approximately $8,000,000, the ownership of Frederick Loeser Co., Inc., Brooklyn department store, changed hands yesterday.

The League of New York Theatres, whose membership consists of producers and theatre operators, yesterday maintained it was indirectly involved in a dispute with the Theatrical Costume Workers Union (Local 124), a branch of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F.L.

Horses saddled by Rigan McKinney took all except $1,500 of the $11,225 gross in the Harbor Hill Steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday. Hot, owned and trained by McKinney, led all the way and won by a dozen lengths from Allier, trained by McKinney and owned by his mother, Mrs. Corliss Sullivan.

ALBANY, Aug. 31--The State's 125 city and county civil defense directors held their first meeting with Governor Dewey and Gen. Lucius D. Clay today. They came away with a grim picture of a farreaching job that must be done with limited resources--and done at once.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 31--A five-and-one-half-acre waterfront estate here, bequeathed in 1946 to Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, is proving an invaluable investment in off-duty relaxation and recreation for thousands of the hospital's nursing school graduates, student nurses and members of its clerical staff.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 31-- Farm women are just as much interested in their homes as city dwellers and want the same kind of automatic washers, driers, home freezers and other 1950 gadgets as their urban cousins have.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31--The grain markets here reversed their action of the previous day on the Board of Trade today, declining sharply in part on profit-taking and scattered liquidation.
DETROIT, Aug. 31--Mayor Albert E. Cobo today dismissed 2,000 city garbage and rubbish collectors who left their work to demonstrate for a pay rise.

There is a way for Americans to come through the present crisis in a sound condition without being victims either of inflation or unlimited Government controls, Louis W. Dawson, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, declared yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 31--Price's tended to improve in most sections of the stockmarkets here today. Gains, however, were neither so numerous or so large as yesterday.

Walter E. Heller Co., Chicago factoring and commercial financing business, has arranged with Metropolitan Life Insurance Company for loans totaling $14,380,000 to refund all outstanding longterm notes and debentures and to provide $2,000,000 of working funds.

ANYONE would have thought that Alice Norton was a very lucky girl. Didn't she have just about everything which is sup posed to make a girl happy? Alice was beautiful and clever. The Nortons were rich and their ancestral estate down in Devonshire was magnificently impressive. Alice had made her debut during the London season and had been presented at court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--A defense production bill, complete with "stand-by" authority for the President to invoke wage-pricerationing controls at his discretion, emerged from a Congressional conference committee tonight.

The stock market idled along yesterday in another inconclusive session. Price changes in the main were so small as to be meaningless and trading was the dullest in three months. The approach of a long week-end, the result of the Saturday closing and the Labor Day holiday or Monday, kept most active traders on the sidelines.

Prices of crude rubber futures continued to decline sharply on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, but the volume of trading was comparatively light. At the close bf trading quotations for No. 1. rubber smoked sheets were off 25 to 175 points, or to 1 cents a pound.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 31--The Nationalist Government strengthened its hold on South Africa with a clean sweep of seats for the Union Parliament in yesterday's elections in South-West Africa.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--President Truman declared at his news conference today that it was not his intention to scatter the Federal Government across the country as a precaution against a possible bomb attack.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)-- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill to put into operation the "performance budget" urged for the Government by the [Hoover] Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 31--September still was seven or eight hours in the distance this humid afternoon, but so far as the forty-one heavily padded and fully uniformed young men were concerned it was football time.

SANDY SADDLER is a raw-boned, skinny youngster who looks as though he would be blown over by the first real gust of wind. But he's a surprisingly sturdy specimen who may pack more dynamite in his fists than any featherweight champion who ever lived--which is covering a lot of territory.

Merger of the Brooklyn Trust Company into the Manufacturers Trust Company has been agreed upon by the managements of the two institutions, according to a joint announcement made yesterday by Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, and by George V. McLaughlin, president of the Brooklyn Trust Company.

Babies born prematurely, infants being placed for adoption, youngsters suffering from chronic ills and crippling conditions, are among the tens of thousands of additional children who will benefit from the new Social Security provisions that became law on Monday.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 31 --Mrs. J.B. Balding and Bobby Balding of The Creek Club and Frank Van Ness and Mrs. J.K. Berlage of Siwanoy were the winning combinations today as the two-day family competition jointly sponsored by the Metropolitan Golf Association and the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened at the Cherry Valley Club.

Two new films will arrive in town this morning. At the Roxy is "The Black Rose," Twentieth Century-Fox's version of the Thomas Costain story of adventure in the Chinese empire of Kubla Khan, filmed in Technicolor in North Africa and England, starring Tyrone Power, Orson Welles and Cecile Aubry. Henry Hathaway directed, Louis D. Lighton produced and Talbot Jennings wrote the screen play.

OTTAWA, Aug. 31 (AP)--All regular passenger and freight trains in Canada were reported back in operation by noon today. Industrial and business life quickened with the ending of a nine-day strike on railway and telegraph systems.

Col. Harold D. Corbusier, Medical Reserve, United States Army, retired, a veteran of the first World War and three previous campaigns and an orthopedic surgeon, died yesterday in Santa Fe, N.M., after a long illness. He was 77 years old and formerly resided and practiced in Plainfield, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--President Truman expressed the hope today that Communist China would not intrude in the United Nations effort to establish peace in Korea and asserted the Seventh Fleet would be withdrawn from Formosa when the Korean conflict was settled.

The Labor Day week-end trek from the metropolitan area will get under way late this afternoon by automobile, train, bus and airplane. The Automobile Club of New York estimated yesterday that 2,225,000 persons would leave the city tonight and tomorrow morning in 750,000 cars.

Albert Sokolski, a builder and real estate operator and broker, died on Wednesday in his home at 969 Park Avenue, after an illness of several months. He was 76 years old. His office was at 70 Pine Street.

MANILA, Aug. 31--President Elpidio Quirino has accepted the resignation of Ruperto Kangleon, Secretary of National Defense, in a dispute over the retention of the armed forces' top generals. Congressman Ramon Magsaysay, chairman of the House Committee on National Defense, was appointed as Secretary.

PARIS, Aug. 31--Discussion of the Schuman plan for the merger of the coal and steel production of Western Europe was resumed today by the delegates of France, Italy, Western Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, who hoped to agree this autumn on a treaty to submit to their governments and parliaments.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 31--Senator Robert A. Taft called tonight for taxation that would put the nation on a pay-as-you-go basis up to a total of $60,000,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--During the week ended Aug. 30, member bank reserve balances decreased $157,000,000, the Federal, Reserve Board reported today.
James H. Sheils, Commissioner of Investigation, attacked the latest rise in the price of milk yesterday as "outrageous" and "unconscionable."
DETROIT, Aug 31 (UP)--Mayor Orville Hubbard of suburban Dearborn announced today that he would go to jail as a debtor next week.
TOKYO, Aug. 21--Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters today, for the first time, publicly identified the commander in chief of the North Korean invasion army--a marshal of the "People's Republic" ...
