OTTAWA, Aug. 31--What has happened in Korea might happen again at any time in Germany, Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Minister of External Affairs, told the House of Commons today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--One of the most difficult books to borrow in the capital is a slim, paperbound volume known to its publishers, the Government Printing Office, as No. 92202.

DIANE ALLAN WED TO NAVY VETERAN The marriage of Miss Diane Y. Allan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Allan of 1100 Park Avenue, to A. Richard Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius J. Goodman of Troy, N.Y., took place last night in the grand ballroom of the Pierre. The Rev. Dr. Jacob K. Shankman performed the ceremony.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 31--Reports to the Hague from Jakarta today said that Indonesia would seek membership in the United Nations shortly because the government there believed a third party would bring the dispute between Indonesia and the Netherlands over Dutch New Guinea before the United Nations General Assembly, next month.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Aug. 31 (AP)--The University of North Carolina and North Carolina State College are not complying fully with the "sanity code" of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
With a forecast of 36,000 traffic accident fatalities throughout the country for this year, a new warning was issued on the increased dangers caused by drunken driving and speeding.

Prospects for holding a permanent international trade fair or exposition in this city, beginning in 1951, will be explored at a special meeting to be held today in the Governor Clinton Hotel under the auspices of the International Trade Section of the New York Board of Trade.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31-- Gary Cooper today signed with Twentieth Century-Fox to star in his first film for that studio, a comedy-drama entitled "The Flying Teakettle."

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 31 --Speaking as a big man, I always find it a source of wonder that small men so frequently have big personalities, Shakespeare, Mozart, Beethoven and Napoleon were all small men, yet they wrote their names on the map of the world.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 31--A special all-day session of the Cabinet attended by representatives of the Knesset (Parliament) and financial institutions discussed the state's economic problems today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 31-- Alexis Kyrou of Greece said today that the Soviet Union's charge of terrorism and mass executions in Greece were "fantastic and ridiculous,' and he strongly hinted that Moscow may have future aggression in mind as a motive for the new accusations.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31 --Plans have been completed by Miss Ann Cogswell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cogswell of Good Ground, Southampton, and 161 East Seventy-second Street, New York, for her marriage to Esmond King Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter T. Murphy of New York and East Hampton.
Business loans in the New York area continued to expand last week for the thirteenth consecutive rise, despite efforts of Government agencies to stem the advance.
Thirty-four American Jewish business and community leaders left last night from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, for Israel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--President Truman approved plans today to raise the volume of the American propaganda of truth, and the Senate heard a proposal that the Voice of America be amplified and "elevated to the voice of freedom."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31.-- The Federal Government today seized the freighter Mary Luckenbach as a result of her collision with the Navy hospital ship Benevolence last Friday in which atleast eighteen persons died, with five still missing.

Henry Winston, national organizational secretary of the Communist party, set a thirty-day deadline yesterday for the completion of the party's own registration of members, before the Wood bill becomes law.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--President Truman today suggested that the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L., stop making foreign policy by its refusal to unload Russian cargoes in New York.

The Chrysler Corporation, which last week took an extraordinary step in providing voluntarily a large wage increase for employes, made another unexpected move yesterday when its directors voted payment of a second dividend to stockholders during September.
As she heads back to college or returns to the office from her vacation, the average girl thinks of a fall hat to go with fall fashions as instinctively as she does of an Easter bonnet in the spring.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 31--John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner for Germany, and Lewis W. Douglas, Ambassador to Britain, arrived here together today for talks with President Truman and Secretary of State Dean Acheson on the defense of Western Europe against future aggression.

In a new salon at 8 West Fiftyseventh Street, the press viewed Andrew Geller's late fall and cruise shoe collection at a breakfast yesterday. Like the modern decor of the store, the shoe designs were up-to-the-minute in line and use of fabrics and trim.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--Senate tax leaders moved today to guarantee Congressional action next year on a retroactive excessprofits levy in an effort to head off Senate approval now of a plan they classed as unworkable and inequitable.

West 163d Street between Broadway and St. Nicholas Avenue seemed more like Podunk Corners yesterday than a city thoroughfare. Two hundred youngsters dressed in crinkly parti-colored crepe costumes danced the Virginia reel and did the grapevine twist, sang, and played country games.

The Linden-Roselle Sewerage Authority, N.J., sold yesterday $3,850,000 of bonds due from Dec. 15, 1953 to 1385, to Shields Co. and associates at a bid of 100 for interest of 2 per cent, 2 per cent and 2.10 per cent, an interest cost of 2.1094 per cent.

John Bromwich of Australia, Jaroslav Drobny, formerly of Czechoslovakia, and Miss Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., Wimbledon titleholder, were eliminated from the national tennis championships at Forest Hills yesterday.

PROTESTS concerning the recently announced waterfowl regulations were to be expected, for no agency could draft a set of restrictions which would meet the approval of all hunters. But the Connecticut wildfowlers who are complaining about the dates of the open season there' would seem to have an argument based on sound conservation.
Recordings of a song called "Old Man Atom," described in the trade as "a talking blues number," have been withdrawn from public distribution by R.C.A.-Victor and Columbia Records.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UP)-- An economy-minded Senate today upheld President Truman's veto of a bill that would have granted an "indirect bonus" ranging up to $250 a year for 100,000 postal workers who are World War II veterans.

DIST EL ASHRAFF, Egypt, Aug. 31--A Trans World Airlines Constellation crashed and burned in the desert sands on the western edge of the Nile Delta today. All fifty-five persons aboard perished. Twenty-three Americans and an Egyptian film star were among them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--Abraham George Silverman, a wartime $10,000-a-year civilian official of the Air Corps, blocked for a second time today efforts by the House Committee on Un-American Activities to trace an alleged channel of passage of military secrets to Russia through a spy ring operating here in 1942.
GASTONIA, N.C., Aug. 31 (AP)-- Representative A.L. Bulwinkle of North Carolina's Eleventh District died at his home here tonight. His age was 67.

A three-man advisory committee headed by Herbert W. Seward, Emeritus Professor of Marine Engineering at Yale University, has been established by the Federal Maritime Board to review Government subsidy grants in the construction of six ocean liners.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--The House of Representatives, by a vote of 215 to 115, today cited Joseph P. Kamp, executive vice chairman of the Constitutional Educational League for contempt of Congress.

A two-day-old strike affecting 30,000 General Electric Company employes spread to seven plants yesterday amid indications that an additional 10,000 workers in two more plants might join the walkout Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31--A revolt is brewing among railway labor chieftains against some Democratic leaders in Congress.

Several eastbound Pennsylvania Railroad trains, carrying several thousand passengers to the Pennsylvania station here, were delayed from forty minutes to two and one half hours yesterday afternoon when an eighty-foot-long overhead cable supporting electric power lines snapped at Highland Park, N.J.

To help make this city the nation's television capital, the State Mediation Board is considering the establishment of a special division that would concern itself with heading off strikes or jurisdictional disputes in the video field.

PUSAN, Korea, Aug, 31--Fleeing the advancing North Korean Communist Army, almost 2,000,000 South Koreans, in some cases constituting whole villages, have moved in the past month into the United Nations defense area in what was described here as the "most orderly refugee movement in recent history."
Beginning today the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will help "spread the gospel of great music" by opening a two-week engagement at the Roxy Theatre.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 1--The North Korean invaders launched a general assault today on a fiftymile front against positions held by the United States Second and Twenty-fifth Infantry Divisions along the Naktong River line and the South coast approaches to the vital landing port of Pusan.
EASTON, Pa., Aug. 31--Dr John Edgar Fretz, physician here for fifty-three years, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

DETROIT, Aug. 31--The Hudson Motor Car Company today granted voluntary wage increases of 7 cents an hour to 20,000 production workers. Two smaller concerns granted 10-cent-an-hour rises to a total of 4,400 workers. Hudson was the fourth auto maker to grant pay increases. The others were Chrysler, General Motors and Packard.

Governor Dewey and Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley staged a joint public appearance yesterday in Albany for the apparent purpose of demonstrating that relations between them are cordial despite efforts of some Republicans to persuade Mr. Hanley to withdraw as a candidate for Governor and to induce Mr. Dewey to run again.

Big users of imported nickel scrap here have started asking New York Senators and Representatives in Congress to enact new legislation immediately to remove the 25 per cent duty which has reduced imports drastically the past two months.

After a month of gross misconduct in office and deliberate sabotage of the United Nations effort to stop Communist aggression in Korea, Jacob A. Malik, the Soviet delegate, yesterday stepped down as President of the Security Council with one last propaganda blast which merely added, another lie to the many he has launched.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Aug. 31--An account of the discovery of two new elementary particles in cosmic rays was given at the British Association for the Advancement of Science today by Nobel Prize winner Prof. P.M.S. Blackett of Manchester University.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 31-- Warren R. Austin, the United States representative, told the United Nations Security Council tonight that there was "a possibility" that a United States F-51 fighter might have mistakenly violated the territory of Communist China on Aug. 27 by strafing an airstrip at Antung in Manchuria, five miles from the North Korean frontier.
LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 31--Following is the unofficial verbatim record of today's meeting of the United Nations Security Council:

The enemy launched a general attack estimated at three divisions, with two in reserve, against the United States Second and Twenty-fifth Divisions last night at 2400 hours (midnight) on the Naktong River front from Tukson (twelve miles southwest of Taegu) south to the coast. Heaviest pressure was felt at the Naktong-Nam Rivers junction.
WASHINGTON, Aug.31--Rates on air parcel post, affecting primarily shipments of more than one pound, will be raised Nov. 1, Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson announced today.
Commissioner William P. O'Brien advanced 107 members of the Police Department yesterday at ceremonies in the presence of 300 members and their families at Police Headquarters.

Mayor O'Dwyer, accompanied by Mrs. O'Dwyer, left the city at 6 P.M. yesterday aboard the Twentieth Century Limited bound for El Centro, Calif., where he will be the guest of his brother Frank until he assumes the office of Ambassador to Mexico on Oct. 20.

DETROIT, Aug. 31--Five United States speedboats of the "unlimited" class are in readiness here tonight to run as defenders tomorrow and Saturday in the Harmsworth Trophy race against the challenge of Harold A. Wilson's Miss Canada IV of Ingersoll, Ont.

Today is Christmas day. Dr. William Whitney Christmas will pass his eighty-fifth birthday as usual--in conference with Government representatives, telling some of his innumerable flavorsome anecdotes about Washington notables and probably inventing something.
Volunteer inactive Marine Reservists from private to sergeant will begin to report for duty at the date of about 200 a day beginning Tuesday, the Third Marine Reserve District said yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31--This was Big Jim Hearns day and the big fellow from Georgia rose to the occasion in the grand manner.

Having taken the better part of twelve weeks to reclaim first place, which had slipped out of their grasp on June 9, Casey Stengel's Bombers served notice on all and sundry at the Stadium yesterday that they are not of a mind to let it get away a second time.
Court action to bar an election for Mayor this fall if Mayor O'Dwyer's resignation is filed tomorrow, as scheduled, is being contemplated by the City Fusion party, it was disclosed last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, Aug. 31--A packed house turned out today for the swan-song performance of Jacob A. Malik, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, as President of the United Nations Security Council, and the feeling of the last-day audience as it filed out of the exits was one of profound relief over a well-earned rest for all concerned.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 1--Senator Robert A. Taft accused his opposition today of resorting to Communist tactics in carrying out "the most complete campaign of falsification ever undertaken in the United States."
Acting Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri took over yesterday the reins of city government that had been relinquished by Mayor O'Dwyer on Thursday.

UNIVERSITY, Va., Sept. 1-- Dr. Dudley Crofford Smith, founder and head of the Department of Dermatology and Syphilology in the University of Virginia Medical School and chairman of the section on dermatology and syphilology of the American Medical Association, died of a heart attack Wednesday night at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington. His age was 57.

OTTAWA, Sept. 1--No enabling legislation will be sought during the present special session of Parliament to restore wage and price control system, Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent told the House of Commons this afternoon, but he added that the question of how to deal with rising living costs was under constant consideration.

There is much to be said for "the old school tie," at least in diplomacy. It would have been hard to find a sharper human contrast than that presented by Jacob Malik and Sir Gladwyn Jebb, who began his month as President of the Security Council yesterday.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Murphy of Sneden's Landing, Palisades, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Honoria Murphy, to Capt. William M. Donnelly Jr., U.S.A., retired, of Carmel, Calif., son of the late Mr, and Mrs. William M. Donnelly of Detroit.

A modish winter coat this season does not have to be of wool or fur. It may be of a new nylon cloth resembling a never-seen-before fur. Or again, it may be of a featherweight, springlike cloth, yet be as warm as the heaviest winter coat.

DETROIT, Sept. 1--Speed boating's most famous trophy, known officially as the British International but popularly as the Harmsworth, seemed beyond much doubt tonight to be destined for another and perhaps long stay in the United States.
The wall paper industry in the nation was at a virtual standstill yesterday as union employes in forty out of forty-three manufacturing plants in the East and Midwest walked out.

Despite President Truman's rebuke of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L. for attempting to make foreign policy by refusing to handle Russian cargoes, longshoremen continued yesterday their boycott of all Iron Curtain goods.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 1--Dr. Donald F. Gibson, the Danbury surgeon who had been named the sole beneficiary in the will of an elderly local spinster whose death on July 26 is under investigation, was dismissed today as the conservator of the estate of his aunt, Miss Eleanor K. Peterson.

DETROIT, Sept. 1--Pressure strikes by the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., for cost-of-living wage increase spread to the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation today where 9,000 were made idle and assembly operations shut down.
Spot and futures prices of lead and copper rose yesterday along with advances in rubber and most other commodity futures.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 1--Returning today from a three-week trip to Norway, Secretary General Trygve Lie said that he would see what might be done to revise the rules of procedure of the United Nations Security Council, which was kept in a state of parliamentary paralysis all last month by its President, Jacob A. Malik of the Soviet Union.

The marriage of Miss Selwa Carmen Showker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saleem Showker of Kingsport, Tenn., to Archibald Bulloch Roosevelt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roosevelt of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., took place here yesterday afternoon in the home of the bridegroom's aunt, Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt, at 9 Sutton Place.

Plans of the State Department of Social Welfare to provide food, shelter, clothing, child care and other necessities for hundreds of thousands of evacuees in case of an enemy attack on New York have been received by, the State Civil Defense Commission.

Twenty-four hours after they had amassed nineteen runs against the Braves, the Dodgers, performing as if they had aged a year for each hour, dropped a 4-1 decision to Leo Durocher's spirited Giants last night at Ebbets Field.

C.V. Whitney's 4-year-old filly Nasophar kicked up quite a fish when she was led into the gate for yesterday's main event at Aqueduct. For a few seconds Bobby Permane wondered whether he was going to stay right side up. Then Nasophar settled down, the flaps popped open and the filly proceeded to give Permane as pleasant a ride as he's had all season.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 15 per cent in August compared with the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

VIENNA, Aug. 30--The integration of the power resources of Austria, Germany, Italy, Switzerland and France, with assistance from the Economic Cooperation Administration, is being seriously considered in Washington and the capitals of Western Europe as an indirect result of the Korean war.

An election in the remote and sparsely populated territory of SouthWest Africa might seem of small moment to Americans these days. This world of ours happens to be interlinked and sensitive, and these elections meant a great deal to the Union of South Africa, to Africa as a whole and to the United Nations, and therefore to all of us.

CENTERBROOK, Conn., Sept. 1 --Mr. and Mrs. Martin W. Wright have announced the engagement of their daughter, Priscilla Redfield, to Charles Norris Pratt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Pratt of Essex.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 1 (AP)--The Cleveland Browns tonight beat the Chicago Bears, 27 to 23, before 51,075 fans. This exhibition football contest marked the first time the teams had met.

The Greyhound Building Corporation, a subsidiary of Greyhound bus lines, has purchased the property on West Fiftieth Street through to Fifty-first Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, which the buyer has operated as a bus terminal for twenty years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--Following is a digest of the major provisions of the Defense Production Bill passed by the House and Senate today:

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 2--The North Koreans resumed early to day their all-out drive against the United States lines, which had been pushed back but still held firm to the east of the broken Naktong River bastion and in the area to the south of the Nam River, thirty miles at the closest point to the vital United Nations bases and landing port of Pusan.

The Jaeger Machine Company, manufacturer of cement-mixing and road-building equipment, reported yesterday that net income for the year ended on June 30 amounted to $1,068,651, an increase of 47 per cent over the $724,417 reported for the previous fiscal year.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 1-- Thirty-four cruising yachts, among them John Nicholas Brown's yawl Bolero, De Coursey Fales' schooner Nina, A. Howard Fuller's sloop Gesture and John Timken's yawl Kitty Hawk, set out from the Cows tonight, on the Stamford Yacht Club's annual Vineyard Race.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 1 (UP)-- Trans World Airlines officials said today they believed some "mechanical defect" caused the Constellation Star of Maryland to crash in flames on the desert early yesterday, killing fiftyfive persons, twenty-three of them Americans.

HONG KONG, Sept. 1--Two American commercial pilots and three members of their crew have been released by the Communists in Southwest China after having been marooned in Kunming for eight months, eleven weeks of which were spent in full confinement.

Creation of a corporation to sponsor an international trade fair in this city next year was author ized yesterday at a special meeting under the auspices of the international trade section of the New York Board of Trade at the Governor Clinton Hotel.

Top leaders of the American Labor Party went into conference last night with Representative Vito Marcantonio, their state chairman, to pick candidates for presentation to their state convention next Wednesday evening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--The Federal Communications Commission declined today to adopt final standards for color television. It released, however, a report strongly favoring the Columbia Broadcasting Company's color television method.

Mass picketing of Madison Square Garden next week was threatened yesterday by W.A. Hunton, secretary of the Council on African Affairs, because the Garden refused to rent the premises for a council meeting on Sept. 14.

THE hunter who has tried everything else and still wants to kill a wild boar will have an opportunity to pick up one of these trophies by participating in one of the hunts to be held in the Santeelah Forest of North Carolina.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1-- The Luckenbach Steamship Company today asked the Federal Circuit Court to dismiss a $14,000,000 damage suit filed against it by the Federal Government and, in turn, filed a cross-libel action against the Government, asking tentatively for $193,653.

LONDON, Sept. 1--Britain made a notable advance in the international financial field tonight with the lifting of virtually all restrictions on the transfer within the sterling area of sterling securities and blocked sterling owned by nonresidents.

Frank Sedgman, champion of Australia, passed from the national amateur tennis tournament at Forest Hills yesterday, leaving American players in possession of the field. With him also was eliminated Tom Brown of San Francisco, winner of the only match salvaged by the United States in the Davis Cup challenge round with Australia.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1(AP)-- The United Sates Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that picketing a construction job against a non-union subcontractor is legal under the Taft-Hartley Act.
There are times on warm and humid evenings in the summer (and this could happen in other seasons too)

Television coverage of baseball's 1950 World Series early in October will be presented simultaneously by three networks--the American Broadcasting Company, the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)-- The United States Court of Appeals today issued a temporary injunction restraining Housing Expediter Tighe Woods from lifting rent controls in Los Angeles. The court said it would hear an appeal in the case on its merits.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--The Senate tonight passed the $4,508,000,000 emergency tax increase bill to help pay for the Korean war and the country's rearmament program.

Potatoes are selling at shipping points at the lowest prices since before World War II, the New York office of the Department of Agriculture said yesterday. At retail potatoes average less than 4 cents a pound--that is, 19 cents for five pounds.

Loss of revenue and passengers on the Lake Mahopac branch of the Harlem division of the New York Central Railroad was cited by road officials yesterday as the basis for their petition for permanent curtailment of service between Lake Mahopac and Golden's Bridge, N.Y.

A study designed to banish the bogey of high blood pressure has been published in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association. It calls for a redefinition of the word "normal" to conform more closely to the observed facts.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Sept. 1--After three hours of acrimonious debate on new evidence in support of the Wegener theory that continents had broken off from a solid mass and drifted apart, the issue was put to the vote of a crowded British Association meeting here today. The result was a dead heat for and against.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--Three men formerly in key government posts, identified Monday by Lee Pressman as having been fellowmembers with him of a Communist group in the early years of the New Deal, defied the House Committee on Un-American Activities today as it sought to confirm the Pressman testimony. The committee, it was indicated, might cite the three for contempt.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--Average primary market price advance was 0.7 per cent in the week ended Aug. 29, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 1--The Central Presbyterian Church was the setting here tonight for the marriage of Miss Helen Elizabeth Rowe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Alton Rowe, to Wellden Pyle Jr., son of Mrs. John Harold Jackson of South Orange, and the late Dr. Pyle.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)-- The Treasury announced today that it would open its books next Tuesday for subscriptions, by holders of maturing securities, to an issue of thirteen-month, 1 per cent Treasury notes.

The long Labor Day week-end began yesterday with the exodus of hundreds of thousands of persons from New York by automobile, bus, train and plane to enjoy the last summer holiday at beach and mountain resorts.
The butcher, the baker and the candlestick maker will come under the protection of the Federal oldage insurance system on New Year's Day, along with most other persons who own their own businesses.

Pleasures of the night life of the ancient Corinthians in the time of Alexander the Great have been disclosed by the excavation of a colonnade with thirty-three taverns outside modern Corinth, Oscar Broneer, Professor of Archaeology, said yesterday aboard the American Export liner La Guardia when the docked here.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 1--It cost the Federal Government $78,000 last year to apprehend and return Mexican nationals who had "skipped" on their contracts to work in the cotton fields of the mid-South, the President's Migratory Labor Commission was told today.

Gladiolus, asters and dahlias in flower shops all over town give city people an inkling of just how good a growing year it has been for these flowers. In spite of the abundance of summer flowers, pompon chrysanthemums, associated with fall, are starting to arrive in small quantities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)-- World output of cotton in the 195051 season may be considerably below that of last season and below the 1949-50 world consumption, the International Cotton Advisory Committee said today.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1--In his annual report to the nation, President Miguel Alem n requested his admirers today to drop their unauthorized campaign for his reelection in 1952.

Americans have an obligation to set an example of leadership before the world by coordinating economic self-government and political government on a democratic basis at home, says the 1950 Labor Day statement of the Social Action Department of the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

He said he had so advised ...

Ezzard Charles was a confident one as he talked yesterday of his chances in his clash with Joe Louis at the Yankee Stadium on Sept. 27, Charles, recognized by the National Boxing Association as the heavyweight champion of the world, visited the offices of the International Boxing Club after a train trip from Cincinnati.

The Information Office of the Republic of Indonesia here released yesterday a statement by the Indonesian Foreign Ministry assailing as unwarranted the intervention of Australia in the dispute between Indonesia and the Netherlands over the status of West New Guinea.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 1-- A squad of fifty-five today answered the first call for football practice at the United States Military Academy as Coach Earl H. (Red) Blaik began preparations for one of the toughest schedules in the sixty-one-year history of the game here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--The Census Bureau reported today that employment rose 1,153,000 in August to 62,367,000, highest in American history.
Twenty-six hundred New Jersey, commuters got a last-second reprieve yesterday when the Interstate Commerce Commission ordered a seven-month postponement of rate rises as they were going into effect.

Jean Muir, who last Monday was dropped from the cast of the television version of "The Aldrich Family," said yesterday she was prepared to appear before any governmental body, such as the House Committee on Un-American Activities, to clear herself of pro-Communist charges.

In fully granting the State Department's $49,000,000 request for additional radio activities of the Voice of America, the House this week reflected an increasing realization that we must win the war of ideas which the Communists have forced upon us.

TOKYO, Sept. 1 (AP)--General Douglas MacArthur today condemned imperialistic militarism under "unified direction" but said that the United Nations was "morally and physically able" to secure world peace.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 1-- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley, Metropolitan and New York State champion, playing alternate shots with her mother, Mrs. Frank Adel of Oakland, won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's mother and daughter championship over the Cherry Valley course today, with a 42, 40--82.
BERLIN, Sept. 1(AP)--East German Communists are building up a shipping center on the Baltic coast to compete with the bustling Western port of Hamburg.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 1--With Jacob A.Malik of the Soviet Union no longer in the chair, the United Nations Security Council today restored Dr. John M. Chang, representative of the Republic of Korea, to his seat at the Council table.
The nation's two largest electrical production companies faced crippling strikes yesterday that may drastically disrupt production of vitally needed war materials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today that no proposed revision of international machinery for collective security would serve to lessen the East-West tension which is threatening the world's peace.

Sound policies of inventory accumulation will pay off for rayon goods converters in the next few weeks, according to Abraham J. Cohen, vice president of Atlantic Piece Dye Works. The waiting period for apparel manufacturers and retailers is coming to an end and they must come into the fabric market for both fall reorders and spring goods, he said.

BERLIN, Sept. 1--Six of the most prominent members were expelled from the Socialist Unity (Communist) party today and four others were dismissed from their jobs in a Moscow-type of purge. Four of the major victims have been placed under house arrest, one was said to have fled and the other to have disappeared.

IN SOUTH KOREA, Sept. 1-- With a United Nations offensive against the North Korean Communist forces in prospect, the subject most discussed here in South Korean political Government circles is what will be done about the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--A commitment of $150,000,000 in funds to establish further credits to the Republic of Mexico was announced today by Herbert E. Gaston, chairman of the board of directors of the Export-Import Bank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today the beginning of a fifteen-month program of special studies of retail prices. The bureau said this was a necessary phase in the revision of the consumers' price index, authorized by Congress last year.

ATHENS, Sept. 1--The Greek General Staff said tonight that a band of Greek Communist guerrillas, following a party plan backed by the Cominform, had struck across the border from Albania on Wednesday and had been routed by Regular Army troops.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 1 (UP)--A powerful storm with winds of more than 140 miles an hour struck islands in the Caribbean today. The weather bureau here said the disturbance is only 200 miles southsouthwest of Havana.

From old friends and neighbors to the "cop on the beat," New Yorkers called up Mrs. Vincent R. Impellitteri yesterday at 200 West Sixteenth Street to congratulate her on becoming the city's new First Lady.

Efforts of big primary copper producers to "hold the line" on copper prices at 22 cents a pound broke up yesterday when Anaconda Sales Company officials announced their decision to sell copper at the 24 -cent price levels previously set by big custom smelters here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--An emergency appropriation of $6,000,000 for the Federal Bureau of Investigation because of "the changed international situation" was requested of Congress today by President Truman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--Confirmation of the Presidential appointment of Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York as Ambassador to Mexico seemed headed for at least a slight delay today as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee indicated it would hold public hearings because of a number of protests it had received.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 29 --Of all the countries along the Western frontier, Sweden has been able to handle her post-war refugee problem with the least difficulty, indeed, with positive benefit to her economy.

HONG KONG, Aug. 30--Landlords in the six provinces of the Central-South China military area have been forced to disgorge more than 500,000 tons of rice to hardpressed tenant peasants under the "land rent reduction and rent refund" campaign being waged in this restive zone by Chinese Communists.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--The Switchmen's Union of North America, A.F.L., and ten Western and Midwestern railroads settled their year-old dispute at the White House today.

The American Furniture Company, Martinsville, Va., will again accept dealer orders beginning on Tuesday, Thomas Barbour, vice president and general sales manager, revealed yesterday. Orders to be taken are for November delivery only, he emphasized.
FREEMAN, S.D., Sept. 1 (AP)-- A 425-year-old peace stand has been reaffirmed by the General Conference of the Mennonite Church. But the church plans to move into Korea with relief services.

Louis Goldring, a partner of the law firm of Sherman Goldring, 51 Madison Avenue, died in Mount Sinai Hospital on Thursday night after having suffered a coronary thrombosis earlier in the day. Mr. Goldring, who was 65 years old, lived at 40 West Sixty-seventh Street.

New efforts to resolve Republican confusion over a state ticket for the fall election got under way last night after Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley designated Representative Dean P. Taylor of Rensselaer as floor manager of his campaign for the nomination for Governor.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP)--Andy Seminick banged a two-run, inside the park homer as the Phillies trounced the Braves, 7--3, tonight for the league leaders' ninth victory in their last eleven road starts. Rooke right-hander Bubba Church scattered eight Boston hits, including Roy Hartsfield's sixth homer of the season.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS W.Va., Sept. 1--Ernest T. Weir chairman of the National Steel Corporation, recommended here tonight that the over-all administration of both military and civilian controls be placed under "a civilian board composed of citizens of such stature that they would be beyond the reach of partisan politics."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UP)-- The Air Force confirmed today that a United States F-51 fighter plane may have strayed across the Chinese Communist border and strafed a Manchurian air base on Aug. 27.

The patient detective work of an off-duty young patrolman yesterday resulted in the arrest of four men on the lower East Side fifteen minutes before a $16,000 payroll was to be delivered at the Benson Hedges factory at 585 Water Street.
A total of 1,333 youths, the largest number for any one day since the start of the current draft, was called up yesterday for pre-induction physical and mental examinations.

The Playwrights Company, it develops, may be the firm to present this season Raymond Massey's drama version of "Hanging Judge," a murder-will-out novel by Bruce Hamilton. The script will be submitted to the company after Labor Day. If it is found to be satisfactory, there will be a midseason production.

The surprise announcement by Chrysler that it would pay a second dividend in September supplied the stock market yesterday with a basic reason to reverse its trend and advance. While the upturn was selective, gains were of major proportions in the favored issues, with Chrysler up more than 4 points.

ALBANY, Sept. 1--In an abrupt about-face that might have startled Sigmund Freud, the State Department of Mental Hygiene has temporarily deserted the bleak case histories of psychiatrists' reports for the more colorful pages of comic books.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., Sept. 1 --South Amboy, like many another small city, seemed to be sleeping through the hot days of the late summer today.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 1 (AP) --The Rev. John J. Cavanaugh, president of the University of Notre Dame, said today the "man in the street" in France believes "Stalin could take Paris by telephone."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--President Truman warned the leaders of international communism tonight that the United States would employ its great power without limit to uphold the rule of law in the world.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1--The Veterans of Foreign War demanded today that all Government officials, high or low, responsible for the United States being "sold out at Yalta" be "driven from office and punished to the full extent of the law."

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Sept. 1 --The struggle for the state title continued to be close as games in the seventh round of the tournament were contested today at the meeting of the New York State Chess Association.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 1-- Headquarters of the United Nations Palestine Refugee Organization here is investigating reports that the flour supply, the principal food staple of the Palestine refugees, is being sabotaged.

Columbia's sixty-second football campaign was launched with an innovation yesterday, when the candidates who reported to Coach Lou Little at Morningside Heights were whisked off by bus to Camp Columbia at Lakeside, Conn., for three weeks of preliminary training.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 1-- China's Kuomintang, or National People's party, today issued the platform upon which it will strive to regain control of the mainland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP)-- Loans were made to 4,000 farmers during the first year's operation of the farm housing program for construction or repair of houses and other farm buildings, the Agriculture Department reported today.
Labor sermons and special religious programs will have prominence today, tomorrow and on Labor Day for Jewish, Protestant and Roman Catholic congregations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1--The Defense Production Bill of 1950 emerged in finished form from Congress this afternoon and was sent immediately to the White House. Word there tonight was that the President probably would sign the measure over the weekend since he plans a special radio address to the nation on the measure next week.

Net income of the American Gas and Electric Company for the twelve months to July 31 amounted to $22,357,438, or $4.49 a share, compared with $20,972,695, or $4.21 a share, in the preceding twelve months, it was announced yesterday.

With retail business returned to a more normal pattern, purchasing in the wholesale markets has become more normal, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4-- Volunteers for police, and fire reserve forces have begun signing up here as Mayor Elmer E. Robinson reported on the city's atomic defense situation and asked for 800 men to offer themselves for the auxiliary forces.

"Pots and Pans For Your Kitchen," a new 30-page booklet by the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics of the Department of Agriculture, helpfully treats a homely theme. THERE was an item in the papers not very long ago that Walter Hagen had been forbidden by his doctors to play any more golf. It didn't rate big headlines because it has been ages since the Haig did any serious divot digging. Yet the mere fact that the links have been barred to the most colorful figure who ever swaggered across them is of itself newsworthy.

Mooney of Centre Island.

Important fashion news in the recent Paris collections was the seven-eighths length coat. Designers in this country like it, too. It is, however, only one of numerous attractive fall styles awaiting those who do not want a full length coat.

Thirteen youths armed with baseball bats, bricks and large pocket knives were seized by the police in Brooklyn before dawn yesterday. The arrests were believed to have forestalled a gang fight in the Bay Ridge district.

Postponement of the international tariff negotiations at Torquay, England, schedule to begin on Sept. 28, is urged by H. Wickliffe Rose, president of the American Tariff League, in a letter to President Truman released yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 12--The kingdom of Jordan has officially accused Israel of occupying Jordanian territory and forging a map to justify her act.

SYOSSET, L.I., Sept. 10--Mrs. Joseph L. Merrill's gray mare Buttermilk from Locust Valley won the working hunter championship at the annual Helping Hand horse show on the estate of Mrs. M.B. Hewlett today. Reserve was Mrs. James C. McGusty's chestnut gelding Darby Davis.

Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the United Nations division of trusteeship, asserted yesterday that thousands of Negro soldiers were "fighting valiantly" in Korea in order that Koreans might enjoy "that freedom and equality which these same Negro GI's have never experienced in full at home."

ATHENS, Sept. 11--Sophocles Venizelos, Liberal party leader, is again Premier of Greece. Tonight he was seeking the cooperation of political foes of a day or so ago to form a broad coalition in conformity with a request by King Paul that the Government proceed with the present Parliaments and avoid new general elections.

DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia, Sept. 11 (AP)--Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, captain of the American chess team, blamed "a silly squabble" for the United States' poor showing in the first postwar chess Olympics.
The cotton futures market closed 6 to 16 points net lower yesterday with activity on the New York Cotton Exchange tapering off somewhat from the active pace of last week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)-- The nation's crops overcame effects of some unfavorable weather during August to maintain production prospects well in line with the average of World War II.

A 52-year-old unemployed mechanic, accused in the Brooklyn gambling investigation of having handled police "protection" money, insisted in Kings County Court yesterday that he did not know James Cassese, key figure in the inquiry.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11--Meat packers and agricultural specialists joined here today in predicting lower pork and beef prices for the last quarter of the year.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Sept. 11-- An ace on the fly was produced by Sleepy Hollow Country Club pro Al Collins, 54-year-old links veteran, to highlight the opening of the seventeenth annual New York World-Telegram and Sun hole-in-one contest in today's murk and rain at the Leewood Golf Club.

Philip Watson, Harlem lawyer and a Republican candidate for one of two vacancies on the Municipal Court bench in the Tenth District, accepted yesterday the nomination of the American Labor party. His name was substituted with the Board of Elections for the

Occupation authorities hope Japan will have her foreign trade on a balanced basis within two years, Carl H. Boehringer, economic counselor in the Office of the United States Political Adviser for Japan, reported yesterday.

The General Foods Corporation, which two weeks ago dismissed Jean Muir from the cast of "The Aldrich Family" after receiving anti-Communist protests against her television appearance, urged yesterday the formation of an industry committee to recommend a solution in handling such cases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--The two Congressional groups in charge of foreign matters pledged today to Secretary of State Dean Acheson their full support for "the general line" he will take in the Western Big Three foreign ministers conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11-- Winding up their affairs in the Capital with a grand flourish, the Yankees today flattened Bucky Harris' Senators in both ends of the afternoon doubleheader, bounded into first place and then went storming into the West.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)-- Henry W. Grunewald, "mystery" man in two Federal inquiries into wiretapping in the national capital, today drew a threat of a contempt-of-Congress citation for refusing to answer questions.

Homemakers who are shopping for new floor coverings this fall and have shuddered at the rising prices of wool rugs may take consolation in the newest development to hit the floor coverings industry --carpetings made wholly or partly from man-made fibers.

LONDON, Sept. 11--George Bernard Shaw underwent an operation tonight, after having fractured his thigh in a fall yesterday while walking in his garden. The hospital reported after the operation that the condition of the 94year-old playwright was "as satisfactory as could be expected."

CHICAGO, Sept. 11--The national graphic arts exposition, largest printing show ever held, was opened today in the international amphitheatre with a roar of presses and a clatter of typesetting machines. After a formal opening by John J. Deviny of Washington, public printer of the United States, the big display was thrown open to the first of the thousands expected to attend.
Tatiana du Plessix knows how to give a small hat lots of verve. She demonstrated this in her showing of fall and winter hats, designed for Saks Fifth Avenue and presented yesterday noon.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--Army medical officials reduced by more than half today the quotas of doctors and dentists to be called soon into active duty from the Organized Reserve Corps.
OFF-SHORE anglers are rather concerned as to what the big wind will do to their fishing, but the surf casters are looking forward to improved conditions immediately following the disturbance.

In a spirit of mutual admiration, the City of New York yesterday honored the motion-picture industry--and Universal-International Pictures in particular--and the film company literally paid a goldplated tribute to the Police Department.

Justice Ferdinand Pecora, original choice of the Liberal party for Mayor, received its formal nomination at an enthusiastic meeting of its state executive committee at the Statler Hotel yesterday afternoon.

It is unfortunate that the question of racial designation of blood donors was ever raised in connection with the establishment of the United Nations blood bank. The opportunities for misunderstanding were great and the misunderstanding took place.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--When the President ordered "substantial increases" in our armed forces stationed in Western Europe he had in mind another factor than the military.

HO-HO-KUS, N.J., Sept. 11--A 17-month-old dog beat a good field of specials and a recent importation of quality to win best of breed in the golden anniversary specialty show of the Scottish Terrier Club of America in the rain today at the Chestnut Ridge Stables grounds.

One hundred rooms of the Waldorf-Astoria, including the turquoise blue suite usually reserved for visiting monarchs and state dignitaries, have been taken over for the meetings of the foreign ministers of Britain, France and the United States, that begin this

CHICAGO, Sept. 11--Congress must approve a master blueprint for "atom--proofing" America against attack, Dr. Eugene Rabinowitch, research professor of biochemistry at the University of Illinois, asserted today.
BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP)--Harvey D. Gibson, internationally known banker, died today of a heart ailment in the New England Baptist Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 68.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 11-- The Genetics Society of America today began a four-day "Golden Jubilee" program to commemorate fifty years of scientific study since the principles of Mendelism first were widely accepted. The sessions are at the Ohio State University here.

Steel production by the nation's mills set a record high in the first eight months of this year, aggregating more than 63,000,000 tons.

Because the city has had 589 cases of food poisoning in the first seven months of this year the Health Department has arranged to instruct restaurant workers and other food handlers in the sanitary preparation of food.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--Bitterness mounted as the Senate pressed tonight efforts to complete general debate on rival bills to control communism and subversion. The showdown voting is scheduled to start tomorrow.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 11--Since the Korean invasion began, as much as $300,000,000 to $400,000,000 in "refugee capital" has flowed here from Europe. This has emphasized the growing role of this little democracy as the "Switzerland of the Western World."

With a congratulatory message from President Truman and addresses by Acting Mayor Impellitteri, Secretary of Labor Maurice J. Tobin, and A. Philip Randolph, its leader, the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, A.F.L., opened its seventh biennial convention yesterday. Nearly 400 delegates are attending the sessions at the Theresa Hotel.
Camp is over now, and school is beginning, and no doubt it was due to dismal recollections of last term's paucity of theme material that a few suggestions were set down in advance of the first class.

Mrs. Mary Agnes Sullivan, former director of the Bureau of Policewomen and a policewoman here for thirty-five years, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital, after a brief illness, at the age of 71. She resided at 225 West Twelfth Street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--Signs of progress towards ending the two-month strike of soda ash workers were noted here by Federal conciliators.

Edward J. Barber is not prone to excitement. Nearly half a century in the shipping industry, noted for its vacillating economy, has taught him the value of remaining on an even keel at all times. He also is endowed with a temperament that hag gained for him the respect and admiration of the industry.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 11 (AP) --Palatine Stable's Chickle II, a topnotch grass performer, found the main course to his liking today when he splashed to victory in the Harry Hackney Memorial purse at the Atlantic City track.

Twenty-seven trainloads of homebound commuters were stalled on the Long Island Railroad from nine to forty-nine minutes in last night's rush hour after the first train of the procession had been halted by a short-circuit at Valley Stream.

It is given to few men at any time to play a dominant role in their era. Jan Christiaan Smuts, "the Old thief," was such a man. There are not many grown-ups alive today who can remember a world in which he did not play a great part.

Meeting under the shadow of the Korean war, which has disclosed the inadequacy of Western defenses against even a minor foe, the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France begin work today in New York on a program of intensified rearmament of the Atlantic community.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--Sam Rayburn, Speaker of the House of Representatives, asserted today that he would rule out of order any attempt to force inclusion of an excess profits levy in the interim tax bill that would raise $4,508,000,000 for immediate mobilization needs.
SARANAC INN, N.Y ., Sept. 11 (AP)--New York's Superintendent of Banks said today that savings institutions "can help check inflation by redoubling their efforts to attract the savings of the public."

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept, 11-- The school bell rang here tonight for Republican party workers in half a dozen Fairfield County, communities where it is hoped that a new political approach will yield votes next November.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 11-- Farmers and their cooperatives used credit totaling $1,700,000,000 in the year ended June 30, I.W. Duggan, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, reported today. This was $50,000,000 more than the 1948-49 period.
From the battle areas of Korea to the synagogues of New York, Jews the world over prayerfully hailed last night the advent of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year of 5711.
Carstairs Distillers, division of the Calvert Distillers Corporation, will use a "leading brand" theme for a strong fall campaign on Carstairs Whisky.
Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company will increase its prices by the end of the month, at the latest, for the sixth time since last November, dealers declared yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11-- Claudette Colbert and Ann Blyth will co-star in "Bonaventure" for Universal-International, it was announced by that studio today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 11--A Department of Agriculture estimate on the 1950 grain harvest was close to trade expectations today and was not expected to have much influence on prices.

SCARSDALF, N.Y., Sept. 11-- Five of the sixty-nine pro-amateur teams in today's one-day tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association tied for best-ball honors with three-under-par scores of 67 at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club, and a match of cards determined the final placing.

SAGINAW, Mich., Sept. 11-- The President's Commission on Migratory Labor was told today that any attempt by the Federal Government to enforce regulations on the use of such labor could have a "ruinous" effect upon the beet sugar industry in this state.

For a few minutes yesterday at the commencement of a special assembly at Public School 122 at First Avenue and Ninth Street 12year-old Tzuporia Shoenblum and her 10-year-old brother Erwin stared wide-eyed about them and shifted their feet nervously.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 11-- The prospective absorption of Tibet by Communist China is causing concern in Nepal, the independent Himalayan kingdom between Tibet and India.
Joe Louis and Ezzard Charles, who have an important engagement at the Yankee Stadium on Sept. 27, yesterday took care of another important transaction at the offices of the State Athletic Commission.

United Nations forces pressed counter-attacks against the flanks of the enemy's Pohang salient; the North Koreans were reported in confused retreat. Stretches of the vital highway in that area were cleared.
WENDOVER, Utah, Sept. 11 (AP) --A California driver wound up today with six American and international Diesel speed records in runs on the Bonneville salt flats.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 12-- United States and South Korean forces pushed their counter-attack today against both flanks of the salient that the Communist invaders drove last week through the United Nations lines southwest of the seaport of Pohang.

School bells tolled the end of the summer vacation yesterday as more than 1,000,000 city youngsters trudged off to school at the beginning of the 1950-51 academic year. Both the public and parochial school systems entered the new term with the largest enrollments in years.

John C. Weadock, a corporation lawyer specializing in the public utilities and railroad fields, a former law partner of the late Wendell L. Willkie, died of a heart attack Sunday night in his home at 225 Central Park West.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "The Happiest Days of Your Life," a British-made comedy, starring Alastair Sim and Margaret Rutherford, which will arrive at the Little Carnegie on Saturday. The importation written and directed by Frank Launder, was produced by Mr. Launder and Sydney Gilliat and is being presented by London Films.

The Senate will begin voting today on the anti-Communist measures which it has had under consideration for the past week, If it follows the course of least resistance, which is to approve anything with an "anti-Communist" label without looking too closely to see what else is involved, it will doubtless pass the McCarran bill (S. 4037).

IT would have been infinitely more appropriate if he'd departed with the flourish of a no-hitter or at least a victory. Secretary of State Dean Acheson said yesterday that he was confident his conferences with the Foreign Ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty countries here this week "will result in agreement on practical conclusions which will contribute to preserving peace."
TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 12 (AP)-- Release 420, issued by Gen. Douglas MacArthur at 11:40 A.M. Tuesday (10:40 P.M. Monday, Eastern daylight time):
COSHOCTON, Ohio, Sept. 11-- Thirty-three soldiers were killed early today when the Pennsylvania Railroad's Spirit of St. Louis rammed the rear of a stalled troop train. The death total may go higher.

In her twenty-six races, including seven stakes triumphs, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's trim little Bed O'Roses never has been sharper than she was in the rain and the wind and the slop at Aqueduct yesterday.

A charge last week by Sylvia Siegler, head of the Show-of-theMonth Club, that Broadway ticket brokers were attempting to restore the "buy," an outlawed system of bloc-ticket purchases, drew a denial yesterday from the New York Ticket Brokers, Inc.

Prices on cotton textiles sold yesterday in the Worth Street primary market reflected the record cotton price that followed the Department of Agriculture's low crop estimate. The 80x80 print cloth constructions reached a new high for the year with selling of limited amounts for 28 cents a yard. Sales of 64x60's were reported at 21 cents.
Fritz Refiner has signed a recording contract with the R.C.A. Victor Company, it was announced yesterday. His first recording will be an album of highlights from Johann Strauss' "Die Fledermaus."
Acting Mayor Impellitteri sent yesterday to the Board of Elections his formal acceptance of the independent nomination for Mayor filed in his behalf by the Experience party.
On the subway from Brooklyn to New York, an attractive young woman will stumble against someone occasionally.
ALBANY, Sept. 11--The State Board of Law Examiners announced today the names of 881 law students who passed the state bar examination given June 22 and 23. The test was taken by 1778 applicants.
Voluntary price control plans in metal industries are now expected to be among the first steps approved in Government actions to aid war output through anti-inflation procedures.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--The Economic Cooperation Administration announced today that it would allocate twice as much money for stockpiling strategic materials this year as it did last year.
A West Coast designer's knack of creating handsome suits and beautiful evening fashions was proved again yesterday by Lord Taylor in the store's first presentation of designs by Irene.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 11-- Yale football starts almost from Wick bottom this year following an exodus of talent that left Herman Hickman's cupboard bare of about everything except a couple of sides of prime beef.

Rain washed out the scheduled game between the Giants and the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds last night. Since the Giants have no more open dates at home on which the Dodgers also are free, the contest will have to be played at Ebbets Field.
The great Atlantic hurricane that had been churning slowly northward from the Caribbean since Aug. 30 passed 200 miles eastward of New York and out to sea last night.

The three R's are no longer enough for school children. A new idea was proposed this week when one of the country's leading educators suggested that the study of child psychology by children be made a basic part of all general education from nursery school up.

Events tonight: "The Beggar's Opera," The Interplayers, Carnegie Recital Bail, 8:40 o'clock; Alfredo Gandolfi, baritone, and Millicent Kahn, contralto, Riverdale Neighborhood Hall, 5221 Mosholu Avenue, Bronx, 8:30.

Alger B. Chapman, treasurer of the Republican State Committee and a former State Tax Commissioner, was selected yesterday to direct the campaign to return Governor Dewey to Albany for the third time and to elect Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley to the United States Senate.

TRENTON, Sept. 11--The constitutionality of the state utility anti-strike law and an award under it of $2.50 weekly to telephone operators were attacked today before the State Supreme. Court by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company.

HONG KONG, Sept. 11--Two large mechanized state farms are being established by the Chinese Communists along the upper bank of the Yellow River near Paotou, in Suiyuan Province.

TOKYO, Sept. 11--The North Korean People's Army lost more than 10,000 men, the strength of one full division at maximum recruitment, during last week's fighting, an analysis of official United States casualty reports showed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP)-- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, called today for a Senate investigation of the appointment of Morris A. Shenker, St. Louis lawyer, as a Democratic party fund raiser.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 11-- Communist China failed by one vote tonight to win an invitation to appear before the United Nations Security Council and press charges that United States planes had attacked Manchurian territory.
Dwellings dominate the real estate transactions reported in various sections of Long Island.

LONDON, Sept. 11, (UP)--Aviation experts took a long look at Britain's "fastest interceptor plane in the world" today and said the Soviet Union might have developed one almost as fast from jet engines shipped to Moscow by the Labor Government.

A new booklet designed to show young women how they can have their cake and eat it too--by combining a nursing and college career and nursing and marriage--is just off the press at the Committee on Careers in Nursing.

More than six months has passed since Dr. Luther Gulick was chosen by city authorities to be executive director of the Mayor's Committee on Management Survey. Dr. Gulick has described this survey as "the most momentous review of civic management ever undertaken."
The Department of Parks has offered a remedy for that "all work and no play" feeling youngsters experienced yesterday on their first day back at school.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11-- The mystery of why no "SOS" was sent from the fast-sinking Navy hospital ship Benevolence after its collision with the freighter Mary Luckenbach in a dense fog outside the Golden Gate on Aug. 25 was cleared up today at a Coast Guard hearing.

Crude rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange here yesterday, following sharp price rises on the London and Singapore markets, advanced 200 points, or 2 cents a pound--the permissible limit--on an expanded trading volume totaling 135 contracts.

After one of the financial district's closest competitive bidding operations in recent years, the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company awarded yesterday $40,000,000 of its first mortgage pipeline bonds to an investment banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
Men being called into the armed forces for Korean service are losing old-age insurance credits as a result of a gap left by Congress in the new Social Security Act.

J. Murray Williams has been appointed general manager of the foreign producing activities of the Atlantic Refining Company, Philadelphia. He succeeds C.H. Ford, who will assume new duties in the domestic crude oil production department in Dallas, Tex.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Sept. 11 (AP)--United States troops participating in war games retreated westward tonight before the mock attack of overwhelming "Aggressor" forces invading Western Germany from the east.
MADRID, Sept. 11 (Reuters)-- Count Alvara de Figueroa y Torres-Mendieta Romanones, veteran Spanish liberal statesman, died here tonight at the age of 87.
O'Gara Co. were the brokers in the recent lease of the building at 966 Avenue of the Americas by Beatrice B. Berle and others to Chock Full O'Nuts, Inc.

WASHINGTON,-- Sept. 11--The possibility of developing strong, democratic trade unions in Asia was stressed here today by John Brophy, a member of the Far East mission of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

A wage increase of 37 cents an hour covering 45,000 longshoremen from Portland, Me., to Hampton Roads, Va., and proportionate rises for 15,000 allied workers were asked yesterday by the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L.

IN the fifteenth century the little kingdom of Portugal had a population of considerably less than 2,000,000. The country was poor and unimportant, often at war with the Moors of North Africa and often at war with Spain.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP)--Ray Robinson will get the next shot at the world middleweight title if the National Boxing Association has its Way.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 11-- Philip Ashton Rollins, noted author and collector of Western Americana, died here today at his home after a long illness. His age was 81.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 11-- Prince Erik of Denmark, who, when he married Lois Frances Booth, daughter of a wealthy Canadian lumberman, had to renounce all rights of succession to the Danish throne for himself and his family, died today in a Copenhagen hospital at the age of 59. He was a cousin of the late King Christian X.

TOKYO, Sept. 11--For the benefit of Americans not acquainted with the peculiar language military men use, a few definitions were given today by a spokesman for Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters to assist in reading the communiques.
There were further reports yesterday about the tremendous advance business being done by box offices handling sales for "Call Me Madam," the new Irving BerlinHoward Lindsay-Russel Crouse musical.
The names of 160 draft dodgers have been reported to the Federal Bureau of Investigation here, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)-- The armed services disclosed today that first checks for direct family dependency payments under the new service men's allowance law will be in the mail early in December.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP)-- A Presidential fact-finding board ruled today that sixteen short line railroads were financially able to grant their nonoperating employes substantially the same wage-hour settlement in force on major carriers since 1949.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 11--Jan Christiaan Smuts, soldier, statesman, philosopher and generally regarded as the greatest figure that South Africa has produced, died tonight in his eightyfirst year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--Two officials of the Department of the Interior testified under oath today that Oscar L. Chapman, Secretary of the Interior, observed the usual procedure when he took his oath of office in 1946 as Under Secretary of the Interior.

LYNN, Mass., Sept. 11--Officials of the General Electric Company today made their first attempts to go through union picket lines in the twelve-day strike that has made idle 19,600 employee in five plants at Lynn and Everett, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)-- The Army said today Maj. Harold Dean Banning, who flew to this country on leave from Germany, was wanted for questioning in confection with alleged "misapplication of public funds in excess of $250,000."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11--Continued Government spending for civilian needs in the face of increasing defense demands was criticized here today on several sides at the opening of the fortythird annual conference on taxation at the William Penn Hotel.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sept. 11-- This temporary capital of Nationalist China is engaged in choosing the first representative City Council in the history of China.

Five "danger signals" that should warn parents that trained help is needed to set right difficulties with their youngsters are outlined in "How to Live With Children," by Edith G. Neisser and the staff of the Association for Family Living.

Plans for the construction of an 800-car garage in Pennsylvania Station in the space above the auto ramps at the south end of the building were made public yesterday by Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the City Planning Commission.
Harvey Dow Gibson's first contact with the business world when he left Bowdoin College in 1902 was with the American Express Company in Boston, and his first job was sweeping out the local office.

Although Tallulah Bankhead is considering some offers for television appearances, no video commitments she may undertake will interfere with her intention to continue stage activities, she said yesterday.
PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 11 (AP) --Gov. Frederick G. Payne, Republican, and three Republican members of the House won reelection in Maine's state election today.
The ban on the sounding of sirens, which went into effect at 8 A.M. yesterday under the state's Civil Defense Law, brought with it unexpected difficulties.

Cross-currents of magnitude developed yesterday in the stock market, with selling emphasis on securities of companies that might suffer from more stringent consumer credit. The rails continued to set the pace on the higher side, but even some of the leaders in this division came under realizing.

PARIS, Sept. 11--President Truman's announcement of an increase, in United States forces in Western Europe, which the French began urging more than two years ago, gave profound satisfaction to officials here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--Former Mayor William O'Dwyer of New York will go before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tomorrow to answer criticism of his nomination as Ambassador to Mexico.

YONGCHON, Korea, Sept. 11-- Two examples of North Korean propaganda designed to weaken the morale of United States troops in Korea were found Sunday in this city, from which the last enemy snipers had just been eliminated.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11--President Truman visited Walter Reed Hospital about 8 A.M. yesterday to inquire on the care received by casualties of the Korean war, the White House said today.

Miss Anne Caldwell Millett heads a group, of debutantes aiding in the sale of tickets for the performances of "Daphne Laureola," with Dame Edith Evans, on the night of Oct. 17 at the Music Box Theatre, and "Ring Round the Moon," with Lucille Watson, on the night of Dec. 9 at the Morosco Theatre, both for the benefit of the SpenceChapin Adoption Service.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)-- The Federal Power Commission late today recessed until Sept. 25 a hearing on allocation of natural gas supplies of Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company.

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 11--A plan for the establishment of a three or four state commission or authority with broad powers to finance and build the proposed $800,000,000 system of dams and reservoirs in the Delaware River Basin was divulged

ATLANTA, Sept, 11--Although she had to rally to win, Mrs. Mark Porter, the Westmont, N.J., housewife and mother of two youngsters, successfully began the defense of the women's national title in the United States Golf Association tournament which started today over the East Lake course of the Atlanta Athletic Club.

A superb cheese with a venerable history--it has been made high in the Swiss Alps by the Same family since the seventeenth century--is appearing here for the first time. It may be had at Macy's for $1.49 a pound.

Retention of the contributory pension system as the best method to increase benefits under the Railroad Retirement Act was advocated yesterday at the "silver jubilee" convention of the brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, A.F.L.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Out of 143 mayor labor market areas checked in mid-July, only four received an "E" classification, meaning a "very substantial labor surplus." This is less than half the mid-May total.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--President Truman signed today the Budget and Accounting Procedures Act of 1950 providing for a reorganization in the Treasury Department.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $97,212,000 fund for the State Department's many-sided information program, every dollar that had been asked by the Administration for the propaganda struggle with the Russians.

Asserting that careful use of water is still necessary, Water Commissioner Stephen J. Carney urged the public yesterday to make a particular effort tomorrow, the first water holiday since Aug. 10, to cut consumption.

The stock market made a complete about-face yesterday as prices rallied to new high levels of the recovery movement since the Korean crack-up. The advance of 2.10 points, as measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES index, was the best in more than a month and was accomplished on a comparatively small volume of trading.
LONDON, Sept. 12--Dr. Geoffrey Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of All England, accused the Roman Catholic Church today of not joining with other Christian faiths in the cause of freedom.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 12--The kingdom of Jordan has officially accused Israel of occupying Jordanian territory and forging a map to justify her act.
An impromptu South American jam session had everyone from guests to porters "jumping" yesterday in the sedate lobby of the Latham Hotel at 4 East Twentyeighth Street.
