A plan to make religion a major subject in 1951 at New York University's Washington Square College was stressed by Dean Thomas Clark Pollock in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase yesterday.
In a step that will open a new chapter in the redevelopment of a long-neglected slum district, the Bowery Savings Bank has decided to extend its operations into the heart of Harlem.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP)--The third-place Red Sox opened their fourth Western staging with a 2-1 victory over the White Sox before 9,119 persons tonight. Mel Parnell pitched a five-hitter to gain his sixteenth decision in beating Bill Wight in a tight pitchers' duel.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 12--Lowhanging rain clouds, whipped along on the skirts of the weary offshore hurricane, rolled back today and clear, crisp weather favored 7,000 visitors to the opening day of the Queens-Nassau Agricultural Society's 108th Mineola Fair.
Governor Dewey spent a second day yesterday with top Republican leaders and candidates, mapping campaign plans behind closed doors.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 12 --Six debutantes from this area were presented to society tonight at a large dance given by their respective parents at the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club, which was decorated for the occasion with ivy, palms, ferns, smilax and white flowers. The dance was preceded by many dinner parties.

Norman Tishman, president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, reported that the General Motors Corporation has leased the entire first and second floors in the four-story building at 1731-37 Broadway for twenty years.

Fifty-four students and teachers who had been stranded in Europe for eleven days because a student travel agency was unable to finance their return, journey, landed last night at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, after a free trip across the ocean.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Sept. 12-- The marriage of Miss Jeanne Vroman Borst, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Vroman Borst of Amsterdam and Piseco Lake, N.Y., to Ernest Hugh Rice Jr., son of Mrs. Arthur Newton Pierson Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., East Hamp
PARIS, Sept. 12--The British are letting word get around that Britain will need gold and dollar reserves of at least $6,000,000,000 before she can consider making hound sterling fully convertible.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP)--The Tigers made their five hits pay off in a big way today as they eked out a 3-2 decision over the stubborn Senators: Washington made it a fight all the way, pecking away at the three-run lead Detroit had built un in the early innnigs.
The delinquency rate among men called to take pre-induction physical examinations soared to a record 22 per cent for the metropolitan area yesterday.

Services among banks and their customers will be extended and facilitated by means of a new private teleprinter system which will begin operation soon, it was announced yesterday. The system, to be known as "The Bank Wire," will link 142 banks in thirty-six large cities throughout the nation, beginning on Nov. 1.
WHEN Steve O'Neill succeeded Joe McCarthy as the manager of the Boston Red Sox last June, the inevitable question was put to Joe DiMaggio.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 12--William O. Douglas, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, proposed to an audience of leading Iranians gathered at the University of Teheran today the distribution of the country's large landholdings to peasants to check communism.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 12--Communists theoretically demonstrating in sympathy with striking metal workers marched by the United States Embassy this afternoon yelling, "Peace, yes; war, no!" They also demanded that United States troops get out of Korea and that no Uruguayan troops be sent there.

The General Electric Company will reduce the number of television receivers allocated to distributors and dealers, a company spokesman indicated yesterday. Quotas on electric washing machines also will be cut, it is understood.
Rayon suits will enter the merchandising picture in men's suits for spring to a greater extent than ever before and will be a strongly competitive factor in pricing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--The National Inventor's' Council, which screens answers to armed services' technical problems for the Department of Defense, would like to hear the sane answers to Arctic problems.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP)--The Italian Government has banned most chartered flights of Holy Year pilgrims between Britain and Rome, a spokesman of the British Ministry of Civil Aviation said last night.
Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year of 5711, was hailed in synagogues throughout the city yesterday with fervent pleas for world peace.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--A New Bedford fishing boat went down today in heavy seas stirred by the Atlantic hurricane 100 miles off Nantucket and a broad air and sea search was ordered for the twelve crewmen adrift in a small dory.

TOKYO, Sept. 12--A spokesman for Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today that during the past three weeks United Nations forces captured more North Korean prisoners than during the whole previous course of the war.
Refunds or savings of $60,000,000 have been obtained by the Economic Cooperation Administration through basic controls on the purchase price of E.C.A.-financed exports. This was reported yester

CHICAGO, Sept. 12--Mr. and Mrs. Winfield Ellis have, announced the engagement ofd their only child, Gwen, to Alexander L. Cochrane of Chicago, son of Mrs Dudley L. Pickman of Boston and Hamilton, Mass., and New York, and the late A. Lynde Cochrane. The wedding will take place in December.
A funeral service for Pfc. Richard Riordan, believed to be the first Manhattan soldier to die in the Korean war, was held yesterday while flags on city buildings flew at half-staff.
The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France yesterday began their discussions of the steps necessary to provide Western Europe with sufficient strength to repel a...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 12-- The average American selects a bride or bridegroom from a group which consists of between 400 and 3,000 eligible persons of the opposite sex, it was estimated tonight at the meeting of the American institute of Biological Sciences at Ohio State University.

A new sortie record was established in Korea Monday when United States Air Force aircraft flew a total of 634 individual flights. In addition to these the Royal Australian Air Force flew thirty-eight sorties and the Marines eleven, under the operational control of the Fifth Air Force, making the total for the

SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Sept. 12--The Interstate Commission on the Delaware River Basin (Incodel) voted at its annual meeting here today to submit promptly to the legislatures of four states its program for developing water resources of the upper Delaware River.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12--American railroads, in an effort to meet military demands and requirements of an expanding domestic economy, are studying and using many methods whereby they can more effectively use the cars they own, Caleb R. Megee, vice chairman of the car service division of the Association of American Railroads, said today.

The American Broadcasting Company refused last night to cancel a new radio program with Gypsy Rose Lee, strip-tease dancer and author, unless the Illinois Department of the American Legion could substantiate its charges that she had pro-Communist sympathies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--The news that Morris A. Shenker had declined to serve as a member of the finance committee of the Democratic National Committee was received with undisguised re

DETROIT, Sept, 12-Under an overhang of official austerity, Jake La Motta, rugged Bronxite, will defend his world middleweight title in the Olympia tomorrow night gainst. Laurent Dauthuille, French challenger, in a struggle scheduled for fifteen rounds.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12--Buyers got busy today at the National Graphic Arts Exposition being held here weekdays through Sept. 23 in the International Amphitheater.

A year ago Fordham followers who have lamented the decline of the Ram as a football power had something to cheer about for the first time since pre-war days. It was a fighting, hard-hitting team with one of the best forward pass combinations in the country, though lacking in running speed, that Ed Danowski fielded, to win five of its eight games.

ATLANTA, Sept. 12--A surprising triumph by Mrs. J. Albert Hayes of Philadelphia marked the second round of the Women's United States Golf Association's championship at the East Lake course today as she eliminated the defending titleholder Mrs. Mark Porter of Westmont, N.J., 1 up, at the nineteenth hole.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP)--Rookie Ransom Jackson, who rejoined the Cubs this morning, clouted a tworun homer in the eighth inning tonight as the Braves suffered a 3-1 setback before 3,392 chilled fans. It was the smallest night-game gathering in this city's major league history.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 12--Federal taxation that duplicates state levies and wasteful Government spending were blasted by the big guns of both politics and industry here today at the forty-third annual conference of the American Tax Association.

Dr. Samuel Gring Hefelbower, professor emeritus of philosophy at Wagner Lutheran Memorial College on Grymes Hill, S.I., former president of Gettysburg (Pa.) College and an ordained Lutheran minister, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home in Chautau qua, N.Y., after a long illness. His age was 78.
ELDRED, Pa., Sept. 12 (AP)--A dynamite explosion that splintered a building at the National Powder Company today killed eight men and rocked homes for miles around.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 12--The Government of President Juan D. Peron was praised tonight by Stanton Griffis, United States Ambassador, for its social reforms.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Stephen T. Early, Deputy Secretary of Defense, stepped down from his job this afternoon a few hours before President Truman dropped Louis Johnson from his Cabinet as Secretary of Defense. For Mr. Early, former press secretary to the late President Roosevelt, it was a move he had long wanted to make.
Opposition to the Denton bill (H.R. 8763) was expressed yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., through Thomas Jefferson

Reflecting the increased sales for the quarter and nine months ended with July, earnings of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., substantially exceeded those of the corresponding periods a year ago, according to the financial statement issued yesterday by Robert T. Stevens, board chairman.
Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies rose 17.4 per cent in August, according to a compilation of forty concerns made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Several important developments are expected to follow the nomination of Gen. George C. Marshall as Secretary of Defense.

Last May when I returned from an earlier visit to the Philippines, I had occasion to explain that the violent acts perpetrated by the Communist bands there [the Huk balahaps] were of a sporadic character and presented no real threat to the political stability of the country. In recent weeks, however, these acts of violence have occurred on such a scale as would warrant a revision of that previous estimate of the situation.

Ernest Bevin, Foreign Secretary of Britain, arriving for meetings of the Western Big Three Foreign Ministers, expressed doubt yesterday that a revival of German military might was the way for Ger many--to come back as great power.
Henry Wallace Cohu, senior partner in Cohu Co., investment bankers, has been elected a director of Angostura-Wuppermann Corporation, it was announced yesterday.
Joseph B. Ryan, 44-year-old proprietor of the famous ski resort at Mont Tremblant, Que., and a grandson of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, plunged twenty-two floors to death at 7 A.M. yester

CHICAGO, Sept. 12--Grain markets closed irregular on the Board of Trade today after being fairly active, especially in the early trading, when buying of wheat, corn and soybeans, attributed to export interests, resulted in higher prices. However, volume fell off later.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP) --Robin Roberts won a brilliant 1-to-0 pitching duel from Max Lanier and the Cardinals tonight to annex his nineteenth victory of the year and preserve the Phillies' six-and-one-half game National League lead.

A large section of organized labor in New York is scheduled to announce today its support of Justice Ferdinand Pecora, Democratic and Liberal party nominee for Mayor. In doing so, it will split the United Labor Committee, whose co-chairman, Martin Lacey of the Central Trades and Labor Council, A.F.L., is a principal backer of Acting Mayor Impellitteri's independent candidacy.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 12 --Woodbridge Vanderhoof is back in jail and Morris County peace officers have saved their red faces. But trees will never look the same to them.

Guy G. Gabrielson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, urged yesterday the election of a Republican Congress pledged to American principles and opposition to communism at home and abroad. He asked particularly for the defeat of Democrats who "blindly" followed President Truman's "incompetent" leadership.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dept. 12--The first five jurors, all Long Island Rail Road commuters, were chosen today to try Jacob Kiefer, motorman charged with responsibility for the train wreck that killed thirty-two and injured seventyseven passengers at Rockville Centre last February.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP)--In returns containing only a scattering of the important Detroit vote former Gov. Harry. F. Kelly held a lead in today's primary voting for the Republican nomination as Governor.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Wednesday, Sept. 13--Senator Charles W. Tobey won renomination by a slim margin in New Hampshire's Republican primary. The self-styled Liberal topped Wesley Powell, 34-year-old protege of Senator Styles Bridges, also a Republican, in a battle that ran down to the final tabulation early today.
Fake furs make no pretenses this year. They are making fashion news as a novelty fabric rather than a substitute for fur.

GREEN RIVER, Wyo., Sept. 12 (UP)--The Union Pacific streamliner Pony Express smashed into a switch engine in the rail yards here today, injuring twelve persons, six of them members of the road show of the hit musical "South Pacific."

Last May London was the scene of the first Foreign Ministers Conference in which Russia did not participate. That meeting was the official admission that the break in the war alliance was complete. Now the three Western

Form fell flat at the Aqueduct Race Track yesterday exactly were one would expect it to hold up. The feature attraction was the Naiad, for 2-year-old fillies, run in two divisions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--President Truman accepted the resignation of Louis Johnson as Secretary of Defense this evening and then announced he would appoint Gen. George C. Marshall as his successor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--They Senate Foreign Relations Committee deferred a vote today on the nomination of William O'Dwyer, former Mayor of New York, as, Ambassador to Mexico but a committee recommendation for confirmation is considered certain.

Three five-story buildings containing six stores and forty-nine apartments on plot 74 by 100 feet at 485-87-89 Tenth Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-seventh Street, have been sold by the Estate of August G. Luchow to a client of Foss Dohm, Inc., brokers in the deal. The seller took

As the Big Three Foreign Ministers began work yesterday on a program for speeding up and expanding the defenses of the Atlantic community to prevent further Russo-Communist aggression the problem confronting them

HONG KONG, Sept. 12--Although the mixed economy of Mao Tze-tung's "new democracy" reserves wide sectors of activity for private enterprise, the state has come to dominate all major aspects of economic life in China.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP)-- Mrs. Frances Dustin, administrative assistant to Senator Owen Brewster, Republican of Maine, told Senate wire-tap investigators today of making a cash payment to a Washington police lieutenant, Joseph W. Shimon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12--The International Harvester Company today increased its offer of wage increases from seven to ten cents an hour to two unions in an effort to end strikes of 50,000 workers against the company's nineteen plants in Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Kentucky and Tennessee.
BARCELONA, Spain, Sept. 12-- The prospect of a large loan from the United states has had the paradoxical effect here of slowing down industrial production.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--The National Labor Relations Board ruled unanimously today that an individual seeking to obtain a board election to decertify another union would not "front" for a union that had not complied with the non-Communist affidavit requirements of the Taft-Hartley Act.

OTTAWA, Sept. 12--Completing the legislation proposed by the Government at the opening of its special session two weeks ago, Parliament has approved measures giving the Govermnent the power to control and regulate the production and use of essential materials and services and to set a limit on installment purchase.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Sept. 12--Morris A. Shenker of St. Louis, a lawyer whose clients include several who are being investigated by the Senate Crime Investigation Committee, declined appointment today to the Democratic National Finance Committee.

With the completion of two adjourned games from the fifteenth round, which were both drawn, but yielded Argentina an additional victory or twele in all the ninth chess tournament for international team supremacy was officially closed, yesterday, at a luncheon in Dubrovnik, according to a report from Yugoslavia.

In the true spirit of democracy an alliance has been made between one of the topflight designers of America and a leading merchant with department stores in New York and Los Angeles. Announcement was made at a luncheon yesterday at the Sherry-Netherland that an important model collection made by Charles James has been bought by Ohrbach's.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--President Truman today nominated Ambassador Cavendish W. Cannon, a career diplomat of thirty years' experience, to be Minister to Syria, a key post in the troubled Near East.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 12-- North Korean authorities told the United Nations today that bombings by the United States Air Force had resulted in the destruction of almost all Korean industry.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Sept. 12 (AP)-- Mrs. Ana Frohmiller, Arizona's State Auditor for twenty--four years held a narrow lead tonight for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Sept. 12 -The people of the Benelux area expect and hope that a definite decision to build up a West German defense force will come out of the Western Big Three Foreign Ministers' conference and meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Council. But they have one major condition to tag on to such a decision.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 12--With the realization that the death yesterday of Jan Christian Smuts marks the passing of an era in South African history, the country has tacitly declared a political truce to mourn "a great figure of his time." This description came from Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan.
United Nations forces at Yongchon and Pohang yesterday continued their task of clearing the area of the enemy and establishing a strong defensive line.

DENVER, Sept. 12 (AP)--Former Gov. Ralph L. Carr, making a comeback after eight years in political retirement, took a long lead for the Republican nomination for Governor in early returns tonight from Colorado's primary elections.

LONDON, Sept. 12--Prime Minister Attlee disclosed today that some British manufacturers had been advised not to accept orders for "unusual quantities" of certain material that might be helpful to the North Korean military forces. He said that other manufacturers receiving such inquiries should consult the Government, but he did not specify what the material was.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 12-- Fear that a motion picture dealing with the life and exploits of Hiawatha, Onondaga Indian Chief of the fifteenth century of whom Longfellow wrote in his classic

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Representative Carl Hinshaw, Republican of California, charged today that Great Britain had not cooperated with the United States to prevent export of important atomic energy "gadgets" to the Netherlands.

Big industries here have started preparations for operation under any new priorities and allocations system to be announced by the National Production Administration. Executives of many leading trade associations visited Washington yesterday to find out what indus
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--After seven days of bitter contest, the Senate passed a drastic anti-subversion bill this evening by a vote of 70 to 7. The bill would not only force the registration as

Sheldon Jones, who gets married today, made it practically mandatory for Leo Durocher to hand over an especially handsome wedding present by shutting out the Pirates, 3--0, on six hits at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the Giants stretched their newest winning streak to three games.

In the latest chapter of the controversy between the Show-of-theMonth Club and the Broadway ticket brokers, Sylvia Siegler, head of the club, characterised as false yesterday the charge that her organization had restored the "buy," the outlawed method of purchasing theatre tickets in blocks.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 13-- United States and South Korean troops moved into the offensive today on all sections of the United Nations perimeter in Korea.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 12 (AP)--Lou Clayton of the famed night club act of Clayton, Jackson and Durante, died today of cancer at the age of 63.

Although everything at Ebbets Field yesterday was low, including run and hit production, the temperature and the attendance, these were gigantic alongside the feelings of Cincinnati's Ewell Blackwell. "The Whip," as the elongated right-hander is called, pitched himself a one-hitter, only to be beaten by the Dodgers, 3--1.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 12-- Major airports currently in use will require few changes to accommodate jet-propelled transports, but expansion may be needed for increasing air freight service, according to reports submitted today at the opening of a three-day conference on ground facilities at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- James K. Knudson, new Defense Supervisor of Transportation, today took steps to relieve a nationwide freight car shortage.
The chief snag in negotiations to end the three-month-old soda ash strike was removed yesterday, stirring hope that the dispute would be settled by the end of this week.

A complete skeleton organization for the civil defense of New York was announced last night. It extended from the first liaison with the Eastern Air Defense Force, in the event of attack, to the duties set for the smallest unit of city residents--the air raid post.
Less than one month out of the reconversion yard and with only one voyage recorded in her logbook, the French liner Liberty at

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Sept. 12-- Mike Turnesa, pro at Knollwood, had two shots within the ten-foot circle at Leewood Golf Club's 155yard ninth hole today and his closest, one foot, four inches away was the best try among the 156 hopefuls in the second day's activity of the seventeenth annual New York World-Telegram and Sun hole-in-one contest.
LONDON, Sept. 12--Progress in Britain's overseas trade in August and more encouraging news from Korea stimulated the stock markets here today to another long list of small rises.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 12--The Soviet Union tonight vetoed the appointment of a United Nations commission to investigate Communist China's charge that United States planes had attacked Manchurian territory.

Prices for natural crude rubber turned weak in the futures market on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. The market opened lower and sagged almost continuously during the trading session. At the close prices were 110 to 150 points under. Monday's final levels.

NOW that the majority of gunsmiths have their benches and racks piled high with repair work, thousands of sportsmen who should know better are shipping rifles and shotguns for repairs or alterations that should have been initiated last spring.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 12--Delivery of three American President liners under construction at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation's plant here will be delayed three months.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--President Truman left it today to his Democratic leaders to give the signal when this Congress should adjourn.

My dear Mr. President: I have today presented to you the unanimous recommendations of the Joint Secretaries, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and myself for the re-armament of the United States in concert with the rearmament programs of the other free nations. The completion of these unanimous recommendations marks a milestone in our work for the security of the United States and the peace of the world.

Establishment of a board to review appeals by seamen denied shipping articles because of alleged Communist affiliation has been delayed because the proposed board members are themselves being screened.
Unless business sets aside adequate reserves now to pay for the cost of tomorrow's pensions and invests those reserves in productive enterprise, the drains on na
Results of the wine judging at the California State Fair at Sacramento, which closed on Sunday, have been announced. Most medalwinners represent lots of wine specially made in too small amounts
CLEVELAND, Sept. 12--For more than four and a half hours the Yankees fought a heroic battle to retain their half-game lead in the sizzling American League flag race tonight.

Robert B. Brown, vice president of the Bristol-Myers Company, has also been named president of the Bristol-Myers products division. He has been with the parent company fourteen years, joining it as advertising manager in 1936. He is a past chairman of the board of the Association of National Advertisers.From Our Own Correspondent.
LONDON, Sept, 12--Prime Minister Attlee said today that Britain would send another division of troops to Germany and bring up to strength the two divisions already there.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 12--Dr. Frederic E. Merwin, director of the Rutgers University School of Journalism, announced

The Arlando Realty Company, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the one-story taxpayer containing seven stores at the southwest corner of Merrick Road and Rockaway Avenue in Valley Stream, L.I., from Mrs. Rose Claire. Robert S. Kline and Harry Segal were the brokers.

Advance reservations for the twenty-fourth annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States, which runs in conjunction with the annual American Merchant Marine Conference, are exceeding expectations.

PARIS, Sept. 12--Two notable figures in French journalism of the first half of the century, died today. They were Raymond Recouly, newspaper and magazine writer and historian, and Leon Renier, for forty years president of the old Havas Agency for news and advertising.

MONICA ENID DICKENS is a young English woman with a sense of humor and con siderable literary ability, qualities she shares with one of her ancestors, her great-grandfather, Charles Dickens. For the last eleven years Miss Dickens has been writing books which have been enormously successful in England, only moderately so here. There have been eight of them

DETROIT, Sept. 13-In a blazing finish that thrilled 11,424 fans who paid receipts of $71,694 for the spectacle, Jake La Motta pulled victory from imminent defeat at Olympia tonight and retained his world middleweight title.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Something in the nature of an Economic Overseas Administration through which would funnel the billions of dollars in United States military and economic aid that goes abroad annually is suggested in a preliminary draft of recommendations to be submitted to President Truman by Gordon Gray.

The controversy between the New York City Opera Company and Local 10 of the American Federation of Musicians in Chicago has been settled, and the opera company will carry out its original plans of opening in Chicago on Nov. 15.

Leon Bronesky, whose last Broadway presentation was "How Long Till Summer," has taken an option on a new farce-comedy by Morton Krause called "Check and Double." The work was tried out this summer at the Blythewood Summer Theatre in Chesterton, N.Y., which Mr. Bronesky runs.
Thanks to the weather, the sweet-potato yield is expected to total ten bushels more an acre this year than the 1939-48 average.
The Messrs. Shubert have practically concluded all production arrangements for the forthcoming Frederick Lonsdale comedy, "The Way Things Go," a current success at the Phoenix Theatre in London.

In a letter made public here yesterday, John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner for Germany, denied he had ever considered "anything in the nature of a general amnesty for German war criminals."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Ernest Gruening, Governor of Alaska, denied before the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee today that he or any other official of the territorial government could be considered a potential "Quisling" in the event of attack by the Soviet Union.

The Twenty-seventh Infantry Division Association, composed of veterans of the only division made up exclusively of New York State men to serve in the last war, will hold its first annual convention at the Hotel Commodore starting tomorrow. The division has 50,000 veterans of both World Wars from the metropolitan area alone.

Smaller banks will be assisted in developing salary programs designed to assure fair treatment for employes while improving administrative methods, under a project announced yesterday by the American Bankers Association.

GREENS FARMS, Conn., Sept. 13 Miss Gertrude Floyd-Jones Harrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Triplett Harrison of Greens Farms and 1 East End Avenue, New York, has completed plans for her marriage to Hamilton Winslow, son of Mrs. John Winslow of Montclair, N.J., and the late Mr. Winslow, which will take place Sept. 30 in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

It was sensible of the Senate Appropriations Committee to restore the original full sum of $97,212,000 for the Voice of America and other State Department information services. The House of Representatives had lopped off more than $19,000,000, which was shortsighted and a good example of how not to economize. There is always a tendency, although a natural one, to chop down items that do not offer tangible results or that have little or...

Two separate sound programs were transmitted over a single ordinary FM station channel here yesterday in the first public test of a new system designed to "increase the effectiveness of all available FM channels now in use by making it possible for them to send more programs."

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 13 (AP)--Israeli forces have occupied an area at Naharayim along the border of Jordan because it is Israel's territory under the Rhodes armistice agreement with King Abdullah, an Army spokesman said today.

"Well, at least I can get a little sleep now." That was Sal Maglie's philosophic reaction to the seventhinning homer by Pittsbugh's Gus Bell that yesterday ended his nearrecord string of consecutive scoreless innings at forty-five.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Percy C. Spender, Australian Minister for External Affairs, made an earnest plea today for a Pacific defense alliance comparable in scope and purpose to the North Atlantic Pact.

Yesterday marked the thirteenth anniversary of the laying of the cornerstone of the building Lilly Dach occupies at 79 East Fifty-sixth Street. This gave flavor to the presentation of her fall and winter custom-made fashions. But it was also an exciting and glamorous collection.

Near-by gardens, in a last burst of productivity before they are nipped by fall frosts, are supplying local markets with an abundance of fresh fruits and vegetables, greater than any other time of the year.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. of the Federal District Court ruled today that the action of four leading American manufacturers of coated abrasives in combining to manufacture jointly in foreign countries was a violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

It rained a little harder at Ebbets Field yesterday than at the Polo Grounds, with the result that the Reds' second engagement with the Dodgers finally had to be called off, an hour after the scheduled 1:30 starting time.
DETROIT, Sept. 13 (AP) The Tigers clung grimly to their halfgame lead in the American League pennant race as they cashed in on 10 hits and a coupe of breaks to whip the Senators, 6 1, today.
ROME, Sept. 13--Civil Aeronautics authorities have recently shown increased reluctance to authorize chartered plane flights to and from Italy.

NEWARK, Sept. 13 The right of Federal savings and loan associations to establish branch offices, disputed in a suit in Federal Court here, by the North Arlington National Bank, was in effect sustained in an opinion by Judge Guy L. Fake today. Judge Fake dismissed the suit in which the Kearny Federal Savings and Loan Association, with a branch office in North Arlington, was defendant.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 14 Guns of United States and British warships shelled Inchon on Korea's west coast twenty miles from Seoul while carrier planes raked 100 miles of coastland, the Navy announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the arrest of ten persons in what was described as a $2,000,000 international lottery ticket ring. Arrests were made in several cities, J. Edgar Hoover, F.B.I. Director, said.

To strengthen the attack on the mental health problems of the nation, the country's three leading voluntary organizations in this field the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, the National Mental Health Foundation and the Psychiatric Foundation yesterday announced their merger. The new organization will be called the National Association for Mental Health, Inc

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 13 The significance of the return to Mexico of sixty-nine battle flags captured by the United States Army in 1847 was emphasized today in an impressive ceremony when President Miguel Aleman accepted the flags.

TOKYO, Sept. 13 The United States Air Force is developing new weapons and new techniques to deal with the problems of the Korean war, a spokesman said today. One of these is an armor-piercing rocket eight to each lighter plane that has made the Soviet-built T-34 tank a "sitting duck" for the pilots who are able to get the North Korean armored vehicles within their sights.

JUST about a month ago there was considerable excitement generated by the fact that Ralph Kiner was slugging away at a pace which was threatening Babe Ruth's home run record. The heir apparent to the title of Sultan of Swat even was one homer ahead of the Babe's production rate.

M.A.H. Ispahani, Ambassador of Pakistan, told the National Management Council at the Pierre Hotel yesterday that his country welcomed American help in its efforts to achieve a better balance between agriculture and industry.

A gain in manufacturing was seen yesterday as the chief hope for an essential increase in total employment and population of New York City. This was one of the conclusions reached by Harrison, Ballard Allen, consultants, in a new survey made public by Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Capital expenditures by industry will be expanded by at least $1,800,000,000 this year as a result of the Korean war, according to a joint survey made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the United States Department of Commerce.

Panama City, Fla., sold yesterday issues of $3,500,000 of utilities revenue obligations due April 1, 1953 to 1985 to a banking syndicate headed by John Nuveen Co. at a bid of 100.0128 for 3s, 2.80s and 2 s, an interest cost of 2.7954 per cent.
The "Blue Alert" has been abolished as an air raid warning. In early plans for defense against atomic bombing the alert had been designed to sound fifteen to thirty minutes before an expected attack.

The semi-annual report of the Union Tank Car Company and its wholly owned subsidiary disclosed yesterday a net income of $2,130,953, realized on $8,838,006 gross operating income, for the six months ended June 30. Net income for the corresponding period of last year was $1,508,623, on a gross of $7,872,345.

HONG KONG, Sept. 13 The People's Court has ordered the former Shanghai branch of the American Chase Bank to pay to the municipal government of Sian, capital of Shensi Province, the equivalent of $148,664 (United States) in connection with a disputed business transaction dating back to August, 1936.

While the Western Big Three foreign ministers conferred yesterday in their skyscraper suite atop the Waldorf-Towers, a work force of advisers, diplomatic experts, military specialists and administrative helpers was also busy fifteen floors below.

As it passed the Senate Tuesday evening, the McCarran anti-subversive bill is something of a hodgepodge. On the credit side, it now includes as a lastminute addition the Kilgore detentioncenter bill, which goes to the heart of the Communist problem. And it retains a few useful technical provisions that would strengthen existing security laws. But the fact that the bill embraces some good features does not...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13 (AP) Sara Allgood, Irish-born actress who had a long career with the Abbey Players in Dublin before entering motion pictures, died of a heart ailment today in Motion Picture Country Hospital. She was 66 years old.

VANCOUVER, Wash., Sept. 13 (UP) Theodore A. Penland, last commander-in-chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, died today of a heart attack at Barnes Hospital at the age of 101. He had been a patient at the hospital intermittently during the last year. He had returned only a week ago from Los Angeles, where he had flown to attend a meeting of veterans' organizations.

ADVANCE HEADQUARTERS, Eighth Army, in Korea, Sept. 13 Lieut. Gen. Walton H. Walker, commander of the United States Eighth Army, promised his troops today that they would pass to the offensive within a short period.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) The House passed today a bill to let the Government buy two passenger shops from the Oceanic Steamship Company and use them as troop carriers. The measure now goes to the Senate.

The New York City C.I.O. Political Action Committee, representing eighteen unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations with a membership 500,000, decided yesterday to support Justice Ferdinand Pecora, Democratic-Liberal nominee for Mayor.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 13 Five more jurors were picked today in the trial of Jacob Kiefer, motorman accused of causing the Long Island Rail Road collision that killed thirty-two and injured seventy-seven passengers in Rockville Centre last Feb. 17.

Last night's bill at the Metropolitan Opera House found the Sadler's Wells Ballet still performing the full-length version of "Lac des Cygnes", but this time with its second cast. It was Beryl Grey who was the Odette and Odile, with John Field as the prince, and a number of other changes down the line.

A plot containing 14,000 square feet at the corner of Queens Boulevard and Union Turnpike in Forest Hills, Queens, has been leased by Perry P. Kemp from the Queens Union Realty Company, Inc., of which Morty Wolosoff is president.

Another forward push of major proportions was registered yesterday by the stock market. Supported by the heaviest trading since July 25, prices came within a point of the mid-June high, with the composite rate raised 1.55 points, although gains in many sections exceeded this.

WALTHAM, Mass., Sept. 13 C. Keefe Hurley, one of three court-appointed trustees of the Waltham Watch Company, said today that twenty-five workers had been rehired to prepare inventory and get the 100-year-old plant back into production.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today major new issues of securities valued at more than $50,000,000. The flotations include mortgage bonds and preferred stock of public utility companies and the equity shares of a Canadian oil enterprise. The offerings are as follows:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 Under cover of a leaden sky that threatened to burst into tears any moment, but never did, the Yankees struck hard and fast today as they thrashed the tottering Indians in the series finale, 10 to 3. Then they pushed on to Detroit, where tomorrow they engage the Tigers in the first of a three-game series with the league leadership at stake.

PARIS, Sept. 13 The appointment of General of the Army George C. Marshall as United States Secretary of Defense, replacing Louis Johnson, was welcomed here today on both political and military grounds.

NOW that the preserve shooting season is under way in New York and will open in Connecticut and New Jersey on Oct. 1, many sportsmen unable to wait for the open game seasons will have a chance to try new guns and dogs on pheasants, quail, chukar partridges and waterfowl provided, of course, the budget can stand it.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (AP) The Pennsylvania Railroad's Spirit of St. Louis was running late, going too fast and ran through a stop signal as it ripped into a stalled troop train, its engineer testified today.

Don McNeill, toastmaster of radio's daily "Breakfast Club" for more than seventeen years, led his entire radio troupe into television last night at 9, o'clock over the American Broadcasting Company. What transpired on the TV screen amounted to the "Breakfast Club" coming to dinner.

BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Sept. 13Princeton's football squad will leave its mountain training site tomorrow morning, three days ahead of schedule. Head Coach Charlie Caldwell made the decision today to take his charges back to Princeton. Because the rain and cold prohibited normal drills, it became impossible to dry out the players' equipment.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Polish Embassy protested today against alleged "discrimination" by United States authorities against the Polish liner Batory.

LAKESIDE, Conn., Sept. 13 Far from Broadway in its first offcampus training quarters, the Columbia football squad is in its second week of development for the twenty-first season of Lou Little's tenure as head coach.

A proposed motor-freight increase for the West Side market zone and the city's garment section was denounced as "without justification" yesterday in a joint protest by the Port of New York. Authority and 200 companies represented in the Shippers Conference of Greater New York.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 13 Delos W. Rentzel, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics, asserted today that airports handling intercontinental flights should begin planning for jet aircraft soon.
Manufacturers of work clothes, opening their books for fourthquarter business, are increasing the prices of work shirts, dungarees, and overalls.

The graphic Daily Weather Bulletin started in July by the Weather Bureau here has proved its value and probably will start soon to pay its way, Ernest J. Christie, chief meteorologist, said yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 13 Tom Robbins of Winged Foot, winner in 1948 and 1949, set his sights on a third straight title by shooting a four-over-par 35, 39 74 today, to lead a field of 103 in the first round of the Westchester Seniors' Golf Association sixteenth annual championship at the Westchester Hills golf club.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 If the American people are to be assured a steady supply of petroleum products at reasonable prices the present corporate structure of our domestic oil industry with both integrated and independent companies must be maintained, the National Petroleum Association was told here today.
TODAY, through Sunday, an educational film collection, "Secrets of Nature," by Oxford Films, will have its final showing at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, 154 West Fifty-fifth Street.

Uncertainty about the future of shipping in the international crisis has caused cancellation of the New York-Florida service of the Refrigerated Steamship Line, a subsidiary of the United Fruit Company.

Two American students who recently returned from a year's study overseas said yesterday that British students go to school to learn, while here students go to "mix socially." They added that the social life at English school was "too staid" for their tastes.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 13 A $375,000,000 merger, the largest in the history of Indiana, was approved today by directors of the Indiana National Bank and the Union Trust Company, two of Indiana's oldest and strongest financial institutions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Texans supporting a proposal to build three dams on the Brazos River today attacked the Government's claim to jurisdiction over the projects.

A comprehensive program for corporate simplification and a general reduction in operating expenses was announced yesterday by E.C. Huntington, chairman of the boards of the Equity Corporation and the American General Corporation, both investment companies of the closed-end type.

YORK, Pa., Sept. 13--A program that eventually will result in reactivation of the famous York plan for national defense, under which mobilization of the community's resources established a nation-wide pattern during World War II, was announced today by the Manufacturers' Association here.

WINNIPEG, Sept. 13 (Canadian Press) Stanley Jones, president of the Winnipeg Grain Exchange, said today that Canadian farmers had lost $680,000,000 in five years because of the compulsory grainmarketing policy.

Secretary of State Acheson had a trump card to play in the current Foreign Ministers conference at the Waldorf-Astoria, but President Truman gave it away before the Secretary arrived, and Mr. Acheson has been trying to cut his losses ever since.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Sept. 13--Five years as resident physician and surgeon in Eastern hospitals ended today for William R. MacLeod, 37 years old, when he began serving a one-year sentence in the Westchester County Penitentiary at Eastview. Exposed as a fraud, he possesses neither a medical degree nor high school diploma.
PARIS, Sept. 13--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development made two loans totaling $7,000,000 to Ethiopia today.

Away Away of the Woodvale Farm landed the heavier part of the old one, two punch in the Cowdin Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. Allowing his stablemate, Iamarelic, to spear away at the others in the early part of the six-and-ahalf furlong event, Away Away came through with the crusher at the finish to score by three lengths.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 An emergency board in a report to President Truman today accused four railroad brotherhoods of trying to "extort" hundreds of thousands of dollars from the New York Central by economic force and disregard of the Railroad Labor Act.

MORNING COMMUNIQUE: On all fronts units of the People's Army continue fierce fighting, overcoming the enemy's resistance. On the eastern bank of the Naktong River the American troops, who had sustained heavy...

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 (AP) Led by the top two Davis Cup stars from Australia, Frank Sedgman and Ken McGregor, favorites advanced into the quarter-finals of the men's singles in the Pacific Southwest tennis tournament today.

KAPRUN, Austria, Sept. 4 Up above the clouds from here, more than 6,000 feet above sea level, Austria is building with United States help what will be when completed in 1954 her loftiest and largest electric storage plant. It will also be among the greatest in Europe and one of the most important units in the integrated Central European power system envisaged as part of the Marshall Plan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 House-Senate conferees informally agreed today on the corporation and individual income tax increases voted by the Senate on Sept. 1.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 Rigidly enforced scientific tests to rid the roads of drunken drivers were urged today by Thomas W. Ryan, New York State Director of Safety.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13--Congress moved quickly today to make it legally possible for a professional soldier, General of the Army George C. Marshall, to become the Secretary of Defense in place of outgoing Louis Johnson.
A comprehensive picture of fall fashions was projected yesterday in the collection presented by Bloomingdale's.
Keith Stuart, 17-year-old jockey who has been having so much success as a daily double factor, figured in the combination again by scoring with Good Boy in the opening event.

MANILA, Sept. 13--President Elpidio Quirino has announced the appointment of three new Cabinet members in the Government reorganization that has been going on piecemeal several months under public pressure for top-level changes in the administration of national affairs.

LONDON, Sept. 13 Interest broadened beyond the usually favored shares in the stock markets here today following the Prime Minister's statement on rearmament yesterday. Prices responded with widespread rises to increased business.
Richard Rodgers conceded yesterday that there is a possibility that he and Oscar Hammerstein 2d might fashion a show for the especial talents of Judy Garland, movie actress.

The American Legion official who linked Gypsy Rose Lee to proCommunist groups said yesterday that he would not substantiate his charges against the strip-tease dancer and placed the burden of proof on the publishers of "Red Channels." The publishers, in turn, said that they would not offer further documentation.

CHICAGO, Sept.13 Guy George Gabrielson, Republican national chairman, declared tonight that President Truman would have been well advised to dismiss Dean Acheson, Secretary of State, just as he did Louis Johnson, Secretary of Defense.
BOSTON, Sept. 13 Political observers agreed today that the resuits of yesterday's primaries in New Hampshire and Vermont constituted a victory for the forces of Republican liberalism.
LONDON, Sept. 13--Britain has ordered a halt to deliveries of scarce military equipment, including jet aircraft, to countries outside the North Atlantic Pact and the British Commonwealth.

Two major unions representing mechanical employer on New York daily newspapers have reached tentative wage agreements with the Publishers Association of New York City, William Mapel, vice chairman of the association, announced yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 Announcement has been made by Mrs. Eugene James McMahon of the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Catherine Louise, to Francis Troja of New York, son of John S. Troja of Fort Madison, Iowa, and the late Mrs. Troja. The wedding will take place Oct. 7 in St. Louis, King of France, Roman Catholic Cathedral (Old Cathedral) here.

BOSTON, Sept. 13, (AP) A New England apple crop of 8,788,000 bushels, 46 per cent more than the average production over the last ten years, was forecast today by the crop reporting Service of the Department of Agriculture. It said the crop would be 1 per cent smaller than in 1949.

Putting aside for the moment their opposing campaigns for the mayoralty, Acting Mayor Impellitteri and Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora yesterday led 500 of their colleagues into St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church for the "Red Mass," traditional to the opening of the judicial season. Mr. Pecora was one of a number of non-Catholics present.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 How extensively would General of the Army George C. Marshall make over the top civilian command of the Defense Department was one of the biggest questions at the Pentagon today. But in discussion and speculation attempts to reconstruct the steps by which the Secretary of Defense, Louis Johnson, submitted his resignation and had it accepted were close up.
WITH UNITED STATES 24TH DIVISION, Korea, Sept. 13 Gar H. Davidson, a West Point football immortal, emerged today as a hero of the allied Korean campaign.
A combined British-American cruiser and destroyer force, commanded by Rear Admiral John M. Higgins, U.S.N., yesterday bombarded military targets in the Inchon area.

DETROIT, Sept. 13--Adoption of the new contract proffered to the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., by the Ford Motor Company on Labor Day became assured tonight when Local 600, with a majority of all Ford workers within its membership of 65,000, voted by a margin of 6 to 4 in favor of the agreement.
ATHENS, Sept. 13 The new Government under the Liberal party leader, Sophocles Venizelos, was sworn in today before King Paul.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 An emergency supplemental bill for about $17,185,000,000, largely to increase the military strength of the United States and its European friends, was approved unanimously tonight by the Senate Appropriations Committee.

LONDON, Sept. 13 A program of economic mobilization for something short of war was outlined in the House of Commons today by Hugh Gaitskell, Minister of State for Economic Affairs, during the second day of the debate on British rearmament.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP) Lefty Warren Spahn pitched his nineteenth victory, a four-hit 5-2 decision over the Cubs, tonight, to protect the Braves' third-place National League margin of one-half game over the hard-driving Giants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 9 0 today to cite for contempt of Congress Earl Browder, Frederick Vanderbilt Field and Philip J. Jaffe for refusal to answer questions concerning Communist affiliations or associations.

ATLANTA, Sept. 13 One of the most unusual matches in the history of the championship was called on account of darkness tonight in the United States Golf Association's women's title tourney at the East Lake course when the South American entry, Miss Fay Crocker of Uruguay, and 24-yearold Miss Mae Murray of Rutland, Vt., had completed play at the twenty-fourth hole.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 13 The sudden end to the brief and stormy career of Louis Johnson as Secretary of Defense unquestionably strengthens national security at a time of international peril.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 13 A program to improve the relationship between medical practitioners and patients was put into effect today by the Westchester County Medical Society.
All true gourmets, as well as other sundry sportsmen, are taking to the rivers and inlets these days in search of their dinner. Not for shad, which are bony

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Louis A. Johnson, the Secretary of Defense, was feeling better about things than he had for months when he departed Friday night to spend the week-end at his home in Clarksburg, W.Va.

Gen. William H. Harrison was granted yesterday a leave of absence from his duties as president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation by its board of directors to enable him to devote full time to his new duties as administrator of the National Production Authority in Washington.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 13 A strong recommendation that the Department of Agriculture drop its farm price support program was made today by Dr. O.B. Jesness, chief of the Division of Agricultural Economics at the University of Minnesota. He spoke to officials from the Department of Agriculture, business men and agriculturalists in the Minnesota Club here.

PARIS, Sept. 13 The Schuman plan negotiators have run into a major snag the wide differences in costs of production that make it difficult to create at once a single market for coal and steel within the nations that would merge those basic industries. This single market is one of the first aims of the plan.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 13 (AP) Mrs. William W. Vaughan's Briar White won his first stakes race in the Homebred Handicap at Atlantic City today before a crowd of 8,994. The son of Neddie, bred by his Red Bank (N.J.) owner, registered by 3 lengths in the onemile test for New Jersey-bred racers.

A note of moderate optimism on the outlook for peace in Europe was sounded here yesterday by Foreign Minister Dirk U. Stikker of the Netherlands, who arrived for the meeting of the North Atlantic Council opening in this city tomorrow.
The Western Big Three foreign ministers reached agreement in principle yesterday on a marked increase in the size of the Federal police to be allowed for Western Germany Whether such

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 13.--A new combination of chemical analysis at the submicroscopic level with genetic breeding experiments is leading to a further explanation of the puzzling mechanism by which genes reproduce themselves, speakers reported at the American Institute of Biological Sciences meeting at Ohio State University here today.

In a purchase for investment and partial occupancy, the twelve-story loft building at 138-44 West Twenty-fifth Street has been bought by a client of Adams Co. Real Estate, Inc., broker, from the B.C.L.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 Credit curbs and shortages of such materials as lumber, copper, zinc, iren and steel, will case a cutback of 400,000 in the number of single dwelling units built next year, according to estimates compiled by the National Production Authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The Senate Foreign Affairs Committee voted approval today of the nomination of William O'Dwyer, former Mayor of New York, as Ambassador to Mexico. The ballot was 8 0, with one member, Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, voting present.

Edward Corsi, Republican candidate for Mayor, indicated yesterday at his first press conference since his nomination that stress on civilian defense measures, including plans for evacuating the city, would figure in the joint state and city campaign plans now being laid by the Republicans.

Substantial long-term subsidies in the form of tax exemption and revenue from a vast number of parking meters are considered essential to the economic feasibility of any municipal off-street parking program.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13--Grain markets developed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today largely owing to a more favorable view of the war situation in the Far East. Wheat dropped around 2 cents at one time and finished 1/8 to 1 cents lower. Short covering in this and other grains brought a rally from the low of the day.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 13 William S. Donahue of Suburban shot a four-over-par 40, 35 75 in pouring rain today and became the favorite to win the twenty-ninth annual New Jersey State Senior Golf Association tourney at the Essex Fells Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 6:

The nineteenth century was...

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 13 (AP)--Mrs. Robert Cramer's Tattenham scored a surprising half-length victory in today's New Haven purse at Narragansett Park. Tattenham, virtually overlooked in the betting, paid $55.40 for $2 after running the six furlongs in 1:12 2/5 on the slow track.
SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 13 (AP) The Governments of Australia, South Africa and New Zealand propose to set up a fund to support wool prices at a stated minimum.
Reserve Officers Training Corps units in thirty-three Eastern colleges and universities will be increased up to 72 per cent this year to help meet the new quota announced recently by the Army.

OTTAWA, Sept. 13 For the present, Canada's contribution to the joint strength of the North Atlantic Nations in Europe will be confined to providing arms and equipment, Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent told the House of Commons today.

"Sierra," a Universal-International Western with music with Wanda Hendrix and Audie Murphy, which arrives at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Alfred E. Green directed and Michel Kraike produced from a screen play by Edna Anhalt with additional dialogue by Milton Gunzberg and a novel by Stuart Hardy. Burl Ives, Dean Jagger,

Prices for crude rubber continued to fluctuate widely on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Following sharp declines of as much as 150 points on Tuesday, the market reversed itself and advanced the daily permissible limit of 200 points, or 2 cents a pound. Transactions totaled 770 long tons.

A home run that met the minimum major league specifications for a four-base blow by a matter of inches yesterday cost the amazing Sal Maglie two more possible listings in baseball's record books, although the curve-ball artist of the Giants beat the Pirates, 3 1, for his eleventh straight completegame victory in a rain-drenched contest, called at the end of seven innings.

After a chronic Cabinet crisis that has plagued it ever since the inconclusive election of March 5, Greece has again a Government with a chance of some durability. It is headed by a triumvirate of the country's three principal political leaders; with Sophocles Venizelos, Liberal, as Premier, and Constantin Tsaldaris, royalist Populist,

The 1501 Broadway Corporation, wholly owned subsidiary of Paramount Pictures Corporation, has obtained a loan of $9,000,000 from the Prudential Insurance Company. The loan consists of a mortgage of $7,000,000 on the Paramount Building at 1501 Broadway and a $2,000,000 note guaranteed by Paramount Pictures Corporation.

Reversing the previous trend, the nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 818,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they were 106,381,000 barrels, compared with 105,563,000 a week earlier and 104,375,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) A beer-for-the-boys-in-Korea controversy foamed up on Capitol Hill today.

In an election conducted by the National Labor Relations Board, the results of which were announced here today, Hollywood scenarists have voted by a large majority in favor of having the Screen Writers Guild continue to represent them in collective bargaining with the film studios.

The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday the completion of arrangements to obtain 7,000 new freight cars, estimated to cost about $36,500,000. Of these 5,000 will be purchased from various builders and the remaining 2,000 obtained under lease.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--A widely expected quick agreement between Senate and House managers on the final draft of legislation to force the registration of Communists as soon as possible and internment of suspected subversives during a major crisis failed to develop tonight.

The Madigan-Hyland engineering report to the city's Public Works Department certainly does not minimize the financial and other difficulties that stand in the way of any substantial city program for providing public offstreet parking facilities.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 14 (UP)-- The fighting in Korea swung the doors wide open to German exports in a world heavily engaged in rearming, a Government report shows.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered Eastern railroads today to establish joint rail-water class and commodity rates with the Pan-Atlantic Steamship Company on traffic movinb from the North Atlantic Seaboard to New Orleans.

Population increases east of Freeport have caused the Long Island Rail Road to increase frequency of service on the Montauk Branch between Freeport and Babylon and to lessen frequency of service for Freeport and stations west. These changes are to be effective at 3:01 A.M. on Sunday...
Decisions taken here by the Western Big Three foreign ministers will soon enable Western Germany to move far and fast toward a more normal place in the world's family of nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--The Senate passed unanimously tonight an urgent and supplemental appropriation bill of $17,192,000,000. Nine dollars of every ten in it would go to strengthening the defense of the United States and its associates of the western world.

Election of Deputy Mayor William Reid of New York as president of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company was announced yesterday after a meeting of directors. He succeeds, effective Oct. 1, Morris Cohon, who was elevated to chairman of the board.

Noel Coward was the guest of honor at yesterday's luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk, a group of reporters covering the stage beat, at Rosoff's Restaurant. Discussing all aspects of the London-New York theatre, he captivated those present with his trigger-like humor as was to be expected.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14--Grain markets were irregular on the Board of Trade today with considerable evening up for a Canadian crop estimate due after the markets closed. Mills were, aggressive buyers of wheat with the close to 1 cents higher.

MALDEN, Mass., Sept. 14--The marriage of Miss Jane Dysart Carpenter, daughter of Edwin King Carpenter and the late Mrs. Carpenter, to John Moors Bradley, son of. Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Bradley of Boston, took place here this afternoon in the First Congregational Church.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--The shortage of social case workers trained to work in a medical setting is acute and the demand probably will continue to grow, the Women's Bureau, Department of Labor, reported today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 14--Tom Robbins of Winged Foot carded a two-over-par 38, 34--72 today to go with a first-round 74 for a 36-hole total of 146, that gave him his third straight Westchester Seniors Golf Association title.

BOSTON, Sept. 14--The United States sold Out in China and gave Russia the green light for aggression, Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, charged today as he warned that the Korean conflict is "but the first of that will become many armed attacks."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--A small band of Republican Senators gathered today in opposition to the bill to waive existing law and permit General of the Army George C. Marshall, a professional soldier, to serve as Secretary of Defense.

A vacant plot of land with tennis courts at the northwest corner of Woodside Avenue and Barnett Street in Woodside, Queens, has been sold by the Pennsylvania Tunnel and Terminal Railroad Company to the Carlern Holding Company, represented by Jacob Mishler.
The events of the past years have unveiled to the entire world to an ever greater extent the aggressive and unpeaceful character of communism.

WASHINGTON, sept. 14--The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized the Southern Company of Wilmington, Del., to borrow $12,000,000 from banks on its one-year, 2 per cent unsecured notes. The company will invest $6,000,000 each in the purchase of...

Thirty per cent of the men who reported for pre-induction examinations Wednesday were rejected for physical or mental reasons, it was announced yesterday at Army recruiting offices, 39 Whitehall Street. This compared with a recent average of 40 per cent, and 60 per cent a month ago.

BERLIN, Sept. 14--The Commandants of the three Western sectors of Berlin moved simultaneously today to establish a basis for coping vigorously with a flood of Communist propaganda that has stirred up continual disorders.

OTTAWA, Sept. 14 (Canadian Press)--A severe bout of prairie, frost, along with snow, wind and rainstorms, has knocked the skids from under Canada's expectations of reaping one of the biggest wheat crops in history.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14-- Further flouting of traffic regulations will result in "tough" driver controls, motorists were warned today by Clifford J. Fletcher, Commissioner of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, New York.

The applications of three private bus companies in Queens for leave to charge a ten-cent fare were referred yesterday by the Board of Estimate to the special committee on buses set up by former Mayor William O'Dwyer.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 14--Joseph E. Moody, president of the Southern Coal Producers Association, today urged the nation's oil executives to profit from the experience of the coal industry and avoid industry-wide bargaining.

The Queens County Jockey Club put up $10,000 for the Glendale steeplechase at Aqueduct yesterday. It didn't get its money's worth. Because of the soft going, only four of the nine entrants went to the post, and they provided hardly a reasonable facsimile of a contest.

The Non-Partisan Committee of the New York State Federation of Labor voted unanimously yesterday to endorse United States Senafor Herbert H. Lehman for reelection and by a vote of nine to five, with three members abstaining, endorsed the Democratic-Liberal state ticket, headed by Representative Walter A. Lynch, as the candidate for Governor.

It is not, at this time, the aim of the new powers-that-be in the New York-University athletic set-up to return the Violets to the headline heights of the Chick Meehan era. Somewhat guardedly, perhaps, and with reservations, this was disclosed by James V. Gillon Jr., recently....

Merger of Lawyers Trust Company with Bankers Trust Company was approved by stockholders of both institutions at separate meetings yesterday. The merger will become effective at the start of business on Monday morning when the four offices of Lawyers Trust Company will begin operating as branches of Bankers Trust Company.

The foreign ministers and diplomatic spokesmen from the twelve member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty organizations will open today their second annual meeting devoted to the mobilization of military forces for the defense of Western Europe.
LONDON, Sept. 14 (Reuters)-- A memorial service for Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts will be held in Westminster Abbey at noon on Tuesday, Prime Minister Attlee announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14-- Frank T. Bow, an assistant to Senator Andrew F. Schoeppel, Republican of Kansas, declared today that he would state publicly, without benefit of any Congressional immunity, that there existed items of evidence "which show conclusively strong and close personal alliance between the Soviet Russian cause and the present Secretary of the Interior," Oscar L. Chapman.

NEWARK, Sept. 14--An increase from 5 to 8 cents in the basic bus and trolley fare was applied for today by the Public Service Coordinated Transport and the Public Service Interstate Transportation Company.

A restatement of American democratic ideals to offset the menace of Russian aggression, especially by appealing to the colored peoples of Africa and Asia, was called for yesterday by the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, A.F.L.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 14--There is no reason to doubt that the Republican "Regulars" in Congress hoped that their fellow-partisans in New Hampshire would relieve them of the future presence of Senator Tobey.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Sept. 14-- Miss Barbara Bruising, 18-year-old Whippoorwill ace, posted a 78 to win low gross honors at the weekly Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association's one-day medal play competition today. All told, thirtytwo braved the discouraging out-look...

SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Sept. 14--Americans with other United Nations forces have accomplished a military miracle in Korea, holding the present perimeter, inflicting casualties at the rate of five to one, destroying the enemy's best troops and setting the stage for an eventual counter-offensive to end the existing stalemate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--Department store sales for the week ended Sept. 9 were 8 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.
