IN the northeasternmost corner of India near the Burmese border live the Nagas, wild Mongolian tribesmen, "tremendous, riproaring savages, men who had taken heads but danced like Nijinsky." Ursula Graham Bower first saw them in 1937 when she was 23.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 4--The Hi-Rock Farm's 5-year-old gray mare Circus Rose, with Joe Green riding, was the victor in a jump-off for top honors in the first division of the William S. Blitz Memorial Trophy competition as the forty-fifth annual Piping Rock Horse Show opened today.
De Pinna presented a showing of chic town fashions, smartly accessoried, at the Plaza Hotel yesterday noon. All the costumes were made by Ben Reig, Inc.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14--Miss Carrie Horn Derby was married today to Ralph Webb Gardner at the Beverly Hills home of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Pauley. The bride, for six years an executive assistant to Mr. Pauley, former United States reparation emissary, is the...

TOKYO, Sept. 14--Far East Air Forces headquarters here announced that the second stage of its "interdiction" bombing program was now complete. The announcement said an intense ten-day attack on North Korean roads and rail installations had brought military traffic to a "virtual" standstill.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP)--The Chicago White Sox scored five times in the first inning to whip the Philadelphia Athletics, 5--2, today in the opener of a threegame series. Luke Appling played his 2,207th American League game at shortstop.
The two largest garment unions in the United States announced yesterday that they would seek an immediate, country-wide general wage increase of 15 per cent for their thousands of members.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--President Truman today signed a measure establishing the new Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming.

Foreign Minister Robert Schuman of France and Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin of Britain agreed yesterday to ask their governments for instructions regarding a Western Big Three discussion of the rearmament of Western Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)-- The electrical workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations asked the Federal Trade Commission today to issue a complaint against the General Electric Corporation for what the union called "false, misleading and deceptive statements" in newspaper advertisements.

Sixteen women and six men required medical attention yesterday morning when a spectacular but comparatively minor mishap spread panic among passengers on an IND subway train as it was entering the Second Avenue station. Most of the men were cut by windows broken in passengers' frantic efforts to escape from the stalled train. No serious injuries were reported.

One of the largest suppliers of private brand television receivers in the metropolitan area notified a large number of retail accounts yesterday that private brand manufacturing was being terminated. The move is expected to touch off a wide curtailment in the production of private brands.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 14 (AP)-- Major league baseball today completed all the preliminary arrangements and set the dates for the 1950 world series--if--there are no ties in either pennant race.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closed 18 to 47 points higher than on Wednesday.

Frequent meetings are being held by the various committees planning a dinner-dance for the benefit of the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue Hospital, to be given on Oct. 5 in the Rendez-Vous Room of the Plaza. Mrs. William S. Kilborme is chairman and Mrs. Warren Lee Pierson, vice...
BRIDGEPORT, Sept. 14--A program of sex education for parents, teachers and other adults will begin next month under the sponsorship of the Board of Education.
Mrs. Walter S. McNab of Schenectady was named yesterday as Republican state campaign cochairman.

SAN SALVADOR, Sept. 14--El Salvador's new President, Lieut. Col. Oscar Osorio, swore to defend and obey the new Constitution before 40,000 fellow citizens at 10:30 A.M. here today in the national stadium.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 14--In a joint declaration the non-communist members of the Bundestag appealed to the United Nations today to condemn the "criminal" activities of the Soviet Union in Germany.

BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP)--Long John Sain became the third-place Boston Braves third nineteen-game pitching winner by scattering ten hits, including three home runs, while topping the Chicago Cubs, 7--4, today, before a crowd of 1,489, one of the smallest in this city's long baseball history.
Miss Dorothy C. Kahn, one of the leaders of the social work profession in this country, after five years' service has resigned as executive director of the Welfare Council of New York City.
LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 14-- Uruguay today offered $2,000,000 to the United Nations Unified Command to be spent for supplies needed in Korea.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 14-- Probably the wet weather that forced him to bring the squad back from the Blairstown camp two days ahead of schedule had something to do with it; but Coach Charley Caldwell was a bit gloomy today about his Princeton football team's prospects.

Jay E. Greene, a 36-year-old war veteran who has been a member of the city's school system for twelve years, was appointed yesterday a member of the Board of Examiners, the civil service body that passes on the qualifications of candidates for all teaching and most supervisory positions in the public schools.
Elizabeth Arden's strong insistence on femininity was eloquently expressed yesterday in her fall custom order collection at 691 Fifth Avenue in romantically beautiful evening gowns.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 14-- Probate Judge Robert K. Watson ruled here today that Dr. Donald F. Gibson had exercized "no undue influence" on the late Miss Elizabeth M. Ayres, 74-year-old Danbury spinster, and admitted to probate a will in which she left her $65,000 estate to the physician.

The first full-scale amphibious operation in the Korean fighting was the landing of the famous United States First Cavalry Division on July 18 at Pohang, a strategic seaport on the east coast north of Pusan. This landing was not on the enemy-held coast and was not opposed. It was, however, the first operation of its kind since World War II.
"You'd be surprised to see how many Republicans have signed my petitions for Impellitteri," Mrs. Florita Rogovoy reported yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14-- The collision that sank the Navy hospital ship Benevolence outside the Golden Gate on Aug. 25 took place, according to testimony today, after the Benevolence engine room had received a stop-engine order and while it was answering an ensuing go-ahead two-thirds order.

Shoppers prefer prepackaged meat to such an extent that when stores install self-Service counters, sales of meat increase 30 to 50 per cent. Thomas A. Donahue, meat sales manager of the H.C. Bohack Company, gave this information to food editors in the course of a tour...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14-- Danielle Darrieux, French film actress, has been signed by MetroGoldwyn-Mayer for one of the principal roles in "Welcome to Paris," which will star Jane Powell and introduce Vic Damone to film audiences.
Park Row, 105, 16.7x99; Lawyers Trust Co. to 5010 Realty Corp, 292 Madison Ave. ($60.50). Same property, 5010 Realty Corp. (Irving Meister, pres) to Irving Meister, 425 E 72d St. et al.
Paddy Young, Greenwich Village middleweight, and Ernie Durando of Bayonne, N.J., will meet in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14-- The discovery that tritium, one of the basic ingredients of the hydrogen bomb, is being produced constantly in the upper atmosphere by cosmic rays bombarding the earth from outer space was announced here today at the Research Institute of Temple University.

ED SONGIN of Boston College was offered $50,000 to sign a three-year contract with the Football Yankees; Bob Celeri of South ern California was hailed by many Coast experts as a better T-formation magician than the fabulous Eddie LeBaron and Herman Wedemeyer of St. Mary's had both the National Football League and the All-America Conference scrambling frantically to enlist his services. That was one brief year ago.

In January 1950, the Chief of Staff of the Korean Army informed the committee that he believed the aggressive plans of the North Korean authorities to be mature, and that it was only a matter of time before they would be put into action.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--The State Department is studying an extensive economic aid program for South Asia and the Middle East that would provide from $250,000,000 to $300,000,000 in assistance each year for four or five years.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 (AP)-- Willie Jones poked a ninth-inning single through the middle of the diamond tonight, scoring Eddie Waitkus from third base to give the league leading Philadelphia Phillies a 3-2 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals.

The fact that the negotiators of a treaty to formulate the Schuman coalsteel plan are having their technical difficulties is understandable. It is more important that there has been much hard, fruitful work in the last three months.

The group shows of paintings and sculpture that traditionally open New York's art season usually look in two directions--to the established artists of a gallery and to those whom a gallery is about to launch.
NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Sept. 14--Parents in the Hudson Heights section here began today a boycott of the fifty-three-year-old Ulysses S. Grant Public School.

From suits to crinolines, Hattie Carnegie's fall and winter collection, which made its 1951 debut yesterday, revealed the wide swing of the style pendulum. The suits were exquisite in their understatement, reflecting the feeling for the slender silhouette.

LONDON, Sept. 14--The British Conservatives precipitated a Parliamentary crisis today by calling for a vote of censure after an announcement by the Labor Government that it intended to implement its authority to nationalize the country's steel industry.

For the first time in three days, weather conditions in Korea permitted aircraft of the United States Far East Air Forces to operate on a larger scale. Almost doubling the previous days total, 420 sorties were flown Thursday.

The site of the old Moore homestead in Elmhurst, Queens, where, according to some authorities, Dr. Clement Clarke Moore wrote "A Visit from St. Nicholas," was ordered sold yesterday by the Board of Estimate.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14--What happened tonight at Sportsman's Park was a pretty good illustration of how the mighty can sometimes fall.

The naming of General Marshall to the post of Defense Secretary has already touched off the beginning of what will doubtless be a long and perhaps acrimonious debate about his role in China. It is therefore wise and just that this role and the events that surrounded it be placed in their proper historical light and that they be recorded and remembered accurately.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--The House went on record today, 331 to 2, as favoring action this session on an excess profits tax that would be retroactive to July 1, or Oct. 1.

Commodity futures on the local markets yesterday were generally firm with tin, sugar, cocoa, wool, wool tops, rubber and cottonseed oil advancing, while minor losses were registered by lead and hides.
PARIS, Sept. 14--The Radical party, which was the leading group is the French Parliament for most of the period between the two World Wars, met in its annual congress at Deauville today.

Plans are being completed for The Ribbon Cabaret, a dinner dance to be held Oct. 3 in the Carnaval and Chanteclair Rooms of the Sherry-Netherland under the auspices of the Burlington Mills for the benefit of the Soldiers', Sailors' and Airmen's Club of New York.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 14--The Government's security and loyalty programs are unintentionally retarding scientific progress and endangering American leadership in the field, according to a 90,000word report to be published tomorrow on the impact of governmental security practices on civil liberties.

At this moment "The Amazing Adele," starring Ruth Gordon, looms as a Broadway prospect for the week after next. The authority for this forecast is none other than Garson Kanin, adaptor-director, who also will present the French farce by arrangement with Albert de Courville.

DETROIT, Sept. 14--Vic Raschi became the second pitcher in the American League today to post his twentieth mound victory as the Yankees tripped the Tigers, 7 to 5, to move back into first place by half a length. But there is no getting away from the fact that both Big Vic and the Bombers made it the hard way.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--Former Representative Andrew Jackson May, Democrat of Kentucky, convicted in July, 1947, of accepting a bribe and conspiring in connection with munitions contracts of World War II, has received a parole and will be released Monday from the Federal Correctional Institution at Ashland, Ky., Dr. George C. Killinger, chairman of the Federal Parole Board, said today.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 15--United Nations invasion forces landed today at Inchon, the port city for Seoul on Korea's west coast--150 miles behind the 130,000-man North Korean Army at the fighting front.
LONDON, Sept. 14--A unified military command for the whole North Atlantic Treaty area was forecast tonight by British Defense Minister Emanuel Shinwell.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14--A report that Republicans were certain of unseating at least six Democrats in the Senate and thirty-one in the House sent hopes for victory in November soaring today at the opening of a two-day Midwest Republican conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--The Treasury admitted today that it got only an 81 per cent response to its offer to exchange $7,321,892,200 thirteen-month certificates bearing 1 per cent interest for a like amount of securities maturing tomorrow. Ordinarily, the acceptances by holders of maturing obligations averages around 94 per cent.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 14--Eugene Roberts, founder and president of the Western States Machine Company of Hamilton, Ohio, manufacturers of sugarprocessing equipment, died here today at his home on 22 Overlook Road after a long illness. His age was 72.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept, 14-- Cortisone and ACTH may be effective against hardening of the arteries because they facilitate the storage of Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) in the blood and the adrenal glands, experiments reported at the opening of the American Physiological Society's summer meeting at Ohio State University here today indicated.

The Port Authority approved yesterday the immediate construction of a new passenger terminal at the Newark Airport to cost $8,047,470. The new terminal is expected to be completed by the end of next year or early in 1952 and will be five times the size of the present terminal.
An investigation into charges that the Police Department does not "properly report crimes that have occurred in this city," was ordered yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

MIDLAND PARK, N.J., Sept. 14--John Wenzel, statistical research consultant, who was well known as a genealogist, died yesterday at Hackensack Hospital of injuries received in a fall several days ago. He was a resident of this town. His age was 80.
SIZE, to the average angler, is a matter of relativity, which may account for the fact that the man who takes a 30-pound muskie is just as excited as the man who boats a 700-pound tuna.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 14-- Persons who work near jet test operations become "irritable and inefficient," a safety expert said today at the closing session of the Conference on Ground Facilities for Air Transportation, sponsored by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Hope that the crew of the illfated fishing dragger Theresa A might still be safe was held out last night after a Coast Guard plane reported sighting two dories lashed together ninety-five miles south of the last radioed position of the vessel.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 14--Selection of a jury to try Jacob Kiefer, Long Island Rail Road motorman, on a manslaughter charge was completed in Nassau County Court here today.

Jerome Bloom, 52-year-old Post Office clerk, has been combining business with business, the Government charged yesterday. Not only has he been selling stamps, it was declared, but over the same counter he has sold "hundreds" of Irish sweepstake tickets.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 14--The United Nations Commission on Korea reported today that six weeks before the start of the war United States officers denied South Korean warnings that invasion from the north was imminent.

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Sept. 14--At least three Brazilian parties have already been embarrassed by the fact that the Communists, under a political form of protective coloration, have wangled nominations on the parties' tickets for the national election on Oct. 3.

The Brass Rail will open a branch restaurant in the recently completed thirty-six-story building at 100 Park Avenue, where it has leased street floor and basement space. The lease, involving a total rental of nearly $2,000,000, was negotiated by Cushman Wakefield, Inc., renting agents for the building.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Sept. 14--Arthur Stringer, poet, playwright and novelist, died here this afternoon in his home on Laurel Hill Road after a long illness. He was 76 years old.
Governor Dewey completed here yesterday a series of conferences at which the strategy of his campaign for a third term as Governor was mapped.
Negotiators representing employing stevedores yesterday rejected wage increase demands of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F.L.

The 1010 Lexington Avenue Corporation, a subsidiary of the City Investing Company, has sold the fourteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 125-39 East Seventy-second Street, northwest corner of Lexington Avenue, through the Charles F. Noyes Company, brokers.

ALBANY, Sept. 14--Maj. Gen. Edward Murphy Markham, U.S. A., retired, former Chief of the Army Engineers and a former New York City Commissioner of Public Works, died today in Albany Hospital, where he had been a patient for two weeks. He was 73 years old.

Frank P. Casey, vice president of the National Surety Corporation and the National Surety Marine Corporation, 4 Albany Street, died Wednesday night in the Hospital for Joint Diseases, after he had suffered a heart attack while attending a motion picture in the Strand Theatre. He was 52 years old.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Sept. 14 --Mr. and Mrs. Charles Inness Brown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mabel Inness, to Henry Christopher Wallich, son of Mrs. Paul Wallich of New York and the late Mr. Wallick. The wedding has been planned for December.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Sept. 9 totaled 751,276 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 101,045 cars or 11.9 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 127,314 cars or 20.4 per cent...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--This country's manpower potential is so limited that industries producing strictly for civilians might have to give up 6,600,000--about a fourth --of their workers in an emergency comparable to World War II.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--Herbert A. Bergson, Assistant Attorney General in charge of anti-trust law prosecutions for the Department of Justice, has resigned, effective Sept. 30, the White House announced today.
Ainsworth Manufacturing Corporation and subsidiary--Six months to June 30: Net profit $324,504, equal to 78c a share, compared with $248,224 or 60c a share last year.

Price advances on Chinese embroidered handkerchiefs retailing under $1 are due when the higher rates of duty go into effect in the near future as a result of the withdrawal of tariff concessions to China.
ROME, Sept. 14--Security measures held necessary because of the international situation between the Western powers and the Soviet union were discussed here today.

The Rev. Dr. Athenagoras T. Mr. Dodger Pennant, while still not out of danger, had a much stronger pulse today after having taken quite a lot of nourishment yesterday in the Ebbets Field sanitarium.

Fourteen municipal housing authorities of Massachusetts sold yesterday $10,109,000 of stateguaranteed housing bonds maturing serially over forty years at interest costs slightly under the coupon of 1 per cent designated for all the bonds.

United Nations forces have struck in strength against the North Koreans with landings on both coasts behind the enemy's lines. A major amphibious blow was at Inchon, the port of Seoul, where United States and British warships had shelled the area Wednesday.

The Western Big Three foreign ministers were not able to agree at the Waldorf-Astoria this week about rearming the West Germans, but at least they did not decide to create a West Germany Army and call it a police force.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 14-- The human race stands at a perilous point in the pathway of evolution, Dr. Julian Huxley warned here tonight at the concluding session of the "Golden Jubilee" conference of the Genetics Society of America.
LONDON, Sept. 14--The Government's decision to go ahead with nationalizing of the iron and steel industry introduced a new note of uncertainty into the stock markets today.

Neville Sheldon Cumberbatch, 26-year-old substitute postal clerk, who had admitted that he had stolen from 400 to 500 letters since he became a Federal employe fourteen months ago, was held in $3,000 bail yesterday when arraigned before Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn Federal Court.

PARIS, Sept. 14--Annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction Development closed here today on a note of pessimism about the short run world monetary outlook.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14--President Truman announced today that he had directed the State Department to begin a new effort to obtain a Japanese peace treaty. Behind the move was this country's resolve to produce a peace agreement, with or without Soviet participation.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14--The steel industry of the United States is busy rushing plans for further expansion to keep pace with the nation's military and civilian steel needs, Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, disclosed here tonight.
Saks 34th Street gave a luncheon show yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, presenting daytime, cocktail and evening dresses and ensembles, ranging from $40 to $100.

ALBANY, Sept. 14--The field study on which the 1951 Legislature will base revisions in New York's rent control law is more than three-quarters completed, State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick told the New York State Association of Magistrates today.

WASHINGTON, sept. 14--During the week ended Sept. 13 member bank reserve balances Increased $254,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The bizarre success of William R. MacLeod, self-styled "doctor," in obtaining hospital posts, was attributed yesterday to the excellence of his faked credentials and to the war-born shortage of internes.

The end of water holidays "until further notice" was ordered yesterday by Stephen J. Carney, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity. He added that he did not expect their resumption unless the situation again became critical.

Somewhat to the consternation of passersby, some fire apparatus yesterday began making wider use of a "buckeye whistle," which emits a high, shrill noise not unlike that of a siren. A ban against the use of sirens, except as air raid signals, took effect on Monday.

The second game score was 6-1.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 14 --Lloyd G. Beatty of Glen Ridge and William Donahue of Suburban failed today to overcome Martin S. Lindgrove's leading 157 in the final session of the New Jersey State three-day senior golf tournament at the Essex Fells Country Club course.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15--Average primary market prices advanced 0.7 per cent in the week ended Sept. 12, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The index was 168.9 per cent of the 1926 average, 2.4 per cent above four weeks ago and 9.2 per cent above the comparable week in 1949.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 19 --While he is somewhat short on reserve strength at present, Maurice (Mickey) Shuman, Peddie School's football coach, has hopes that his outfit this year will go all-out to make amends for the old Gold and Blue's 1949 campaign that brought only two triumphs in seven outings.

Last night the Sadler's Wells Ballet gave us two novelties at the Metropolitan Opera House. One was its first "Giselle" here with Margot Fonteyn in the title role, and the other was its first presentation for us of Frederick Ashton's "Les Patineurs."

DETROIT, Sept. 19 (AP)--King Kong Charlie Keller and Pat Mullin, a pair of "retreads," went on a terrific hitting spree today as the Tigers routed the Athletics, 12--4, to move back into a tie with the idle Red Sox for second place in the American League.

ROME, Sept. 19--Security measures required to fight the Communist fifth column in the event of war or internal upheaval figure among the most urgent problems that the Cabinet will take up when it begins meeting again tomorrow after the long summer interruption.

PARIS, Sept. 19--The European Payments Union convention, accepted in June after six months of difficult negotiation, was finally signed here today by representatives of the eighteen Marshall Plan governments. It has been in tentative operation since June 30.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept, 20-- Jacob Kiefer, motorman, could not explain immediately after the Long Island Rail Road wreck that killed or injured 109 passengers in Rockville Centre last Feb. 17 why he had passed a stop signal and disregarded a warning buzzer in his cab.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20-- John Houseman, New York and Hollywood producer-director, and T. EXETER, N.H., Sept. 20--After a dismal football season in 1949-- one that lived up to the coaching staff's pre-season's expectations-- things appear to be picking up at Phillips Exeter Academy. At least that is the general opinion here as the Red and White prepares for a tough seven-game schedule.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 20--West German public opinion, as reflected in a Federal Government statement and editorial comment in the press today, poured warm praise on the decision of the Western Big Three foreign ministers to relax occupation controls and to seek to end the official state of war.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP)-- A new motion picture camera described the world's fastest was unveiled today at the Fifth National Instrument Conference. LONDON, Sept. 20--It can be taken almost as a certainty that there will be no general election in Britain this year. Having weathered the latest Opposition attack, the Labor Government is confident that it can continue in office until next spring. It intends to do so.

Production of vegetables is running 10 per cent above 1949, 8 per cent above average. Television reached a new low in taste last night. It came on the "Truth or Consequences" program, which inexcusably exploited a mother's understandable shock when she unexpectedly saw her son, a Korean combat casualty, on the stage of the Ralph Edwards program over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

LONDON, Sept. 21--The recent upsurge in wool prices in the dominions was fully confirmed today at the first London auctions of the 1950-51 season. Current values in fact were raised by 5 to 7 per cent and established a general level 50 per cent higher than was reached here in July.

Some large home furnishings retailers are being forced to lease additional warehouse space for unfavorably long periods at rentals so high that they cut into operating profit margins. This was revealed yesterday by an executive of a well-known outlet.

The New York City Opera Company, which has made a place and an audience for itself in this town, was back in business last night at the City Center for another fall season. It opened the new eightweek semester with its production of Puccini's "Turandot," which it revived last spring, and the faithful were on hand to welcome the company back.

BOMBAY, India, Sept. 21 (AP)-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru threatened to quit his job today unless his All-India Congress party voted full endorsement of his policies. The party promptly gave him that endorsement, by an overwhelming vote.

The last of Sal Maglie's streaks was snapped yesterday when the Giants bowed to the Reds for the third straight time, 8--, before 3,996 onlookers at the Polo Grounds. Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman, is making plans for 60,000 volunteers to visit 700,000 contributors.

WASHINGTON Sept. 24--The week-end departure of Congress left political Washington in a poststorm calm today. But tomorrow the Administration will find on its doorstep a far-reaching and complicated Communist-control law it had stated it did not need and did not want.

Cooking is serious business but fun, too, in "Sugar An' Spice and All Things Nice," a recipe booklet by Mrs. Julia Kiene, director of the Westinghouse Home Economics Institute. He beat out Ed (Porky) Oliver of Seattle, Wash., and Jack Burke Jr. of White Plains, N.Y., by a single stroke.

The weatherbeaten little cutter Ituna, after a crossing beset by heavy seas and strong northeast headwinds, sailed into New York harbor yesterday morning, completing a voyage that began at Rosslare, Ireland, on June 14.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 24-- It's a shame that the best man on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club today wasn't on the winning side. Fred Allen made his debut on television last night. Score 100 per cent for Mr. A. per se; score a good deal less, however, for other parts of his first show on N.B.C.

The recently awakened New York art season leads off this week with several one-man and group shows, one of which, opening tomorrow and devoted to new paintings and sculpture by Americans, celebrates the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Downtown Gallery.

The American Bankers Association, assembling here yesterday for its seventy-fifth annual convention, will remain aloof from the controversy over interest rates now raging between the Federal Reserve System and the United States Treasury.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 24--Stock prices suffered a rather heavy setback in the past week losing up to twelve points. The causes were mainly technical, namely: That the market was ripe for some reaction but especially because foreign arbitrage selling of Royal Dutch depressed the markets.

The attempt of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to evict thirty-five tenants from Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, its East Side housing developments, will be fought in the courts, a spokesman for the tenants said yesterday.

Activity in most wholesale markets here last week was concentrated on placing of orders for holiday requirements, special orders and fill-ins. There was a continued reduction in activity in almost all divisions of the staples markets as prices continued to rise and tight deliveries prevailed.

During World War I, American doughboys went slogging along the roads of France having learned to sing, "It's a Long, Long Way to Tipperary." Frederick Ashton's "Dante Sonata," which had its local premiere Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is the first completely unfamiliar work which the Sadler's Wells Ballet has given us this season.

BOSTON, Sept. 24--Jim Hearn, the year's best bargain-buy, and a young man whose 1951 bank deposits are certain to be higher than ever before, pitched the Giants to an easy 12-4 victory over the Braves today. VIENNA, Sept. 26--The Austrian Cabinet decided today to permit this country's cost of living to rise to an approximation of the world level and to compensate for this by a 10 to 14 per cent increase in wages.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--The California Electric Power Company of Riverside filed a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission today for $4,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 2 7/8 per cent series due in 1980.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)-- The Navy expects to call up more than 15,000 line and specialist officers as it continues its build-up at sea, in the air and ashore.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 26-- Jacob Kiefer, Long Island Rail Road motorman, was found not guilty here tonight of causing the train wreck that killed thirty-two and injured more than 100 passengers in Rockville Centre last Feb. 17.

Campaign headquarters for Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Mayor, were opened yesterday in the Commodore Hotel on an informal basis. A formal opening is scheduled for Friday.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 --(AP)--The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation, averaging a daily output of 1,200 cars, is back in the earnings column.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 26--Yugoslav Ambassador Vladimir Popovitch departed today for Washington to make a pressing appeal to the United States Government for desperately needed financial assistance.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP)--Detroit's pennant hopes all but flew out of Briggs Stadium as the surprising Browns held the Tigers even in today's double-header.
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and its subsidiary companies, in an unaudited report for the six months ended with July, issued yesterday by Bernard F. Gimbel, president, disclosed net sales at $127,964,813.
Directors of the Link Belt Company declared an extra dividend of $1 in addition to the regular quarterly of $1 on the common stock and proposed a two-for-one stock split.

A Navy reactivating crew swarmed like dungareed Lilliputians over the dreadnought New Jersey at the Naval Annex in Bayonne yesterday, awakening the giant battleship from two years and two months' slumber in the moth-ball fleet.

Among the forty-one persons who donated blood in the Red Cross mobile unit that visited the Bronx County Building yesterday, was a 56-year-old man with records showing that he has given away sixty-five pints of his blood since 1937.
CRESSWELL, England, Sept. 26 (AP)--Eighty coal miners died in a fire deep underground at the Cresswell colliery today and the bodies of many were sealed in the shaft where they had fallen.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 26--Miss Katherine Foster of Westerly, R.I., and Mrs. J. Walker Hoopes of Wilmington, Del., won low gross honors in the Women's United States, senior Scotch foursome tournament with a 6-over-par 39, 40--79 over the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--Failure of a Bolivian pilot to exercise "necessary vigilance" was the probable cause of the airplane crash here last Nov. 1 in which fifty-five persons were killed, the Civil Aeronautics Board reported today.

ON Sept. 7, 1944, Senator Harry S. Truman took his old friend of World War I army days, Edward McKim, to a White House reception. When they left, Mr. McKim, who had spent most of his time staring at President Roosevelt, said, "Hey, bud, turn around and take a look. You're going to be living in that house before long."
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26-- Record floods have converted several hundred square miles of Kashmir valley land, one of the world's famous beauty spots, into a vast lake with only tree tops showing.
"They shall beat their swords into ploughshares and their spears into pruning hooks." --Isaiah dixit.

One of the boldest gambles in modern United States military history--the Inchon invasion--has fully paid off and a large part of the North Korean Army has been cut up and battered and seems to be in the process of dissolution.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26-- With the presentation of "The Lady from Paris," a lavish, Broadway-bound musical, the Erlanger Theatre reopened tonight as a legitimate playhouse for the first time in nearly four years.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 26--The Palestine Conciliation Commission of the United Nations today turned in a complete report of its attempt--and failure--to arrange a settlement of all the questions still in dispute between Israel and the Arab countries.
The time required to process food by freezing soon will be reduced to that needed for the complete processing of regular canned food products, manufacturers predicted here yesterday.

In a transaction involving a total rental of more than $650,000 the Columbia Broadcasting System has leased the building at 403 to 415 East Seventy-sixth Street for use in connection with scenery and other production work in television.
One of the "fairy godmothers" of American community life, Mrs. Henry Ittleson, will be 75 years old today.

The December, 1949, grand jury of the County of kings has justt learned through Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz and District Attorney Miles F. WcDonald that a vacancy is about to occur in the office of Police Commissioner of the City of New York.
The National Maritime Union, C.I.O., asked the Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators yesterday for a wage increase covering 40,000 seamen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--Lewis W. Douglas resigned today as United States Ambassador to Great Britain and a Presidential adviser said that the new envoy would be Walter S. Gifford, former chairman of the board of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 26 (AP)--Lawrence York Spear, chairman of the board of the Electric Boat Company, died today at his home here, after a long illness. He was 79 years old.
BOSTON, Sept. 26--"It's good to be unbeaten this late in the season." said Denny Myers, whose Boston College football team played a 7-7 tie with Wake Forest last week in its inaugural game.

DETROIT, Sept. 26--The Ford Foundation dedicated itself and pledged its assets of nearly a quarter of a billion dollars today to the elimination of war and to the improvement in a peaceful atmosphere of the common lot of man.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26--John Kipper (Spike) Wallace, president of Los Angeles Local 47, American Federation of Musicians, A.F.L., died last night at his home here of a heart ailment. His age was 71.
BERLIN, Sept. 26--A detachment of British soldiers today uprooted a road barrier erected last week by Soviet troops at a disputed sector boundary and dumped it in front of armed Soviet soldiers.

Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink yesterday refused to reduce the $25,000 bail of an alleged police fixer in the Harry Gross bookmaking case and at the same time rebuked former Mayor William O'Dwyer for terming the Brooklyn inquiry a "witch-hunt."
For the first time in its sixteenyear history, "Night of Stars," the annual entertainment which benefits the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, will pay for the talent it employs.

Nestor, passenger traffic manager for the Home Lines.
The board of directors of the Union Settlement have taken over the evening performance of "Daphne Laureola" on Oct. 25 at the Music Box Theatre, as a benefit for that organization.
The Department of Health is in the midst of an intensive crackdown on restaurants whose chefs are violating sanitary principles in the preparation of hollandaise, the "aristocrat" of French sauces.

HONG KONG, Sept. 26--The nationalization of all foreignowned utilities in China within a two-year period is reported to be envisaged in the draft of a new company law now under consideration by the Communist-dominated Peiping regime.

Britain has taken the initiative on the Korean problem in the United Nations with the drafting of a plan to have the General Assembly set up post-war elections in Korea for the establishment of one government for the entire country.

Directors of the American Railway Car Institute yesterday elected Charles W. Wright as president to succeed Samuel M. Felton, who resigned to become president and chief executive officer of Shippers' Car Line Corporation on Oct. 15.

A young Polish-Jewish couple and their 3-year-old son, recently arrived in New York as refugees, were virtually penniless yesterday because the woman had been robbed in a Bronx apartment of their $15,500 life savings by a thief at pistol point.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 26-- Five hundred Jewish athletes from twenty countries are assembling for the Maccabiah games opening here tomorrow. The games, which are sponsored by the Maccabee sport organization, were introduced in 1932 but have not been held since 1935.

From last place in the backstretch to first place at the wire-- that's the way the Wheatley Stable's 3-year-old filly Antagonism, Ted Atkinson up, won the main event at Belmont Park yesterday. Antagonism, $5.50-for-$2 favorite, got the lead in the last four or fine strides of the ninefurlong run and made it by a neck.
A mysterious ailment has taken the lives of ten untamed horses that were to have taken part in the twenty-fifth annual world championship rodeo opening tonight in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--President Truman blamed James F. Byrnes for whittling down the Potsdam agreements and permitting Russia to gain dominance over Rumania, Bulgaria and Hungary, according to Jonathan Daniels in his new book, "The Man of Independence," which will be published tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Economic activity advanced to a new post-war high last month, the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce reported today.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--The fighting Philadelphia Whiz Kids closed in on the National League pennant today by rallying to whip the Braves, 8--7, after Jim Konstanty failed in his record-breaking seventy-first relief chore. Three runs in the eighth off reliefer Bob Hall after two were out did the trick.

Investing departments of the large life insurance companies have under consideration lending up to $100,000,000 to the Iron Ore Company of Canada to help finance extraction of extensive iron ore deposits in Labrador.

Succoth, the Jewish harvest festival, was hailed yesterday in synagogues throughout the city as a symbol of the enduring qualities of a nation's spiritual riches.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 26 (AP)-- United States marine tank crews, leading the battle up Seoul's main street today, fired until they were groggy from fumes in close-quarter combat with the North Korean garrison.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26--Clearer advertising copy--in tune with the everyday language of average people--is an urgent need in sales operations under present conditions, it was emphasized today at the forty-first annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers.

Nearly a million dollars in pledges and contributions have been received during its first year by the C.A.R.E.--Unesco Book Fund, Paul Comly French, executive director of the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe and Asia, announced yesterday.

Striking drivers employed by the Railway Express Agency in the metropolitan area announced yesterday that they had cut their original wage demand in half, but settlement of the four-day-old tieup appeared little closer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--The high level of this country's domestic economy was credited by the Department of Commerce today with enabling foreign nations to add about $640,000,000 to their gold and dollar reserves during the second quarter of this year.
DETROIT, Sept. 27 (AP)--The Tigers found their claws again today as they outfought the Browns, 5-4, to keep their slender pennant hopes alive.

DETROIT, Sept. 27--The Ford Foundation was reported today to have approached thirteen leading universities, including Cornell and Columbia, on the subject of establishing basic research programs in human conduct.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--The White House announced today the appointment of Walter S. Gifford, former chairman of the board of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, as Ambassador to Britain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--Labor's League for Political Education announced today that it planned to distribute widely a "checklist of bad security risks," showing members of Congress who should be defeated on the basis of their voting records.

OTTAWAA, Sept. 27 (Canadian Press)--Trade Minister C.D. Howe today announced an extension of export controls, particularly over metals which could be used in war production, in a move to further block the possible flow of Canadian goods to countries behind the Iron Curtain.

The thundering herd--the Brahma bulls, broncs and steers-- kicked up its annual dust storm last night in Madison Square Garden. The Phillies, having the very deuce of a time wrapping up a pennant generally conceded to them for weeks, yesterday derived their only satisfaction from the scoreboard's news that the Dodgers had Lost the second game of their double-header with the Braves.

Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy ordered twenty-one of his men, some of high rank, some of low, to appear yesterday before the Kings County Grand Jury investigating allegations of widespread police-gambler alliances.

For a few fleeting minutes late yesterday it looked as if the National League pennant pursuit had become a race. The Dodgers had beaten the Braves in the first game at Ebbets Field, 9--6, thanks to a three-run homer off Bob Hogue by Gil Hodges.

The bonds were bought by the bankers at competitive sale Tuesday on a bid of 100.157.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27--A union that negotiates with an association of employers may call a strike against one employer at a time and try to get separate contracts without violating the law.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 27--Mrs. Robert B. Meckley of Washington took a two-stroke lead in the twentyfifth annual United States senior women's golf championship by scoring a 41, 41--82 over the South course of the Westchester Country Club today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27--Higher productivity to build American military strength while maintaining the highest possible living standard will be urged in a campaign to be started soon by the Advertising Council.

TORQUAY, England, Sept. 27-- Delegates from thirty-eight countries gathered here tonight to begin winter-long efforts to hold together the shaky structure of tariff truce's consultative machinery, which since the end of World War II has kept international commercial rivalry from degenerating into economic war.
OUTSIDE TAEJON, Korea, Sept. 27--A big tank battle was in progress this afternoon for this rail junction city, which had a pre-war population of 150,000.
Seatrain Lines, Inc., of this city has awarded contracts, for construction of two vessels to the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa.

The R.O.K. (Republic of Korea) forces continued their rapid advance to the north today, with the Third Division moving eight miles to occupy Utchin, and the Eighth Division moving fifteen miles to take Chunyang. These towns are located on the northwest road out of Yongju.

The fifty-eighth running of the Lawrence Realization was a soft touch for Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Bed o' Roses at Belmont Park yesterday. At the end of the mile and five furlongs the trim little filly was four and a half lengths clear of her closest pursuer in the field of seven 3-year-olds.

THIS has been a week of feverish activity in sports. There was the heavyweight championship fight last night and both pennant races have reached a furious boiling point. Since even the Louis-Charles fisticuffing endeavor had some difficulty in muscling its way past baseball's headline-hogging screen, one of sports better-kept secrets has been tomorrow night's pro football game between the New York Yanks and the Detroit Lions.

WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 28 (AP)-- The defending champion, Miss. Louise Suggs of Carrolton, Ga., shot the only sub-par round of first day play, a one-under 74, for the lead in the National Women's open golf tournament today.

DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP)--The Tigers today announced the purchase of two right-hand pitchers, Ken Fremming and Ted Kapuscinski, from their Toledo farm club of the American Association. Both will report to the Tigers next spring. The price was not disclosed.

Directors of the National Cash Register Company yesterday declared an extra dividend of 50 cents payable Dec. 20. The board also recommended an increase of an additional 179,080 shares to be distributed as a stock dividend in the ratio of one share for each ten held.

A selection of the works of Franz Felix, portrait painter, book designer and illustrator of the "Droll Stories" by Honore de Balzac, will be on exhibition throughout October at the East River Savings Bank in Rockefeller Center in commemoration of the Balzac Centennial.

The Geneva Steel Company announced yesterday that it had awarded to the Koppers Company, Inc., a contract for the construction of a battery of twenty-three coke ovens at its Ironton plant near Provo, Utah. Geneva Steel, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, said the ovens have a carbonizing capacity of 600 net tons of coal a day.

The Republic of Indonesia was voted into the United Nations yesterday by acclamation of the General Assembly. No dissenting voice was raised as the new island republic became the sixtieth member and the first to be admitted since the entry of Israel in May, 1949.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 28--Michael Foley, superintendent of Aubon Park for the last thirty-two years, will retire tomorrow, his ninetieth birthday.

For the first time in many weeks consumers may choose from a large variety of fish in liberal supply, several of which are lower in price. Chickens of all sizes are abundantly available, too, and no higher in cost reports the City Department of Markets in its weekly survey of retail food prices.

BELFAST, Ireland, Sept. 28 (AP) --Six horses of the Irish Army jumping team were loaded aboard the freighter American Builder today bound for shows in the United States. The team will appear at Harrisburg, Pa., New York and Toronto.

Plans for sale of $4,000,000 of bonds and $2,000,000 of debentures by the California Electric Power Corlpany next month were announced yesterday. The company will advertise for bids On Oct. 16 and will open bids on Oct. 24 at the Banlcers Trust Company here.

They embrace principles to which most of the members of the United Nations are committed and are in line with both the Charter and the Assembly declarations on Korea.

Beginning Sunday, Staten Island residents who ask telephone information or the operator for a doctor will be referred to the twenty-fourhour switchboard of the Richmond County Medical Society, where an attendant will dispatch a qualified general practitioner to the case.

BOSTON, Sept. 28-Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. E. Carlisle Baker of Chestnut Hill of the engagement of their daughter, Joyce Beverly, to Thomas Gilbert Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Brown, also of Chestnut Hill., The couple will be married this winter.
Business was moderately active on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices at the close were 26 points lower to 12 point higher than on Wednesday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 28 -A too-realistic play over the Swedish radio last night brought panic to thousands of persons over what they thought was the invasion of Sweden. In Goeteborg, the homeguard was mobilized.

The City Fusion party which brought an unsuccessful action to prevent the election of a Mayor this year, will not announce its choice for Mayor until after its dinner on Wednesday at the Warwick Hotel, Gabriel A. Wechsler, general secretary, announced yesterday.

STROUDSBURG, Pa., Sept. 28 (AP)--Six hourses were killed and three others were destroyed later when a van carrying sixteen horses crashed into a culvert and struck a tree on Route 12 fives miles west of here today.
A super telescope will leave today for South Africa to enable scientists to peer deeper into the Milky Way than ever before.
The Boys' Club of New York announces the appointment of John E. Blackenchip as director of its drama department for the 1950-51 season. He will be assisted by George Young and Frederick Hill.

JOHNSTOWN.N.Y., Sept. 28-- Mrs. Rose M. Knox, gelatine Industrialist who after the death of her husband, Charles B. Knox, developed a business career that led to notable philanthropies, died here last night of a cerebral thrombosis at the age of 92.

UNITED STATES EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, Friday, Sept. 29 (UP)--A crack battalion of Australian troops that arrived at Pusan yesterday has joined British forces and will join in the mission assigned to those forces, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--President Truman said today that he would enforce the controversial anti-Communist law that was enacted last week over his veto. He added, however, that he would be in no hurry to carry out one of its provisions and indicated that he would seek its repeal before the duties of his office demanded that he make it effective.

Cuban chess players will visit this city for a match on eight boards against the Manhattan C. C. N. Y. Saturday October 7. The Cubans are members of the Capablanca Chess Club of Havana. A blindfold exhibition game with clocks between Samuel Reshevsky and Dr. Rueben Fine is scheduled for Oct. 8.
The Department of Health is conducting a widespread study to determine whether the occurrence of poliomyelitis is related to recent immunization against other diseases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28-The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, of Syracuse, N. Y., applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for authority to sell $40,000,000 of general mortgage bonds, series due on Oct. 1, 1980.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 28--At Windhoek, South-West Africa, the Electoral College today chose two Nationalists as members of the South African Senate sitting in Capetown, thus completing the "integration" of the former German colony mandated to the Union of South Africa by the defunct League of Nations.
The first Marine Corps reserve aviation squadron to be called into service will leave Floyd Bennett Naval Air Base on Sunday. It will go to the West Coast by the Marine Corps' own airlift.
Eight alumni of Columbia University have been appointed members of the board of directors of the Affiliated Columbia Clubs, an organization of alumni groups in sixty cities from coast to coast.

A series of twenty-three advertisements, prepared by the J. Walter Thompson Company as volunteer agency, is being released to leading newspapers for use in observance of United Nations Day on Oct. 24. Two tenors will share one role in tonight's performance of Gounod's "Faust" by the New York City Opera Company.

THE surfcasters who make a fall pilgrimage to the North Carolina outer banks for the channel bass fishing can load up the car and get under way right now, for the run is on and the fish are plentiful.

A Sharp increase in sales and earnings was realized by Consolidated Grocers Corporation since the start of its fiscal year on July 1, Nathan Cummings, board chairman, told stockholders at their annual meeting in Chicago yesterday.

Excess profit study groups in a11 of America's trade and industrial associations were urged yesterday to get together to discuss recommendations for retaining profitincentive features in any future tax program.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 (AP)-The Cardinals hammered Ken Raffensberger for nine hits in 21-3 innings tonight and went on to beat Cincinnati, 7--0, behind the six-hit performance of Howard Pollet. Chuck Diering drove tvvo doubles that batted in four runs.
The renovated Germantown, Pa., store of Oppenheim Collins will open for business today at 9:30 A. M. In the ceremonies formally

CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 28 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture of East Bengal estimated today the region's 1950 jute crop would exceed that of 1949 by more than 1,000,000 bales. Fiber from the jute plant is used in the manufacture of carpets, bagging, canvas and other products.

The Citizens Budget Commission, of which Robert W. Dowling is president, announced yesterday that it had addressed twelve questions to the four candidates for Mayor, with a request for discussion during the campaign.

PARIS, Sept. 28 (Reuters)--Gen. Pierre Louis Marie Carolet has been appointed head of the French Military Government in Berlin and commandant of the French Sector of Berlin, replacing Gen. Jean Ganeval, it was announced officially today. General Ganeval will receive a new appointment.

The General Chemical division, Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, has appointed Chester M. Brown as a vice president, effective next Monday. He has Been with the company twenty-one years, holding various positions in the production and sales departments.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 28--The necessity and value of "free inquiry and free speech, of academic freedom in the fullest sense," was emphasized here today by Prof. Emily C. Brown, acting chairman of the Department of Economics, at the formal academic convocation opening the eightysixth year of Vassar College.

NEW ROCHELLE, sept. 28-- Alleged Communists in this city are giving a cold shoulder to the demand that they register with the police. The deadline for registering under a local ordinance adopted last week by the City Council was reached today and not one suspect had even made an inquiry.
