MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 28--Prime Minister Robert GordonMenzies reintroduced in the House of Representatives today the Government's controversial bill for dissolution of the Communist party. Charging that the Opposition was trying to dilute the bill, he challenged the Labor party to force an election on the issue.

A thick overcast through which a copper-colored sun shone wanly caused a lot of folk around town yesterday to wonder whether the week-end's "smoke blanket" from smoldering Canadian forest fires was still hovering over these parts.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 28 (AP) --Tassel Hanover established a world record for 3-year-old pacing fillies by going a mile in 2:00 2/5 on the Grand Circuit card today.
After extending Wednesday's gains in the early dealings, with a few, issues showing strength, the stock market yesterday developed an easier tone as a result of profit-taking and other selling.
TORQUAY, England, Sept. 28-- The United States called for "action" at the opening of the third round of tariff conferences here today.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 29 (AP)-- A broadcast from New Delhi, India, heard in Tokyo today, said North Korean Premier Kim II Sung had ordered his beaten troops to return north of the Thirtyeighth Parallel.

FITCHBURG, Mass., Sept. 28 -- The Fitchburg youth library will provide youngsters with books and experiences to encourage their aptitude for singularity despite a modern tendency for regimenation, said Archibald MacLeish, Pulitzer prize winning poet, today at the dedication ceremonies of the library.
Despite the recent vote of confidence given the British Labor party on the steel nationalization issue, the Government will not proceed with announced plans for nationalization on or after Jan. 1.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 28----The capital of Korea was completely freed today from the Communist invaders.

The New York State Thruway Authority, in an unusual "double play" involving fourteen banks and two insurance companies, borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday to cover construction and outstanding obligations on the first section of the projected 500-mile superhighway to come under its jurisdiction.

J. P. and L. A. Kissling are moving their real estate office from 2 Columbus Circle to 10 West Forty-eighth Street over the weekend. Originally founded in 1870 as A. W. Miller Co., the organization adopted its present name in 1900.
LONDON, Sept. 28--The Labor party's precarious majority in the House of Commons rose from seven to nine tonight with a victory in a by-election and the death of a Conservative member.

The firmer tone noticeable in the market for gilt-edge corporate bonds in the last few days was confirmed yesterday by the quick sellout of two new issues of public utility bonds by marketing syndicates.

Hudson Guild, 436 West Twentyseventh Street, wil hold a threeday urban-rural conference at its farm at Andoucr, N. J., today through Sunday, bringing together city dwellers and farmers to explore current problems faced by both.
Richard Gregor gave a rather puzzling recital in Town Hall last night. At times he appeared inhibited, playing with caution and restraint. At others he tore into a work with fire and dash.
Meeting, sponsored by the American Women's Society of Certified Public Accountants and American Society of Women Accountants, Biltmore Hotel, 10 A. M. and 3 P. M. Continues tomorrow and Sunday.

The actuaries keep telling themselves that they have lengthened the life span, but the heavyweights know different. Joe Louis took the comeback trail, but he found, like all the travelers before him, that it leads nowhere.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (UP)--A Trans World Airlines plane landed at London airport today inaugurating T.W.A.'s direct New York to London service. Forty-three persons, including thirty-four newspaper men, were aboard for the flight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The Army must induct 300,000 men in the next six months to attain its planned strength, high-ranking officers testified at the Capitol today. This estimate later was confirmed at the Pentagon.

HONG KONG, Sept. 28--Indicating an intensified naval blockade of the Chinese coast, a Nationalist warship has intercepted two Liberty ships allegedly purchased by the Chinese Communists. The ships, the Henry Abbot and Juan de Fuca, were being towed from Hong Kong to Shanghai by British-owned tugs.

DENVER, Sept. 28 (AP)--William L. Allen, consulting engineer and former president of the Sheffield Steel Company in Kansas City, died today after suffering a heart attack. He was born sixty-one years ago in Glenwood, Minn.'
NEW PALTZ, N. Y., Sept. 28 --Oscar of the Waldorf, one of the world's renowned connoisseurs of food, said on his eightyfourth birthday today that the average American "still likes plain cooking."

OSAN, Korea, Sept. 28 (UP)--A United States intelligence officer said today that reports from war prisoners and civilians indicated that Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, the hero of Taejon long given up as dead, was still alive.
The fact that the furnishings of a tasteful traditional room need not all be limited to designs from one specific period is illustrated in eight new room settings opening this morning at Altman's.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 28 (AP)--Jadwiga Rodzinska, mother of Artur Rodzinski, orchestra conductor, died here today in the General Hospital at the age of 80. Five weeks ago she broke a hip while at her son's summer home in Lake Placid, A heart condition developed ten days ago.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28 --The question of how achieve "good" scientific work with research Rinds contributed through the often conflicting interests of private endowments, industrial grants, universities and both state and Federal governments, received an answer here today.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, sailed for Europe yesterday on the French liner Ile de France. He will confer with Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion on the economic and financial needs of Israel.

TAEGU, Korea, Sept. 28--All enemy forces south of the SeoulTaegu-Pusan line, about threequarters of the invaders of South Korea, face annihilation without a chance of reaching the Thirtyeighth Parallel, Lieut. Gen. Walton H. Walker, commander of the United States Eighth Army, declared today.

WITH THE UNITED STATES TWENTY--FIFTH DIVISION, Korea, Sept. 28 (AP)--Ninety-one American prisoners of war were liberated today by two columns of advancing Twenty-fifth Infantry Division troops in South Korea.

While the thoughts and hopes of the world are centered on an early end to war in the Far East a peace conference that has nothing to do with hostilities in Korea has quietly convened in an English seaside resort.
GUATEMALA, Sept. 28--Congress today ordered a Presidential election for Nov. 10, 11 and 12 to choose a successor to President Juan Jose Arevalo, whose term ends March 15, 1951.

NEWARK, Sept. 28--Thirty-five years of work for the Children's Aid Society of this city, all but the first three as executive secretary will end in retirement tomorrow for Miss Jessie P. Condit of East Orange.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28-- The Supreme Council, Thirty-third Degree, Scottish Rite, Northern Masonic Jurisdiction, at its 138th annual meeting here today, appropriated $1,000,000 to endow a benevolent foundation.

A woman was found dead and a man unconscious in an apartment at 5280 Heath Avenue, the Bronx, about 6 o'clock last evening, after the continuous playing of a radio had drawn the attention of a neighbor.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William A. Higgins of 333 East Fifty-third Street of the engagement of their daughter, Mildred Eileen, to John Edward Rowan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Rowan of West New Brighton, S. I. Plans have been made for a December wedding.

A Washington dispatch yesterday brought word that $11,000,000, or a little more than one-third of the money made available for Point Four by recent appropriation, would be spent on development programs in Latin America.

CANTON, N. Y., Sept. 28--Ignoring the issue of developing the St. Lawrence River as a seaway, Representative Walter A. Lynch, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, said tonight that he favored developing it fully for electric power "consistent with the expanding demand of national defence."

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 28--The engagement of Miss. Marguerite Anne Gallman to Theodore R. Lilley, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest R. Lilley of Tenafly, has been announced by her parents, the Rev. Herbert H. Gallman and Mrs. Gallman.

HAIFA, Israel, Sept. 28 (Reuters)--The cornerstone of an immigrants' school named for the British leader Maj. Gen. Orde Wingate was laid here today in the presence of his widow, Mrs. Lorna Wingate, and his 6-year-old son.
State intervention in the current city-wide inestigation into alleged police-gambler affiliations became a possibility yesterday.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 28-- The leaders of Portugal and Spain are in complete agreement over the problems facing the world, according to an official note published today. The close understanding between the two countries was reaffirmed.

HAVANA, Sept. 28--The Cabinet today resolved to award the Grand Cross of the Order of Carlos Manuel de Cespedes to Gen. Douglas MacArthur as Chief of the Unified Command of the United Nations forces. This is the highest decoration Cuba confers.
Robert Helpmann, the principal male dancer of the Sadler's Wells Ballet last night made his first appearance of the season, having been detained in London until now by a motion-picture production.

DETROIT, Friday, Sept. 29 (AP) --Mrs. Clara Bryant Ford, 84year-old widow of Henry Ford, died at 2 A. M. today in Henry Ford Hospital. A family spokesman said her death was the result of an acute coronary occlusion.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 28-- Mrs. Edith Sampson made her first speech today as a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly with an air of confidence she confessed later was "mostly pretended."
PARIS, Sept. 28--An elaborate organization to provide internal "defense in depth" of French territory in the event of war or threat of war was decreed by the Paris Government today.

TRENTON, Sept. 28--With the dedication of its new $115,000 Child Care Center on Parkside Avenue here, the Children's Home Society of New Jersey expressed the hope today that the new structure would simplify the problems of persons seeking youngsters for adoption.
LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP)--The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended on Sept. 27 issued today, follows (in thousands of pounds):
Events tonight: "Faust," New york City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15 o'clock; Maria Matyas, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; "The Beggar's Opera," The Interplayers, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:40.

TOKYO, Sept. 28 (AP)--A ferry on the Tsugaru Strait reported today sighting an unidentified submarine in the channel between the main Japanese island of Honshu and Hokkaido, to the north. Officers of the ferry Oshima Mary said the submarine was seen five miles northeast of the northern tip of Honshu at 7:20.A. M. [5:20 P.M., Wednesday.]
One of the most interesting and most passed-by exhibits at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is the collection of European and
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 28 (AP)--Frank Sinatra, the crooner, was legally separated today from his wife, who won a third of his million-dollar-a-year income.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 (UP)--Walter T. Brown, former secretary to Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, has resigned as executive vice president of the Empire State Association of Commerce, it was announced today. F. Ritter Shumway, association president, announced that Mr. Brown would be succeeded by William A. Mills of Chicago.

Col. Walter Jeffreys Carlin, Brooklyn lawyer and a prominent Catholic layman, has been named chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Election of Ferdinand Pecora as Mayor, Aaron L. Jacoby, campaign manager, announced yesterday at the Pecora headquarters in the Commodore Hotel.
Mrs. Philip D. Wilson has been named chairman of the women's di-ivision of Greater New York in the 1950-51 New York campaign of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, sept. 28 (AP)--The official Communist newspaper Borba disclosed today that the Government had fired 6,000 employee of the Croatian State Government. The move to cut Government coats and increase efficiency came about because "a great number of employes had been found to be unnecessary and to lack sufficient qualifications," Borba said.
TOKYO, Sept. 28--The radio station at Pyongyang, capital of North Korea, today broadcast that its Communist news chief Wednesday night telephoned Seoul to find out how the war was going.

Election of Bernard Weiser as vice president in charge of sales for McCormick Co., Inc., was announced yesterday by Charles P. McCormick, president. In January, 1946, Mr. Weiser was elected a director after serving three times as chairman of the company's junior board of executives.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Sept. 28-- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporavion reported today that it has received excellent response from customers in support of measures put into effect to curb a "gray market" in steel.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28 --Coach Herman Hickman bolstered his supply of ends for Yale's Eastern League opener, Saturday, against Brown by moving Sophomore Richard D. Mionroe of Pelham Manor, N. Y., up to the varsity squad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP)-- Robert M.Hanes, chief of the Economic Cooperation Administration mission in Germany, has submitted his resignation, but no action has been taken on it, a spokesman for the agency said today.

Brooklyn College's soccer team' will open its season today in an encounter with Army at West Point, This is the only non-league match for the Kingsmen who start their Metropolitan Conference schedule against the Long Island Aggies next week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The fact that the armed services are taking thousands of bombers and other aircraft from World War II out of "mothballs" has brought the sharp pinch in supplies of aviation grade gasoline. Officials at the Department of the Interior said today ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP)-- The State Department announced today that private organizations during the last week contributed $250,000 worth of clothing, blankets and soap for civilian relief in Korea. Contributions came from CARE, the Church World Service and war relief services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The Truman Administration was accused today by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, of ignoring evidence that officers of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America had filed affidavits falsely disclaiming Communist affiliation.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 (AP)-- A tired Al Jolson returned by plane last night from entertaining combat troops in the Korean war zone and had this comment:

Current trends of sales and business give strong indication that more liquor will be sold in New York City during the last quarter of this year than ever before in the city's history, Gerald F. Dunne, executive director of the Metropolitan Package Stores Association, declared yesterday.
PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Sept. 28 (AP)--An explosion of undetermined origin wrecked three buildings and shattered windows of at least twenty others in this Eastern Shore town early today. No one was hurt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Saying the book speaks for itself, President Truman today brushed off questions about a new biography which quotes him as saying James F. Byrnes "failed miserably" as Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- President Truman today signed a bill granting state and local governments an additional five years to take part in a $520,000,000 program of Federal aid for airport development.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Sole surviving sons or daughters in uniform may, upon their own request or the request of one of their parents, be assigned to non-combat duty, the Department of Defense announced today, They may, however, still be assigned overseas duty.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Microbiologists of eight Communist countries asked other such scientists throughout the world today to "declare war on biological warfare."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--President Truman appointed George J. Bott as General Counsel of the National Labor Relations Board today. He succeeds Robert N. Denham, the first General Counsel under the Taft-Hartley Act, who resigned at the President's request two weeks ago.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Eddie Pellagrini, star shortstop of the Orioles, has been sold outright to the Phillies. Jack Dunn, Orioles owner, made the announcement today. No price was disclosed. Pellagrini will report to the Phils next spring.
Paul G. Hoffman, retiring Administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration, has been chosen as the 1950 recipient of the Capt. Robert Dollar Memorial Award.

The decision of the North Atlantic Council of Foreign Ministers --belated under the circumstances --to create an integrated West European force may well mark the rebirth of military strength in Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, declared today that the price situation was getting out of hand and called on President Truman to set up control machinery speedily.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 28-- The Turkish Army brigade promised to the United Nations has left for Korea, the official Ankara radio announced tonight. Unofficial press reports say the troops left by sea from Iskenderun and will reach Okinawa in forty-five days.
Television adaptations of short stories by Somerset Maugham will provide a new weekly series on the Columbia Broadcasting System beginning Wednesday, Oct. 18, from 9 to 9:30 P. M. An effort is being
VIENNA, Sept. 28--Hungary's Communist Government has been exerting pressure to get Roman Catholic priests to run as candidates in the Oct. 2 communal elections, it was reported here.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28--The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the country's fourth largest steel producer, agreed today to the early wage talks requested by Philip Murray's United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O.

UNITED STATES EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, Friday, Sept. 29--A ranking officer of the South Korean Army predicted today that elements of the rapidly advancing Republican force would reach the Thirty-eighth Parallel--the old border between South...

Stephen H. Jackson, 77-year-old landlord, who began yesterday to serve a thirty-day jail sentence for violation of sanitary and building regulations in his Harlem tenements, later in the day applied to Supreme Court for a certificate of reasonable doubt.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 28--When a man reaches, the half century mark in his life span his career is usually established, but to Bela Balassa, former Hungarian acting Consul General in New York City, that point marks only the beginning of preparations for another.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--President Truman declared today that he had not yet ruled out a campaigning role for himself in this year's important Congressional election.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28--Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, said here tonight that T.V.A. "has earned a place in the long and honored list of American social inventions."

The only place the Communists are actively operating in the Eighteenth Congressional District is "in Representative Vito Marcantonio's two clubhouses," former State Senator James G. Donovan, threeparty coalition candidate for Congress running against Mr. Marcantonio, the incumbent, declared yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28-- Six Japanese jurists headed by Chief Justice Kotaro Tanaka of Japan arrived here tonight on a forty-five-day tour to study United States judicial organization and practices. They will leave Sunday for New York.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sept. 28 (AP)--The Hungarian Government today announced a public subscription "peace" loan of 750,000,000 florints (about $62,000,000). An appeal for support, signed by Premier Istvan Dobi and Vice Premier Matyas Rakosi, said the loan would be repaid in ten years.

HONOLULU, Sept. 28--Hawaii's Territorial Legislature will convene in special session tomorrow in a determined effort to advance the cause of Hawaiian statehood despite delay in the United States Senate in voting on the Hawaiian statehood enabling bill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Without the-economic strength gained through the Marshall Plan, Western European countries could not even be considering spending vast sums to maintain larger military establishments, Paul Hoffman, the retiring head of the Economic Cooperation Administration, asserted tonight.

The time for exchanging dollar bonds of Bogota, Colombia, for Republic of Colombia 3 per cent external dollar bonds due on Oct. 1, 1970, has been extended from Oct. 1, 1950, to April 1, 1951, it was announced yesterday.
TAEJON, Korea, Friday, Sept. 29 (AP)--The bodies of nearly 400 South Korean civilians and police were found last night in two uncovered trenches of the Taejon Prison.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 28--Thomas A. Victor, 28-year-old city patrolmen here, confirmed tonight that he was withdrawing as an inde-. pendent Democratic candidate for Representative in the Thirteenth Congressional District. Mr. Victor
The openings, promised for the week after nest, have been pared down to two. The latest alteration finds "The Curious Savage" set back from Oct. 10 to Oct. 24 at the Martin Beck.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 28 (AP)--Police Chief John R. King said today he was seeking a legal opinion on constitutionality of an order adopted by the City, Council requiring members of the Communist party in this "university city" to register with the police.

The Atomic Energy Commission characterized as wholly untrue a report from Chicago yesterday that "Chicago scientists have discovered the first practical method for the direct conversion of atomic energy into useful electricity."

GARDEN CITY, L. L, Sept. 28 --The one-day medal play handicap tournament of the Long Island Golf Association held today at the Cherry Valley Club course resulted in a tie between two members of the Brookville Country Club. The winners were Dan Rathgaber and Phil Galletta. Each turned in a card of 77--11--66.

Temporarily evicted from Yankee Stadium because of the impending world series, the New York Yanks will make their home debut at the Polo Grounds tonight. They face the Detroit Lions, one of the four remaining undefeated teams in the expanded National Football League.The kick-off will be at 8:30.
Retail conditions have improved in the Union of South Africa, according to reports to the Standard Bank of South Africa released here yesterday by its agency at 67 Wall Street.

AT least it wasn't the ending that his admirers had dreaded, the nightmarish spectacle of a once proud and majestic champion grovel ing on the canvas after being beaten to a bloody pulp by a man who never could be in the same class with the Joe Louis of old.

Directors of the Philco Corporation yesterday called a special meeting of stockholders for Nov. 28 to increase the authorized common shares from 2,500,000 to 5,000,000 shares and to split the common stock by issuing one additional share for each share now outstanding.

El Salvador became yesterday the eighteenth nation to give formal notice to the United Nations of her ratification of the international convention outlawing genocide. Only one more ratification is required to put the convention into force.

One girl was shot and seriously wounded at the East 143d Street entrance of St. Mary's Park in the Bronx last night, and two others were slightly wounded in what appeared, the police said, to have been a clash between juvenile bands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- The Radio Corporation of America and several other television manufacturers today rejected the Federal Communications Commission's proposal for a sudden change in the design of their television sets to make ready for the coming of color.

SCRANTON, Pa., Sept. 28-- Ralph E. Weeks, chairman of the board of the International Textbook Company and its affiliates, died here of a heart attack today at his home. He was 72 years old. He was a past president of the Pennsylvania Chamber of Commerce.

TAEJON, Korea, Sept. 28 (UP)-- Information on the atrocity-slaying by North Korean Communists of fifty-eight more United States soldiers came today from liberated Americans and South Koreans here. Troops of the United States Twenty-fourth Infantry Division freed a group in recapturing Taejon.

WASHINGTON, sept. 28 (UP)In every month since the Korean war began farmers have been paid more for their products than in the corresponding months last year, the Department of Agricul-, ture reported today.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 29--A thoroughly routed and disorganized Communist army fled before the United Nations forces today on all sections of the Korean front. The North Korean invaders fought where they were cornered, resisting fanatically in a few small ,pockets where groups of soldiers battled to gain time for their retreating comrades.
MOAB, Utah, Sept. 28 (AP)--Six boaters were rescued last night from the canyon between here and Westwater after a hectic trip during one day of which they made only 500 yards down the Colorado River.
SAIGON, Indo-China, Sept. 28 (AP)--French garrison forces, hold-- ing the Indo-China frontier with China under rising pressure from Communist-led Vietminh, reorgan-- ized their defense system today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 28 Trinity College has received a gift of $650,000 from the Old Dominion Foundation, established by Paul Mellon, and will use the gift to preserve valuable collections of the Watkinson Library here, it was announced today by G. Keith Funston, president of the college, at its formal opening convocation.
NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 28 (AP)-- The New Jersey Lumbermen's Association was told today that building construction in 1950 would be double the dollar volume of any previous year despite the Korean war.

Ten years ago an ambitious young man was on his way to Washington to seek a West Point appointment. In the outskirts of Newark he somehow lost his footing on the train, fell to the tracks. Both his legs wet a amputated; his future seemed dim.

The United Nations armed forces should continue across the Thirtyeighth Parallel in Korea only if military necessity requires such an action, Robert Schuman, French Foreign Minister, declared yesterday.
Mrs. Hugh Bullock Dave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Eric L. F. Archdeacon, Mrs. Robert Goetz,Mrs. Duncan H. Read. and Mrs. Frederick G. Reinicke. Mrs. Edward L. Greene ...
BELFAST, Ireland, Sept. 28-- The Irish, already well represented in major league baseball in the United States, may soon be producing even more diamond stars.

NEWMARKET, England, Sept. 28 (AP)--An American trainer, Jimmy Ryan, paid Al,172 for a yearling colt by Tehran--Venus at the Newmarket sales today. Clive Graham, British racing writer, acting for Ryan, made the final bid.

Acting Mayor Impellitteri and Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy declared last night that they would bring Governor Dewey "right up to date" on what they have done regarding the Brooklyn gambling situation and what they propose to do.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 28 (AP) --The all-Jewish World Olympics began today at stadiums and sports grounds in Tel Aviv and eight other cities or towns, with elimination play in soccer, tennis and basketball.
TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 29 (AP)-- United States Tenth Corps communique 8, issued at 3:05 A. M. Friday (1 P. M., Thursday, Eastern standard time):

The planning subcommittee of the Munitions Board's industry advisor y committee on storage and handling will meet this morning at the Statler Hotel. The topic for this meeting is to be palletization of heavy caliber ammunition.
Associated Services for the Armed Forces will open next month thirteen new armed forces clubs in communities near military and naval installations in this country.

LANCASTER, Pa., Sept. 28 (UP) -For the second day in a row, an anonymous person today paid the fines of Amish fathers accused of failing to send their 14-year-old children to school, and they were released from jail.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- An attorney for the Navajo Indians reported today that the Indian Bureau plans to cut $4,500,000 from the approximately $12,000,000 voted by Congress for the long-range Navajo-Hopi Indian rehabilitation program.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 28-- The Senate Crime Investigating Committee heard testimony today that Charles Binaggio, local gambler and politician, may have had $12,000 in his pocket the night he was killed last April. The murder is still unsolved.
MINNEAPOLIS, --Sept. 28-Representatives from more than dozen states met here today to organize a national association for the benefit of mentally retarded children.
Increased sales and earnings were reported yesterday by Robbins Mills, Inc., for the quarter and nine months ended with last August.

DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP)--A deadgame bunch of Tigers cashed in on a great break today to edge the Browns, 4-3, in a dramatic twelveinning battle that kept alive their slender hopes of a tie in the American League pennant race.

At 2 P. M. yesterday, two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation identified themselves to George Burdi, 25 years old, of 160 Prince Street, who was seated in an automobile at 126th Street and Broadway. Burdi sped north.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28.--A report to be made soon to President Truman at his request with recommend that the Philippine Government undertake the severest kind of economic and fiscal reforms if it hopes to forestall almost certain economic collapse.

MANILA, Sept. 28 (AP)--Thirteen high Philippines Constabulary officers in Pampanga and Antique Provinces have been transferred pending investigation of reported abuses against civilians, defense authorities said today.
Decisive action on the issue of war or peace may well be taken by the General Assembly of the United Nations at this session, Secretary General Trygve Lie declared yesterday at Flushing Meadow.
Gen. Mark W. Clark, chief of the United States Army Field Forces, warned last night that this country should beware of "phony" peace feelers from the Soviet Union.

Prokofieff's opera satirizing grand opera, "The Love for Three Oranges," was presented for the first time in the fall season at the City Center last night, and as in eleven previous performances in recent spring and fall seasons it drew a delighted, capacity house.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28--The Arlington Handicap and Washington Park Handicap will be increased to $100,000 added each in 1951, Executive Director Benjamin F. Lindheimer of Arlington and Washington Parks announced today.
WINDSOR, Ont., Sept. 28 (Canadian Press)--Windsor bankers today reported an increased flow of United States funds into banks for conversion to Canadian dollars.

Frank C. Moore, State Controller and Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor, placed the blame for school overcrowding in New York City at the doorstep of the Democratic City Administration last night.
The American Radio Association, C. I. O., yesterday joined the group of maritime unions seeking wage increases with a demand upon Atlantic and Gulf Coast ship operators for an immediate wage review.

Frank E. Ellis, co-founder and former vice president of the New England Fibre Blanket Company of Worcester, Mass., manufacturer of pressroom--and stereotype room supplies, died of a heart attack on Wednesday in front of the Dorset Hotel, 30 West Fifty-fourth Street. His age was 76.

The festival commemorating the 400th anniversary of the modern violin, which had been scheduled for Oct. 4 and 5 in the Julius Hartt School auditorium in Hartford, Conn., has been postponed. The new date has not been specified but the festival will be held at the end of October or early in November.

Howard H. Cammack, general agent of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, Albany, N.Y., has been elected president of the American Society of Chartered Life Underwriters. He succeeds Karl K. Krogue, branch manager of the Business Men's Assurance Company, Spokane, Wash.

About 250 members are expected to attend the joint annual meeting of the American women's Society of Certified Public Accountants and the American Society of Women Accountants to be held at the Biltmore Hotel today, tomorrow and Sunday.

VIENNA, Austria, Sept. 28 (AP) --Austrian Communists pulled out roadblocks and other obstacles to traffic in Vienna tonight, In other sections of the country the demonstrators began a back-to-work movement that indicated an end to a three-day protest strike against the Government's new price and wage policy.

To serve on the faculty of the School of Social Work in Amsterdam, the Netherlarfds, Miss. Cora Kasius, director of publications of the Family Service of America, will said from New York tomorrow. She is the recipient of a Fulbright award as lecturer in social work.

The Blackfriars Guild, Catholic little theatre group, will open its tenth season with Ted Farah's new comedy, "Angel With Red Hair," on Thursday evening, Oct. 19. The comedy, a one-set production, having a contemporary French-Canadian setting, may be the Guild's ...
The last mass to be celebrated in St. Boniface Roman Catholic Chucrh, 312 East Forty-seventh Street, will be held Sunday at 11 A.M. The 92-year-old landmark ...
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 28 (Reuters)--The Argentine Senate today approved a Government bill to suppress acts of sabotage, spying and treason.

Loans to business by banks in this area registered their seventeenth weekly advance for the period ended on last Wednesday, but at a slackened rate compared with that of the previous fortnight, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

Earnings of the City Investing Company for the fiscal year ending next April 30 will be better than in the previous year, Robert W. Dowling, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here on Wednesday. The company earned $1,032,453 for the last fiscal year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP) --If the Phillies win the pennant, citizens of Philadelphia may be able to see the games on television in the city parks and squares. Mayor Bernard Samuel said today he has asked each Councilman to suggest places in each district where the sets could be installed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- An Immigration Service official said today that 500,000 aliens were caught trying to enter this country illegally during the last twelve months, twice as many as in the preceding year.

Mrs. Ida Fischel Margolies, widow of the Rev. Moses S. Margolies, who was dean of orthodox rabbis in North America, died yesterday morning in her home at 150 East Ninety-third Street, after a brief illness. She was 88 years old.

As the result of a thirty-year lease involving rentals aggregating $2,250,000, the F.W. Woolworth Company will have a new store containing 25,000 square feet of space in the Journal Square Station Building, a commercial structure being erected on "air rights" over the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks in Journal Square, Jersey City.
CHICAGO, Sept, 27--A plan to provide each Chicagoan with a metal dog tag" was outlined today by A. E. Rose, deputy director of the welfare services division of the Chicago civil defense organization.

Demolition of the Third Avenue elevated line between South Ferry land Chatham Square was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The board voted unanimously to give the Board of Transportation permission to discontinue service on this part of the
OTTAWA, Sept. 28 (Canadian Press)--Canada produced more silver in July than in any month in a decade. The Federal Statistics Bureau reported an output of 2,297,142 fine ounces, compared with
Bank of Manhattan Company is registrar for 1,470,000 shares of $1 par common stock of the Standard Coil Products Company, Inc.
Shortages of materials or allocations likely under the mobilization program will have little effect on continued high use of premiums in advertisers' box-top and other give-away promotions.
PUEBLO, Colo., Sept. 28 (AP)-- State Senator Dan Thornton, Gunnison stockman, was named tonight as the Republican candidate for Governor of Colorado. Dr.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Dickstein began a hearing yesterday on a suit brought by International Meters, Inc., to prevent the City Department of Purchase from awarding a proposed contract for the installation of 1,500 parking meters.
Public Service Electric and Gas Company-$1,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures due in 1963 on Nov. 1 at 101.08 at Chase National Bank.

ATHENS, Sept. 28--Premier Sophocles Venizelos said today that his Government had received no proposals from Western powers for the promotion of a defensive system that would include Greece, Turkey, Yugoslavia and Italy.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28-Concern over the inadequacy of reserve ships in a high-speed global war has led the Government to initiate a program calling for large fast freighters capable of meeting the threat of modern submarines.

The annual City College Film Awards for the best documentary films of 1950 were made yesterday to Allan Resnais' "Guernica" and Curt Oertel's "The Titan." Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college, presented them. First prize went to "Guernica" and the second, a scroll, to "The Titan."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 --The Technicolor Motion Picture Corporation today announced the development of what its president and general manager, Dr. Herbert T. Kalmus, described as "a revolutionary advance in color cinematography."
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 28 (UP)-Gov. Chester Bowles, who headed the Office of Price Administration during World War II, predicted today there would be a rollback ...

Directors of the Kendall Company yesterday elected Harold T. Marshall as vice president. Formerly general sales manager of the Kendall Mills finishing division, he is director of sales for the company.

Saul Goldmark has been named merchandise manager of the infants', girls', and teen divisions of Gimbels, New York. He will continue to merchandise boys' wear, men's wear, Lamps, pictures, curtains, draperies, rugs and floor coverings, upholstery fabrics and
Carrying on a favorite theme, Carrie Munn included gaily bedecked felt skirts of almost circular fullness for evening in her custom collection yesterday at 640 Madison Avenue.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 28 (AP) --Employes of the Mack Manufacturing Company affiliated with Local 677, C. I. O. United Auto Workers Union, today accepted a new wage proposal.

OSSINING, N. Y., Sept. 28--Information indicating that an American Catholic priest is being held prisoner near the North Korean capital of Pyongyang has been received at the headquarters of the Catholic Foreign Missions Society here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP)-- A report published by the Department of Agriculture today said the price support program is pricing American wheat out of the Far Eastern market.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 28 (UP) -The United States has bought 12,000 tons of Chilean iron ingots for immediate shipment to San Francisco according to the Compania de Acero del Pacifico (Pacific Steel Company). It said a first shipment of 2,000 tons will be made on next Sunday and a second one of 3,000 tons on Monday.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Sept. 28 (AP) --Skip Alexander, professional golfer injured in a plane crash Sunday night, continued to improve today. However, Deaconess Hospital reported his condition was still serious. He remained under an oxygen tent.

Rosette Pennington of 20 East Fifty-sixth Street gave a fashion show at the Plaza yesterday. Town costumes and party dresses by American designers, Norman Norell, Pauline Trigere, Omar Kiam, Adele Simpson and Jo Copeland, made up the bulk of the collection. There were also a few French adaptations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Sept. 23, 1950, totaled 870,196 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--The United States outlined an ambitious program of technical assistance to the Latin-American Governments today and foresaw an important role for the Inter-American Economic and Social Council in the efforts of free governments to strengthen their economies.
A number of exhibitions opening in New York galleries this week include paintings and sculpture of interest to those who follow contemporary American art.

The Crown Zellerbach Corporation has called for redemption on Nov. 1 all outstanding shares of $4 dividend cumulative convertible second preferred stock at $102.50 plus accrued dividends.Of the 176,552 shares of this stock issued at the tune of reorganization in 1945, all but 18,109 shares have been converted into common.

NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 28--J. J. Wilson, president of Doelcam Corporation, manufacturer of control instruments, announced today the election of Alex J. McFarland as a director and clerk of the corporation and George J. Schwartz as vice president in charge of engineering.
Maurice L. Lowenthal has been elected an assistant vice president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc.
The James J. Hoey Awards for International Justice were announced yesterday by the Catholic Interracial Council, which confers annually two silver medals for outstanding service.

If sales continue at their present high levels, the truck manufacturing industry should dispose of more than 1,000,000 vehicles during 1950. W. K. Perkins, sales manager of the motor truck division of International Harvester Company, in New ...

A daughter, their second child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. John Theodore Haneman Jr. of Hewlett, L. I., on Tuesday, in Doctor's Hospital here. Mrs. Haneman is the former Miss Isabel Scovill Wayland.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept.28 -- With an enveloping movement that this time refused to be turned aside, the Yankees today closed in on the American League pennant where, come what may, the worst they can get by next Sunday night is a tie for first place with the still surviving Tigers.
BOSTON, Sept. 28 (AP)--The smallest Fenway Park crowd in several seasons--2,411 paid-- watched the Red Sox gain a 4-3 decision over Washington today.

MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 28-- Mrs. Janet Hempel of Out O' Bounds was the only woman in the field of 60 today to shoot in the seventies as she won the low gross prize in the Women's Metropolitan one-day golf tournament at the Maplewood Country Club course.

The American Gas and Electric Company has completed plans for acquisition of the Central Ohio Light and Powver Company through an exchange of 72/100 of a share of American Gas common stock for each common share of Central Ohio.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 28 (AP) --The state record of 2,428,145 registered voters, set in 1948, appeared certain to be surpassed today after Democrats, Republicans and labor organizations concluded the most intensive registration drive'in Ohio's history.

BERLIN, Sept. 28--Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Social Democratic party, named today nine cities in Western Germany, chiefly in the Ruhr area, that he said had been marked by the Communists for disturbances this Sunday to test the strength of the West German police forces.
Warnings of the ruin that awaited America if water loss and soil erosion were not stopped on the farms were voiced yesterday in a forum of agricultural experts at the Statler Hotel.

LONDON, Sept. 28--Rubber and tin shares fell again on the stock markets here today. The reaction was prompted by the further fall in prices of these commodities. Tin shares especially were affected by selling from Eastern holders.

WASHINGTON, Sept., 28--The Labor Department's Bureau of Employment Security reported today that three more labor market areas, including Providence, R. I., had been removed from the "E" list--the list of areas with labor surpluses of 12 per cent or more.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Seventy-eight nominations for postmasters in twenty-one states and Puerto Rico have been sent back to President Truman.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28-- The Bostwick Field and California poloists, finalists in the National Open polo championship last Sunday, earned the right to meet in the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup tournament this week-end with victories at the Meadow Brook Club today.
DETROIT, Sept. 28 (UP)-- Henry J. Kaiser, who once hoped to sell a "people's car" for $500, put his Henry J, on sale today with $1,299 and $1,429 price tags, delivered at Willow Run, Mich.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- President Truman today signed a bill to permit 163 immigrant Span-' iards to remain in this country. Nearly all are sheepherders in western states.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP)--The body of Augustus E. Falkenberg, 70 years old, a water supply engineer, was found today in a filter pool at the city water plant. State police said they believed he had fallen down stairs leading into a filter pool.
Herbert Sorkin gave his third New York violin recital last night in Carnegie Hall.

The work of the Mayor's Joint Committee on Port Industry is expected to be "all wrapped up" by the end of the year, Jerry Finkelstein, the chairman, asserted yesterday after a meeting with representatives of its nine subcommittees.

DETROIT, Sept. 28-The appointment by the President of a group of "senior citizens" to frame a steadfast national policy was urged tonight by Lt. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, retired, wartime head of the Manhattan Project, as a part of the balanced defense needed for total war.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 28-Republicans who intend to vote for Judge George W. Smyth, a Republican, for Supreme Court justice in the November election were saved today from the "distasteful" fate of having to cast the votes in a Democratic or Liberal column.
CLEVELAND, Sept, 28 (AP)--The Indians tonight announced the purchase of two infielders from their Oklahoma City farm club, shortstop Harry Malmberg and third baseman Freddie Marsh.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., Sept. 28 (UP)--William F. Sullivan Jr., 37year-old Boston lawyer, was elected president of the National Association of Cotton Manufactusers at its convention today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Robert A. Lovett, former Under Secretary of State, today was appointed Deputy Secretary of Defense by President Truman. He succeeds Stephen T. Early who will leave the Pentagon Saturday to re-enter private business.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP)--Bell Gossett Company, manufacturers of heating equipment, today announced payment of a $100,000 bonus to its 800 office and factory employes.
Mrs. Amanda Fabris Spanuth of 755 Park Avenue, a retired opera singer, died Wednesday in Roosevelt Hospital, after a long illness. Her age was 83.
Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, last night accused the American Medical Association of blocking the proposed Federal plan to subsidize medical schools.

A bill to bar discrimination in city-assisted housing against any person because of his "race, color, religion, national origin or ancestry" was reintroduced in the City Council yesterday by Councilmen Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Republican-Liberal, and Earl Brown, Manhattan Democrat.
Affiliated Gas Equipment, Inc, voted yesterday an increased quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share on the common stock, payable Nov. 1. Three previous payments of 15 cents each were made this year.
SEOUL, Korea, Friday, Sept. 29 --Gen, Douglas MacArthur ,returned in triumph today to the still smoking city of Seoul and officially restored the South Korean capital to President Syngman Rhee.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Sept. 28 (AP)--Miss Sadie Belle Arbuthnot of Orlando, Fla., was appointed today as the first woman judge in the United States court system in Germany.

BOSTON, Sept. 28 (AP)--Sugar Ray Robinson today was signed to fight 15 rounds against Boston's Joe Rindone at the Boston Garden Oct. 16, the Andy Callahan A. C. reported tonight.

HELMSTEDT, Germany, Sept. 28 (AP)-East German border guards speeded up their clearing of Berlin-bound trucks at the zonal frontier to almost norncial rate today after the latest in a long series of unexplained slowdowns.

EASTON.Pa., Sept. 28 (AP) --A 6-week-old girl died today in Easton Hospital from infantile paralysis. She was Kimberly Joan La Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruco A. La Rose of Phillipsburg, N.J. The death was the fifth from polio in the Easton area this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28-During the week ended Sept. 27 member bank reserve balances increased $400,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Successful operation of its plastics plant in Israel by the Serafon Resinous Chemicals Corporation,. Ltd., and plans for its expansion were reported here yesterday by Dr. Robert Nussbaum, general manager of the corporation.

Fucks and Wilt will recount their experiences while traveling abroad as members of touring American teams during the past summer.

MONTREAL, Sept. 28 (AP)--Five thousand steel box cars, costing approximately $33,000,000, have been ordered by the Canadian National Railways from Canadian builders, it was announced today by E. A. Eromley. vice president.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- It now appears that 1950 will be the third worst polio year on record, the Public Health Service said today. The worst are recorded as 1949 and 1916.

Three hundred persons attended a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Towers, Brooklyn, signaling the opening of the Brooklyn Girl Scout campaign to raise $109,500. The five borough units comprising the 1950 campaign workers took an active part in the affair.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- Federal tax collections in the first two months of the Government's fiscal year, which started July 1, totaled $5,913,121,722, an increase of $559,668,597 over the same period in the last fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)-- The first 15,000-kilowatt generating unit of the Estes power plant on the Colorado-Big Thompson reclamation project will go into service on Sunday, Secretary of the Interior Chapman has announced.

Charles A. Gerhardt has been elected a director of the Seaboard Finance Company, it was announced yesterday. by W. A. Thompson, chairman. Mr. Gerhardt has been executive vice president of Seaboard since last June. Prior to that he was president of the Employes Credit Corporation, which was acquired by Seaboard Finance, which operates 128 small loan offices in twenty-two states.

Ezzard Charles, new world heavyweight champion, and Joe Louis, dethroned monarch of the ring, were nursing their battle wounds yesterday in the wake of Wednesday's night bruising encounter in Yankee Stadium, but tke task of providing action for the conqueror, Charles, went on nevertheless.
Al Marotti, 141, Youngstown, Ohio, won the decision over Claude Hammond, 145, Cliffside, N.J., in the main eight-round bout at Fort Hamilton last night.

SEA BRIGHT, N. J., Sept. 28-- A leak in a twelve-inch water main fifteen feet deep on the bed of the Shrewsbury River, between Rumson and Sea Bright, caused a temporary scarcity of water here early today.
With the working absorption of American Overseas Airlines by Pan American World Airways a negotiation which had taken a little more than two years is translated finally into reality.

Calumet Farm's crack race mare Bewitch, who won $213,000 when she was a 2-year-old in 1947, added $3,305 to her earnings at Belmont Park yesterday in scoring her second success in seven 1950 tries. Steve Brooks got the assist.
Houston, Tex., has under consideration a proposal to invite bids on Nov. 8 on an issue of $24,000,000 of water revenue bonds proposed to mature serially from Dec. 1, 1952 to Dec. 1, 1980.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Sept. 28 (AP)--Club-swinging German police drove out 120 reds from the Communist party's Ruhr headquarters today after they had been pelted with ash trays and beer glasses in the basement dining room.

PARIS, Sept. 28--At a meeting of the French Cabinet today, there was reported to have been strong sentiment in favor of urging Washington to postpone the creation of German military units until they could be incorporated into a continental European army.
Commodity futures on the Exchange here yesterday continued downward for the most part as traders refused to make firm commitments pending the outcome of reported Korean peace feelers.

A two-day auction of English and continental furniture and decorations was ended yesterday by the House of Duveen, Inc., of 61 West Fifty-sixth Street.The sale, which was held in a gallery of the Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Company at Third Avenue and Eightieth Street, brought a total of $17,120.

LONDON, Sept. 28--With a fanfare of trumpets, Bernard Cardinal Griffin, Archbishop of Westminster, was ceremoniously received in Westminster Cathedral today as the legate of Pope Pius to the hierarchy centenary congress, marking the 100th anniversary of the restoration of the Roman Catholic hierarchy in England and Wales.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 28-- From the security of the chair he filled at Amherst as head coach and athletic director for so many years, Lloyd Jordan came to Harvard to accept the challenge of revitalizing Crimson football, at its, lowest ebb ever.

Factory sales of household washers in August totaled 381,452 units compared with 282,261 in July, according to the American Home Laundry Manufacturers Association, Chicago. This is an increase of 35.1 per cent over July, and 17.8 per cent higher than the sales of 323,789 units in August, 1949.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 28--The Soviet Union and Poland lodged a protest with the United Nations today against United States action in barring Georges Fischer. He was to be the World Federation of Trade Unions representative in the United Nations General Assembly's Social Committee.

Development of a new machine that automatically vacuum-packs such perishable foods as bacon, cheese and sliced luncheon meats was announced yesterday in Chicago by the Standard Cap and Seal Corporation. Known as the FlexVac machine, it is said to drastically reduce spoilage, preserve food's color and extend the life of the product.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 28-- A reproduction of the world's first telephone exchange, which opened on Jan. 28, 1878 in New Haven's Boardman Building, is one of the featured exhibits in the New Haven Antiques Show that is in session here.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP)--Bobby Riggs outlasted Don Budge tonight to win third prize. in the singles of Wembley Stadium's indoor professional tennis tournament. The scores were 1-6, 6-4, 4--6, 6--4, 6--4.

MANHASSET, L. I., Sept. 28 -Announcement has been made by Mr, and Mrs. Edward Quintin Carr of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Mulqueen, to Dr. John Gerard Finnegan of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Augustine Finnegan of Bangor, Me.
PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 28-- Gen. Clifton B. Cates, Marine Corps commandant, said today the Marine Corps planned to keep its reserves in uniform after the end of the Korean war.

A pair of Louis XV carved walnut chairs made by a master craftsman of the period, Pierre Eloi Langlois, went for $640 yesterday in an auction sale of French and English furniture, paintings and decorations, at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 29--Delegates to the annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States were excited today over a proposal made in Washington which, they believed, would cripple the merchant marine in order to aid the Marshall Plan maritime countries.
LONDON, Sept. 29--The stock markets here were subdued today by restricting week-end influences. The excitement had vanished from the rubber market, which declined early, but recovered later.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 29 (AP)-- William E. Woodward, the author who introduced the word "debunk" into the English language and who created a new technique of biographical writing, died here on Wednesday.

WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 29 (AP)-- Mrs. Betty Bush of Hammond, Ind., an amateur little known in major competition, carded a 2-under-par 73 for a 36-hole total of 149 and the halfway lead today in the Women's National Open $5,000 golf tournament.

Young men in the 19 and 20 year age groups face possible induction into the armed forces by next spring if the present draft quotas and the policy of deferring students are continued, Col. Candler Cobb, New York's Selective Service director, said yesterday.

Because fifty-one city employes taking an "open book" engineering test nearly a year ago elected to answer one or more of five questions for which the answers were readily available, the group is to be re-examined on Oct. 9 on part of the test.
The Finance Ministers of the British Commonwealth, except South Africa, who have been meeting in London have now come up with an agreed plan for Southeast Asia.

PARIS, Sept. 25--The sinking recently of a French weather ship, the frigate Laplace, with a loss of nearly fifty lives, when the vessel was hit by a magnetic mine has brought to public attention the fact that a large part of the French seacoast is considered dangerous for navigation because of mines still scattered all along it.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (AP)-- Syracuse extra-point specialist Bob Koleser missed his first conversion in twenty-five tries tonight to give the Temple Owls a 7-to-6 football victory over the Orangemen before 12,000 at Temple Stadium.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 29--Foreign Minister Dirk U. Stikker, who returned here today from the Atlantic Pact Council meeting, is expected to have to tell the Dutch Government that the Netherlands' contribution to the Western European land forces must be increased.
At long last Ted Collins, a radio man turned gridiron mogul, has a passer to go with his National Football League franchise.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29--A forecast for below-freezing temperatures in Montana, the Dakotas, Minnesota and parts of Wisconsin and possibly northern Iowa brought in fairly general buying of corn, and closing trades were to cent higher.

LONDON, Sept. 29--A draft plan for extensive economic development in Southern Asia has been produced by the ministers of the seven British Commonwealth countries who concluded a fiveday conference in London today. Outsiders who have seen the plan said it seemed to be a good one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--President Truman, speaking for the American people, sent to Gen. Douglas MacArthur today "my warmest congratulations on the victory which has been achieved under your leadership in Korea."
Molly Picon and Eddie Cantor are expected to liven up the weekend by appearances in two offBroadway presentations tonight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 29--One hundred and fifty representatives of New Jersey groups and agencies concerned with young people met today at Rutgers University to review the state's accomplishments in promoting child welfare and to outline needs still to be met.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--Detailed information covering the changes in excise taxes included in the Revenue Act of 1950 were issued today by George J. Schoeneman, Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

Although frost has already blackened dahlias and zinnias in parts of the suburbs, material for Winter bouquets is not a problem for some gardeners. They have been gathering flowers since June and drying them for use this autumn.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 29-- United States athletes broke two Israeli track and field records today in the third world Maccabiah, Jewish equivalent of the Olympic Games, but trailed Israel and South Africa in points.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept, 29-- Harvard University received almost $10,000,000 in gifts for the three months from April 1 through June 30, Dr, James B. Conant announced today.

Both Republican and Democratic candidates for Mayor endorsed the principle of increased pay for city employes last night, but differed sharply on methods of achieving this objective. A formal bid to Communist China to send a representative to the United Nations Security Council on Nov. 15 for hearings on the Formosa question was approved by the Council yesterday at Flushing Meadow.

Belgian Foreign Minister Paul van Zeeland urged yesterday the utmost speed in organization of a unified European defense force, as projected last Tuesday by the North Atlantic Council.

A series of special ceremonies commemorating the 100th anniversary of the establishment of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will be held here during October.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--The Navy reported today that nine Navy enlisted men were dead, five missing and ten injured as the result of a collision between the destroyer Brush and a floating mine off the northeast coast of Korea Sept. 27.

WAYNE TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept, 29--The qualifying round in the New Jersey State Golf Association's best--ball championship resulted in a three-way tie for medal honors over the Preakness Hills Country Club course today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)--A State Department official said today "major attention" was being given to efforts to free Robert A. Vogeler, an American imprisoned in Communist Hungary.

QUEBEC, Sept. 29 (Canadian Press)--The grounding of the Cunard liner Franconia on the Island of Orleans on the evening of July 12 resulted from "a grave error of judgment" on the part of Pilot Edmond Lamontagne, Justice Arthur I. Smith decided in a ruling given here today.
GOETEBORG, Sweden, Sept. 29 --A landslide that followed heavy rains all but wiped out the industrial village of Surte, about ten miles north of here, today. Two persons are known to have been killed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)-- Farm prices rose about 2 per cent between mid-August and mid-September to a level 9 per cent above that prevailing before fighting started in Korea.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 29 --Lieut, Gov. Joe R. Hanley, Republican candidate for the Senate, declared tonight that the people of the country were "fed up" with the "blunders" of President Truman and the Democratic Administration.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)-- President Truman has signed a bill authorizing sale of ten Government-owned ships for use in restoring a package freight service on the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence River.
TAEGU, Korea, Sept. 29--Thousands of North Korean soldiers, stranded on hills and in valleys by the ebb of the invasion, tide, will be a problem in South Korea for, a long time to come.

BOSTON, Sept. 29--"Tremendous." That seemed the only word in the entire English language that could express Casey Stengel's feelings and those of his players tonight as the Yankees, idle for the day, found themselves in possession of their second successive American League pennant and the seventeenth in the history of the club.
The Western Union Telegraph Company completed arrangements yesterday to borrow $12,000,000 for five years at 3 per cent from a group of New York banks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29--Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall today directed the Navy to order up enough of its medical reserve officers without prior service to meet immediate requirements of all three branches of service.

The Board of Regents' report made public this week shows that discriminatory practices in admitting high school students to colleges and universities have decreased sharply during the last four years.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 1--Nassau County Police today broadcast a fourteen-state alarm describing nineteen items of jewelry, said to be worth $51,550, that were stolen here last night from the home of Rufus W. Scott on Feeks Lane in the Lattingtown estate section of this village.

Inflation, the N.A.M. emphasized, must be recognized as an international menace as well as a threat to this country's domestic economy.

HENRY GREEN, the anonymous English manufacturer who writes books in his spare time, an hour each evening, is a coterie writer if there ever was one--which means that he writes peculiar, artificially mannered novels of limited appeal which are extravagantly overpraised by a few critics whose pride it is to admire books which lesser mortals don't appreciate. So far only three of Mr. Green's books have been published in this country.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1--For the first time since they were assembled in 1946 by canny Paul Brown, the mighty Cleveland Browns today suffered the humiliation of a shut-out. Kingpins of the defunct All-America Conference for four years and apparently headed toward similar dominance in the National Football League, the Browns were blanked, 6--0, by Steve Owen's New York Giants in one of the all-time great upsets.

The 75-year-old Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was rededicated yesterday to a "new era" of spiritual ministry to the people of New York.

The 1950 convention of the American Bankers Association, held in this city last week, marked the seventy-fifth renewal of that annual event. It was at Saratoga Springs, N.Y., in 1875, that the A.B.A. held its first official conclave.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1--This city's three newspaper plants were struck tonight by the Mailers' Union Local 22, A.F.L., to enforce demands for a wage increase of at least $1 a day. Also at issue was continuance of a sixth-day work week and no contract.

Summer gave New York a repeat performance yesterday. In a form reversal as unexpected as the Dodgers' short-lived bid for the National League pennant, the temperature soared to 88.4 degrees at 3:45 P. M., a record high for the date. The previous record of 88.3 for Oct. 1 was recorded in 1881.
The large-scale Russian jamming of the Voice of America broadcasts may have applications that could be of considerable military importance in time of war.

BERLIN, Oct. 1--Harold Wilson, President of the British Board of Trade, and Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Economics Minister, formally exchanged documents today concluding a billion-dollar trade treaty.

The New York City Opera's performance of "Carmen" yesterday afternoon went on nearly as scheduled. The "nearly" involved the title role. On Saturday Winifred Heidt, who was to have sung Carmen, became indisposed. The only replacement available was the Metropolitan Opera's Regina Resnik, who stepped into the part with virtually no rehearsal.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1-- Paul Henreid, actor-producer, and Edward Nassour of Nassour Pictares, Inc., have formed an independent film company, H.-N. Productions, to make screen features based on topical subjects.

Retail stores were returning to selective buying last week, having already purchased what they consider to be ample stock, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Some softening of prices day occur on items that were increased too much.
St. Ignatius' Protestant Episcopal Church, Eighty-seventh Street and West End Avenue, was host yesterday to a modern pioneer. He is the Rev. H.B. Liebler, missionary to the Navajo Indians in Utah.

Last week's foreign exchange market had completed its cycle of trading limits--five days, Monday to Friday--when late on the latter day an Ottawa dispatch disclosed that the Canadian Government had instructed banks to suspend dealings in foreign exchange until further notice, pending a study of the situation by the Canadian Cabinet.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 1--The North Korean Communists' three months occupantion of this capital city was a period of reprisal, confusion and disorganization, according to Koreans who watched closely the Communist conduct of affairs.
Bonds called before maturity for payment in September rose sharply from the month before as a result of large refundings in the public utility field.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 1--The great Danbury Fair--abounding as usual in culinary and agricultural wonders and with special emphasis on merrymaking--rolled into high gear today on the second day of its nine-day run. When dusk fell, fair officials announced that a record crowd of 35,000 men, women and children had passed through the gates.

ALBANY, Oct. 1--The need for a full-scale drive on water pollution in New York State has become more imperative than ever because of the threat of atomic attack, which would cause widespread contamination of water supplies, Assemblyman Harold C. Ostertag declared today.

Asserting that the actions of the Republicans in New York and the Democrats on measures to ban racial discrimination were in sharp contrast, Governor Dewey urged a Negro audience yesterday afternoon to support Republican candidates.

BENA, Va., Oct. 1--Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Pratt of Little England, and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary, to Corbin Braxton Valentine Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine of Richmond.
Garry Davis, former bomber pilot who renounced his United States citizenship to become "world citizen No. 1," made known yesterday that he wanted to become an American again, and as soon as possible.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)-- Operation of the Panama Canal on a pay-as-you-go basis at tolls of 95 cents a ton is forecast by Government economists as the result of a reorganization bill signed into law last week by President Truman.

Carlton Ellis Jr. has been named manager of the newly created coating resins department of the Plaskon division, Libbey-OwensFord Glass Company, Toledo, Ohio. C. Homer Flynn has resigned as sales manager for coating resins.

The first of the "Five Enchanted Evenings," a series of theatre parties for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service, will take place tonight at the Lyceum Theatre.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson urged yesterday that the United Nations pool all its technical skill to assist in the reconstruction of Korea when hostilities cease.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 1-- The Finnish Government has become involved in a dispute with the Soviet Union over the insistence of the Aaland Islanders to retain a defunct League of Nations guarantee of their home rule in the amplified redraft of the 1921 Aaland statute.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 1--After conferring today with Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion on matters concerning Israel's position in event of world war, Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, who is here as a member of a Congressional committee, declared he would recommend military and any other aid this country required.

The first Marine Corps air reserve squadron to be called to active duty from this area--VMF232--got away from Floyd Bennett Naval Air Base early yesterday morning with the clocklike precision of marines--and by their own airlift.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (AP)-- Right Halfback V.T. Smith from Abilene Christian raced 94 yards with a third period kick-off today to break up a tie and start the Los Angeles Rams on their way to a decisive 35-to-14 victory over the San Francisco Forty-niners. A crowd of 27,654 saw the local club lose its third successive National Football League game.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)--Joe Geri's passing and kicking paced the alert Pittsburgh Steelers to a 26-7 National Football League victory over the Washington Redskins today.

Louise Barnes Gallagher--it is her pattern in The American Designer Series that is offered today --has had an unusual career. Professionally it began when, as a young girl, she modeled for a large wholesale dress house. Fashionwise it started when, as a little girl, she sewed for her dolls and made her own clothes.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Monday, Oct. 2 (AP)--A French military spokesman said today a French column occupied Thainguyen, Communist communications hub in North Indo-China, at 5 P. M., Sunday (5 A. M., Sunday, Eastern Standard Time).

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 1 (AP)-- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias won her second women's national open golf tournament today with a fiveunder-par 70 for a seventy-two-hole score of 291, tying the record for the event.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (AP)--A roaring crowd estimated by police at upward of 25,000 packed two railroad stations tonight to greet the victorious Phillies on their return home.

Manhattan rapidly is being transformed into forbidden ground for middle-income families who neither can afford today's high rents in the free market nor qualify for admission to subsidized public housing.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 1 (AP) --An alert Green Bay Packer eleven halted the previously unbeaten Chicago Bears with three third-quarter touchdowns today, winning the National Football League game, 31--21, before 24,893 fans in City Stadium.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1-- Judy Garland, whose release from a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer contract that still had more than a year to run was announced on Friday, said today that she would not return to the screen for at least eight or nine months and possibly longer.
OTTAWA, Oct. 1--No predictions are being made as to the exchange rate at which the Canadian dollar will emerge tomorrow evening from its first day's experience of finding its own level.
TORQUAY, England, Oct. 1-- The international tariff conference has got off to a "good start," officials said today.

BOSTON, Oct. 1--With all four positions in the first division of the American League indelibly set for the records before even a ball was tossed, the Yankees finally got around to relaxing on this closing day of the campaign and, as with most everything else they do, they made a thorough job of it.

In reply to Representative Walter A. Lynch, Democratic candidate for Governor, and other leading Democrats, who have been demanding an explanation of what has become of the state's post-war reconstruction fund, William L. Pfeiffer, Republican State Chairman, made public yesterday a breakdown of appropriations of $801,839,000 for the state's capital construction fund for 1944 to 1951.
Polish-Americans of the New York area unwound a bright, brassy fourteenth annual Pulaski Day Parade--part light-hearted folk festival, part anti-Russian demonstration--up Fifth Avenue yesterday.
Extension of its television network facilities to fourteen more cities, and seven others by privately owned relays and cables, has been announced by the Bell System.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--The Government prepared today to order that industries give priority on materials and plant capacity to the military.
