Their suddenly resurgent heroes would overtake the faltering Phils in the final game of the season, beat them in the play-off and wind up in the world series after all.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 1--Western European industrial productivity, now at post-war record levels after two years of Marshall Plan aid, is to be spurred as a major counter to the threat of lower living standards posed by the Continent's rearmament plans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)--National parks are growing ever more popular, but visitors are becoming bitter about their state of repair, the House Public Lands Committee said today.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1--The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the International Union of Electrical Workers, C.I.O., reached an agreement today on a contract providing a 10-cent-anhour pay increase and $100 a month noncontributory pensions covering 50,000 employes. The agreement is for one year and can be reopened for wages after six months.

This department leaves it to the critics to appraise the painting and sculpture displayed at Rowantrees Pavilion, an art gallery that opened in Blue Hill, Me., last summer. But about one of its sidelines, cakes and breads baked for mail order shipment, there is no such hesitation. They are superb.
William James Timberman, formerly a leader in the sand and gravel industry in the metropolitan area, died on Saturday in his home at 526 West Saddle River Road, Ridgewood, N.J. He was 84 years old.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Oct. 1 --Greater state and local aid to education is needed to rescue the state's public schools from their present financial crisis, delegates at the sixty-eighth annual meeting of the Council of School Superintendents warned today.
BERLIN, Oct. 1--President Truman, in a message to the people of Berlin, emphasized today that the "one great desire" of the United States was to bring a just and lasting peace to the world.

LONDON, Oct. 1--Nearly 100,000 Roman Catholics, one of the largest Catholic assemblies in Britain in modern times, attended spectacular ceremonies in Wembley Stadium today marking the end of a week of thanksgiving for the restoration of the Catholic Hierarchy in England and Wales 100 years ago.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1--The declaration by Chinese Premier Chou that the Korean people, through "tactics of a prolonged war of resistance" would win final victory was published today by all central Soviet newspapers.

Last March, Eddie Cantor titillated a throng of his adherents at Carnegie Hall with a single performance of his one-man show, "Forty Years in Show Business," which, as the title implies, touched on many aspects of his remarkable career in the American theatre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--Cordell Hull, the former Secretary of State, will be 79 years old tomorrow but he says the day will be spent just as 364 others are during the course of the year--"watching events from the sidelines."

BERLIN, Oct. 1--About 1,500 arrests were reported in Western Germany today, many of them "preventive" arrests, as Communist demonstrators had limited success in causing the disturbances they had threatened in the name of peace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP)--A highly responsible Government economist said today that continued price increases by business were "moving" the nation toward compulsory price and wage controls that otherwise might not be needed.

Troops of the R. O. K. (Republic of Korea) Capital Division were reported thirty miles north of Pyongchang yesterday morning and continuing north against light scattered resistance. Leading elements of the R. O. K. Sixth Division were in the Hongchon vicinity at midday and still moving north.

Large flotations of securities for Home Loan and Intermediate Credit Banks lifted the total of bonds offered publicly here in September to $705,118,000 for fortyseven issues from $448,843,000 for sixty-nine issues in the preceding month and from $561,072,000 for sixty-two issues in September, 1949.
Ralph K. Jacobs, former Assistant Kings County District Attorney and head of the county's "rackets bureau," died Saturday evening at the age of 72.

A joint program to eliminate the causes of justified consumer complaints against subscription book companies through the maintenance of ethical advertising an selling practices was announced over the week-end by the Association of Better Business Bureaus.
Developments in Korea probably reduce the chances of attack on Yugoslavia. Since the reckless probing operation in Asia struck hard steel, fewer incidents have been reported on the Yugoslav frontier.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 1--The Netherlands Bank last week raised the official discount rate by one half to 3 per cent--the first alteration since June, 1941. Increase does not mean an alteration in the cheap Monday policy but to halt...

Pity the Old Blues. All across the land there's wailing and moaning over the ruination of the football season for sectional leaders even before the public has been able to give scarcely a thought to the start of the pigskin parade in the heart of baseball's pennant races.

Cy Harrice, radio and television announcer, has purchased for occupancy the five-story residence on lot 20 by 100 feet at 49 East Ninety-first Street through Frances R. Jaffin, broker. The tax valuation is $52,000.

Well grounded in the folklore of ancient Greece, the industrious Maxwell Anderson, who isn't content to rest on his laurels, has just put the finishing touches to a play --said to be mostly in a humorous vein--in which the leading character is Socrates and not Sophocles, as incorrectly rumored.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 1 (AP)--Baltimore shelled Columbus pitchers for four home runs and an 8-1 victory to square the Little World Series at one game apiece today.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 1--Beset by strikes and inflation worries 2,500,000 Finns went to the polls today to select some 11,500 city, town and communal officials for the next two-year period. Voting continues until Monday evening when the tally starts.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1--Last week was a sad one for many steel users. They were in the process of having their quotas cut for October. Some were seeing their shipping promises cut as much as 25 per cent--others more. The worst part for them was that in November they might not fare any better.

In its first change of ownership in more than fifty years, the threeand-one-half-story brick dwelling on lot 25 by 180 feet at 54 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Mrs. Edward Haynes to Lincoln W. Lauterstein for occupancy.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 1 --Peg's Pride, a 9-year-old veteran campaigner owned by the host stable, continued to hold his place as one of the top hurdlers hereabouts by capturing the open jumper championship at the annual horse show held at the Hutchinson farms today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1--The ten Democratic Senators, who unsuccessfully urged their colleagues to vote to sustain President Truman's veto of the McCarran Communistcontrol bill (the Internal Security Act of 1950) today called for the law's repeal or its drastic modification. They seek action when Congress meets again on Nov. 27.

The term to which Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy was appointed by Acting Mayor Impellitteri last Tuesday will expire Feb. 21, 1951, according to a legal opinion on file at City Hall. It was believed, however, in political circles that he would continue in office after that date if he desired, regardless of the outcome of the mayoralty election on Nov. 7.
Leopold Schwarzschild, antiNazi German editor and author, has died in Santa Margherita, Italy, according to word received here yesterday by his wife, Valerie. His age was 58.
Reports from several Asiatic Communist sources indicate that preparations for prolonged guerrilla warfare against United Nations forces have been under way in Korea for more than three months.

SPARTA, N.J., Oct. 1--Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. Edwin S. Ford of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Vail, to Peter Campbell Moore, son of Dr. and Mrs. Sherwood Moore of St. Louis.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS; Korea, Oct. 1--Meeting no enemy resistance, South Korean troops crossed the Thirtyeighth Parallel this morning and by mid-afternoon had moved more than a mile into territory that was under Communist rule before the war began on June 25.

To the strains of Auld Lang Syne and with the satisfaction of a Giant victory over the Boston Braves, the curtain was lowered on the baseball season at the Polo Grounds yesterday before 9,446 onlookers, who had to be in on the finish of a campaign which saw Leo Durocher's squad safely home in third place.

Observing that "it is one thing to be blessed with faith and another thing to make that faith practical," the Rev. Michael J. Deacy of St. Patrick's Cathedral staff declared yesterday that Catholics made practical demonstration of their faith when they sympathized with and relieved the sufferings of human beings.

The military program to which the United States has committed itself makes a peacetime economy impossible again so long as armament remains the only hope for peace in the world, Leo Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, said yesterday.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 1 (AP)--Cincinnati and Pittsburgh rounded out the season's play today by splitting a double-header, the Reds taking the opener, 3 to 2, then dropping the finale, 3--1.

Of all the special "weeks" set aside for one or another purpose in the remaining year, none can be more worthy of thought than this week of Oct. 1-7, designated by Governor Dewey as Employ the Handicapped Week.
PARIS, Oct. 1--Pierre-Olivier Lapie, French Minister of National Education, today presided at the dedication of an Alpine peak observatory built to house what will be Europe's largest telescope.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 1--The Soviet Union and its supporters in the United Nations are prepared to open fire here tomorrow on an eight-nation proposal for the re-establishment of a unified Korea that tacitly approves the crossing of the Thirty-eighth Parallel by United Nations forces.
The domestic steel and aluminum industries, which provide American industry with the principal raw materials for production in war or peace, expect to establish production records this year.

A lot could and should happen during thirty-six hours in a postwar Berlin theatre crammed with several thousand displaced persons awaiting transportation under the sole supervision of a British officer and his aide.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal nominee for reelection, will open his campaign with a state-wide radio broadcast at 6 o'clock this evening over the Columbia Broadcasting System network, with WCBS as the New York outlet.
New York State employers will receive no relief from unemployment insurance taxes next year, even though the number of jobless workers is at the lowest level since V-J Day.
HONG KONG, Oct. 1--Millions of Chinese participated today in parades and demonstrations marking the first anniversary of the Communist-dominated Chinese People's Republic.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange increased slightly last month from the previous month and was the largest for any September since 1946. The volume of business for the first nine months of this year, amounting to $373,504,783 shares, was the heaviest for any similar period in seventeen years, or since 1933.

Noteworthy on this week's metropolitan art calendar are openings of three new galleries. For its initial exhibition today the Ganso Gallery, 125 East Fifty-seventh Street, has a group show of paintings, sculpture and ceramics.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (UP)--Chou Enlai, Chinese Communist Premier, warned today his country "will not stand aside" if North Korea was invaded. As Mr. Chou spoke in Peiping, United Nations forces rolled across the Thirty-eighth Parallel into North Korea. Mr. Chou did not, however, say flatly that China's army would fight in Korea.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1--Grain prices held within comparatively narrow limits on the Board of Trade last week with the markets irregular, wheat and oats averaging lower and corn somewhat higher, the latter being affected by light frost a week ago and a forecast indicating that the growing season will be brought to a close in the more northern sections of the belt.

Stengel today scouted the report that he already had received a two-year contract calling for an annual stipend of $75,000. Not only has he signed no new contract, declared Casey, but he hasn't even discussed the proposition with either of the Yankee co-owners, Dan Topping or Del Webb.

LONDON, Oct. 1--War and peace sometimes have rather unexpected reactions in the financial world. Normally one would expect that ending of a war, especially one charged with such dangerous possibilities as that in Korea, would be followed by a sharp rise in the stock markets. But just the reverse has occurred.

The Philadelphia Whiz Kids, who came so close to winning the ignominious title of the Fizz Kids, captured the first National League pennant for the Quaker City in thirty-five years when they beat the Dodgers, 4--1, yesterday at Ebbets Field before the greatest outpouring of Flatbush fans--35,073--of the 1950 season.

WARRENTON, Va., Oct. 1-- Miss Sally Hoxton Spilman, daughter of Mrs. William Henry Pool of Warrenton, and Baldwin Day Spilman of Palm Beach, Fla., was married here yesterday in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church to Maximilian Agassiz Tufts, son of Mrs. Walter Tufts of Yarmouth Port, Mass., and the late Mr. Tufts. The Rev. Paul D. Bowden, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 1 --Niagara University scored in every quarter this afternoon to rout Brooklyn College 34--0, before 6,500, the largest opening day crowd in Niagara history, at Varsity Stadium.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 2--South Korean troops yesterday crossed the Thirty-eighth Parallel, old boundary line between the Korean Republic and the Communist state to the north. Meanwhile United States Marines moved up to within ten miles of the border, near the city of Munsan, north of liberated Seoul.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1--For the last four days Argentine officials have been trying to wipe out what is considered an insult to the national honor by a young English schoolmaster--the smashing of a plaster bust of General San Martin.
As expected in the food industry, a definite lull in sales has developed at both wholesale and re-- tail levels, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, reported last week.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1--James Roosevelt this week-end loosed throughout California 250,000 copies of a comic-book biography of himself aimed at marshaling support in his campaign for Governor.

The Irish Americans of Kearny, N.J., after winning two straight in the American Soccer League, sustained their first setback yesterday at Sterling Oval, where the New York Americans defeated them, 1 to 0. LONDON, Oct. 1--Canada's decision to restore forthwith complete freedom to its foreign exchange market, which means that the Canadian dollar will now move to its natural level in terms of other currencies, has not come as a surprise in the London market. What may occasion some surprise is the decision completely to free exchange with one stroke rather than proceed toward that end by a gradual process.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 1-- The marriage of Miss Patricia Louise Law, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hervey F. Law of Syosset, to Leonard Daniel Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Frewen Wilson of Brookeville, Md., took place this afternoon in the Oyster Bay Reformed Church.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct, 1--In a masterful exhibition of polo that brooked little or no defense, Bob Skene, eight-goal internationalist, led California to a 9-5 victory over Bostwick Field today in the final of the Twenty-fourth Monty Waterbury Memorial handicap tournament on International Field of the Meadow Brook club.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--Dr George Hill, University of Wisconsin sociologist, recommended today that Midwest farmers abandon sugar beet growing.

Observers here regard unemployment as the fundamental Italian problem. Inadequacy in dealing with it is considered as an indirect advantage to the Communists.

TEHERAN, Iran. Oct. 2--Max Thornberg, chief of a twelve-man American mission consulting on Iran's seven-year plan, has expressed dissatisfaction with the way the plan is being carried out and has reported that several mission members were withdrawing and returning to the United States, according to an interview in the daily newspaper Keihang.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--A second United States destroyer, the U.S.S. Mansfield, was disclosed today to have been damaged by floating mines off the Korean coast. Seven enlisted men aboard the Mansfield, struck Saturday northeast of the eastern city of Changjon, were injured.

The Jefferson School of Social Science, the principal training center for Communists and Communist sympathizers in this city, announced yesterday that a veil of anonymity would surround its students from now on. The announcement came ten days after passage of the new Internal Security Act requiring Communists to register.
In comparing the Yankees and Phillies as they square away for the 1950 world series, two points stand out like the white poles on the ends of the foul lines.

Frederick Brown has purchased the seventeen-story office building at 117 Liberty Street from the Roebling Building Company. John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker in the sale, arranged a self-liquidating twenty-year first mortgage on the property.

MARGATE, England, Oct. 2-- The conference of the Labor party, which during this week will point the direction of Britain's governmental party, opened placidly here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (AP)-- The threat of a strike against fifteen major Philadelphia hotels was withdrawn tonight.

PARIS, Oct. 2--Before leaving for the United States, Jean Desses will inaugurate midseason openings.
MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (AP)--Premier Stalin has received an appeal raising critical questions concerning Formosa.
Mrs. Florence L. Stokes Clark, wife of F. Ambrose Clark of Broad Hollow House, Westbury, L.I., one of the leading American horsewomen, died unexpectedly ...

A wide-eyed owl, an elongated dog with claws in place of legs, and a singing bird perched on a flowering tree were the unusual motifs in a fabric design that won a first prize in a recent competition arranged by Julore.

Further inflationary factors, a new spurt in industrial production and assorted corporate news that ranged from favorable dividend actions to rumors of stock splits combined to give the stock market yesterday its biggest rise since mid-July.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 (AP)--Marty Marion said tonight that Commissioner A.B. Chandler had refused to have a conference with him and Freddie Hutchinson about the world series television rights of the players.
Award of a new issue of $6,300,000 of revenue bonds to finance construction of the state of Colorado's Denver-Boulder Turnpike was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--The Soviet Union rejected today a United States request for further information about German prisoners of war still in Russian hands, charging the demand was being made "for propaganda purposes."

Joe Louis, whose comeback was blasted by Ezzard Charles, revealed at a press conference at the International Boxing Club offices yesterday that he had changed his mind about the permanent retirement he announced immediately after his defeat by Charles.
Radio and television representatives voted yesterday to appoint a committee to seek ways of assuring security against subversive elements and at the same time preserving individual liberties.

Wholesalers and jobbers from Western states and Canada set a new record in the volume of orders placed on an opening day, according to exhibitors at the National Hardware Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday.

Failure of the owners, managers and operators of large buildings in New York to prepare plans for defense against bombing is causing serious concern to Arthur W. Wallander, city director of civil defense.

HONG KONG, Oct. 2--The South Korean drive across the Thirtyeighth Parallel, coming on the heels of the Chinese Communists' warning that they would "not tolerate" attacks on their "neighbors," drew attention today to im portant economic as well as political and military stakes of the Peiping regime in North Korea.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 3 (AP)-- Lieut. Gen. George E. Stratemeyer, commander of the Far East Air Force, said today that Allied planes had destroyed or damaged more than 1,000 North Korean tanks in a continuing air war.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--Consumer credit set a record in August, when it reached $20,979,000,000, according to the Federal Reserve Board.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 2--Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, presented today to the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly a series of alleged captured documents in an all-out effort to prove that North Korea had been attacked by South Korea with the connivance of the United States.

The seventh Assembly District Democratic Club, headed by Robert B. Blaikie, formally bolted the Mayoralty candidacy of Ferdinand Pecora, the Democratic-Liberal Party nominee, last night and voted to support the independent candidacy of Acting Mayor Impellitteri.
Thomas J. Donovan, general counsel of Licensed Beverage Industries, Inc., declared yesterday that business taxes might be increased inequitably.

The controversy over the relative cost of electricity to the user of public power and the user of private power was spotlighted yesterday as the report of the Electric Power Board of Chattanooga was made public.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J., Oct. 2 --Just as darkness was settling down, Mario Cafagno and Andy Kalfut of Lake Mohawk came in to win the pro-amateur best ball tournament of the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association with a 4-under-par 32, 34--66, over the nine-hole course of the Canary Cottage Golf Club today.

MALVERNE, L.I., Oct. 2--A grade crossing accident, in which a sedan was struck by a Long Island Rail Road passenger train and dragged 500 feet, resulted in the death of a man and a woman at the busy Ocean Avenue crossing here today.

WITH PRESIDENT TRUMAN IN CHESAPEAKE BAY, Oct. 2-- President Truman read about the Battle of Gettysburg this morning and took a long nap this afternoon as he cruised restfully up and down Chesapeake Bay.
Despite shortages and price increases in paper, producers of direct mail material expressed confidence yesterday that mobilization activities will stimulate a greater volume for the medium.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--In a formal statement on his seventyninth birthday, Cordell Hull, former Secretary of State, admonished today that "grave difficulties and dangers still confront us on all sides."

William McC. Cameron, vice chairman of the board of directors and a member of the executive committee of the Celanese Corporation of America, 180 Madison Avenue, died yesterday afternoon in his apartment at the Ritz Tower Hotel, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, after an illness of six months.

Materials considered least likely to be affected by defense production were predominant yesterday as the annual Premiums and Ad Specialties Exposition opened for five days at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park-Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
DELHI, N.Y., Oct. 2.--Governor Dewey declared today that disclosure of corruption in New York City had demonstrated that the Democratic party could not be trusted with the state government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--A priorities system devised "to assure that defense production has the right of way," was announced today by the National Production Authority. It goes into effect tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2--The explosive force of this city's celebration over its first National League pennant in thirty-five years had diminished today, but the old town still is jumping.

Dr. and Mrs. Vincenzo Fanoni of 655 Park Avenue have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Teresa Ann, to Ralph Steiner Hurd, son of Mrs. Steiner Booty Hurd of 36 Sutton Place South and East Hampton, L.I., and Arthur M. Hurd of Washington.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct.--Little groups of people today crawled over the sandy, boulder strewn sides of Songbok Hill on the eastern edge of this city to gaze at the mutilated, grotesquely sprawled bodies of thirty-five men, women and children slain in one of the most brutal atrocities the Communists committed during the occupation of Seoul.

In celebration of the founding twenty-five years ago of the Schomburg Collection, the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, placed on exhibition yesterday a cross-section of its wealth of Negro literature, history and the arts.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Oct. 2--Al Brosch of Cherry Valley added another golfing honor to his list when he finished 5 under par for two rounds to retain his Long Island Professional Golf Association championship at the Cold Spring Country Club today.

Private builders, privately financed, are unable under present market conditions to produce new housing in Manhattan for families of moderate income.

New Yorkers basked yesterday in the mellow sunshine of the sceond consecutive Indian summer-like day. Late vacationists reaped the bounty of the near-perfect weather, which lured unusually large weekday crowds to parks, wayside benches and beaches as the temperature climbed to a high of 84.1 degrees at 2:59 P.M.

Facilities to supply this city with 240,000,000 gallons of water a day by motor carriers in an emergency were described yesterday at the opening session of the seventeenth annual convention of the American Trucking Associations at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Deep-throated engines roared in Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx all day yesterday as motor highway glamour boys drove massive trucks and trailers in delicate maneuvers in the annual National Truck Roadeo.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 2-- Three Presidential candidates bolstered their victory predictions with figures today as Brazilians prepared to go to the polls tomorrow in national, state and local elections.

Billy Rose has landed on his feet in television. His first show last night on the A.B.C. network (9 P. M.) was a superior mood piece that had all the intrigue and unexpected twists of the byways of Broadway.

STOCKTON, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP)-- Threatened with a ban by the mighty Pacific Coast Conference, the College of the Pacific today announced it intends to conform to Conference athletic eligibility rules by next year.

An extensive use of advertising, to explain shortages linked to the mobilization program was seen by advertising officials yesterday as an immediate major part of the expected over-all campaign in behalf of national unity in defense.

Developments in Britain's economy these days show the typical blessings and curses of an inflationary strain. MOSCOW, Oct. 3--The Soviet press used most of its editorial and news content today in behalf of a more intensive struggle for maintenance of world peace and the thwarting of "American warmongers."

The United States Employment Service is aiming to reduce civilian unemployment from the latest reported total of 2,300,000 to 1,000,000 by July 1, 1951, Arthur W. Motley, assistant director, revealed yesterday.

The stock market paused yesterday to take an accounting, of the international and domestic economic situations. Traders apparently found them a bit blurred, for, after the robust market of Monday prices turned easier and closed mixed.

Uncle Miltie handed form players at Belmont Park pretty much of a jolt yesterday when he won the Mate purse. The son of Heather Broom was thought to have a good chance for second, but so far as the victory was concerned there appeared no doubt about it at all.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 3-- The plight of the cerebral palsied child who finds public schools closed to him, and his numerical weight in the population, were a uppermost in discussions today at the annual meeting of the New York State Association for Crippled Children.
BERLIN, Oct. 3--A member of the United States Congress described today a dangerous trip into the forbidden Russian Army area and said he had had a peek at secret new Soviet weapons.

The two-for-one split of the common stock of the General Motors Corporation, approved on Sept. 27 by the corporation's stockholders, became effective yesterday when General Motors filed and recorded in Delaware the certificate of amendment of its certificate of incorporation.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3--The afternoon Sun-Telegraph and Press suspended publication today "until further notice" as the wage strike of American Federation of Labor mailing room employes went into the third day with the outlook dim for an early break.

An Oregonian whose hobby is growing giant filberts on his farm near Portland dropped in for a visit with this department yesterday. He was J. Earl Jones, who described himself as "head of the P. C. Hand Forged Tool Company but, in my spare time, a scientific farmer."

WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 3-- Ed Douglas, stepping in as varsity coach after piloting the junior varsity for fifteen years, has a green Taft School football team which includes only four lettermen, but Douglas is far from discouraged.
The cotton futures market turned slightly easier yesterday, and final prices were 9 to 32 points net lower than on Monday, with the weakness most pronounced in old-crop months.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--Liquid savings of Americans dropped during the second quarter of this year but their non-liquid savings, notably investments in homes, was considerably higher than the average rate for the last several years, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 3--Representative Walter A. Lynch, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, charged here tonight that Governor Dewey "not only tolerated but condoned gambling" in Republican areas of New York State.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 4-- United States planes dropped a circle of bombs yesterday around Wonsan, key North Korean base, and attacked convoys coming from the north as South Korean troops captured Kosong, fifty miles north of the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--The Far Eastern Commission brought Japan a step closer to self-government today by giving Japanese courts criminal jurisdiction over most nationals of United Nations governments residing in that country.

TORQUAY, England, Oct. 3-- The Schuman plan for establishing a "community" of the iron, steel and coal industries of six Continental European countries is going to have a rough time in the course of its first examination by the nonparticipating governments.

Esther Glazer, the first of this season's Walter W. Naumburg Award winners to make her debut, was heard yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, playing an exceedingly difficult program of violin music. As is usually the case with Naumburg winners, a carefully screened lot, Miss Glazer played with intelligence and technical command.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3--Paul Ricca and Louis Campagna, paroled from a Federal penitentiary in 1947, were back in jail tonight. They were to be held while State's Attorney John S. Boyle checks on their accounts of what they were doing the night William Drury and Marvin J. Bas, a lawyer, were murdered.

ALBANY, Oct. 3--Gov. Dewey pressed today his attack on Tammany Hall and Edward J. Flynn, the Bronx Democratic leader, taking for iris text the report released Sunday showing irregularities in purchasing for New York City schools.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 3--An ordinance requiting the registration of Communists and members of other organizations deemed subversive was introduced at a meetting of the City Commission today by Mayor John V. Kenny and passed on the first reading.

LONDON, Oct. 3--In the year that has passed since the devaluation of the pound sterling, the gold and dollar reserves of the sterling area have doubled. They now stand at the highest figure since before the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, accused the State Department today of conspiring with Britain to implement "a blueprint of Communist appeasement" aimed at admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 3--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, United States delegate, today hailed the political advances made by women since the United Nations' beginning five years ago and maintained that the standards set by the charter had helped speed the attainment of full suffrage rights throughout the world.
Ferdinand Pecora, the Democratic and Liberal party candidate for Mayor, released yesterday a telegram to President Truman urging the President to take immediate action to control rising price levels.

As part of a crackdown on restaurants that ignore Sanitary Code principles in the preparation of food, the Department of Health has mapped a program to educate chefs in the thorough cooking of all dishes containing pork.

A critical shortage of replacement tubes for radio and television receivers has been growing steadily worse in recent weeks. Amateur technicians who like to make their own repairs sometimes must go from store to store in a hunt for the right tube to put their sets back into operation.

Fordham is gradually reaching a peak similar to that gained before its meeting with Army's eleven a year ago, Coach Ed Danowski admitted yesterday as he directed a two-hour scrimmage, the longest and last of the week, in preparing for the important Yale game at the Bowl on Saturday.
Duties on some West German exports to the United States may increase as a result of reconsideration of the basis of appraisal for duty here. The change would affect shipments leaving Germany Oct. 13.

A voluntary health program whereby women can reduce the death rate in breast cancer by setting up detection clinics in their own homes was opened yesterday by the women's division of the New York City Cancer Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Government priorities just announced for war production materials will not cut into trade dealers' orders through the rematerials on a large scale for at least three or four months.
President Truman named a three-man emergency board yesterday to look into the eleven-dayold strike of 2,600 Railway Express Agency drivers in the metropolitan area.
Shortages of paper packaging materials and railroad freight cars make up the two most threatening bottlenecks in marketing products of the nation's distilled spirits industry.

The thirty-six-foot cutter Ituna, which completed the crossing from Dublin to New York under said in fifty-six days, began her journey home last night under the watchful eye of one of her four original crew members. Her eastbound voyage was expected to require nine or ten days.

LAKE SUCCECS, Oct. 3--Condemnation of Rumania, Bulgaria and Hungary for alleged violation of fundamental human rights was linked today in the Special Political Committee of the United Nations Assembly with the delicate question of membership for these three countries.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3--Amid scenes of no little turmoil and confusion, as might well be expected in a city whose National League entry was making its first world series appearance in thirty-five years, it remained for Eddie Sawyer's Phillies to spring the first big surprise of the 190 classic that gets under way in Shibe Park at 1 o'clock tomorrow.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 3--Price rises between April and September have weakened the Air Force's purchasing power by an equivalent of 750 F-86 jet fighter planes in its drive to add 4,428 new aircraft by 1952, a House Armed Services subcommittee was told today by John McCone, Under Secretary for Air.

AS each successive novel appears in this country it becomes increasingly apparent that Joyce Cary is one of the most gifted of living English novelists. His virtuosity in the craft of fiction is formidable. His insight into the inmost deaths of human beings is profound.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3--On the eve of its first National League representation in a world series in thirty-five long years, this city tonight was "sold out" in a couple of varied directions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3-States and municipalities were advised today to make detailed surveys and estimates of their defense requirements for a civilian defense system in which the Federal Government would act chiefly in a planning and advisory capacity.
The City of Buffalo sold yesterday $4,155,000 of general-improvement and school bonds due on Oct. 15, 1951 to 1970, to J.P. Morgan Co., Ins., and associates at a bid of 100.149 for 1.30s.
Isolation and synthesis of a new vitamin of the vitally important B-complex group is announced in The Journal of the American Chemical Society.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 (AP)-- Judge Michael A. Musmanno today produced a bulky sheaf of seized documents he said proved the Communist party in America was a war machine seeking to overthrow the Government.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz yesterday found Michael F. Reardon Jr., recently broken detective, guilty of "brazen contempt" for insisting that he could not identify the ten policemen at the housewarming party of Harry Gross, the bookmaker.

Mr. and Mrs. George M.L. La Branche Jr. of 139 East Seventyninth Street and North Egremont, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle, to Edward Albert Daly, son of Mrs. O. Theodore Hess of Gates Mills, Ohio, and the late Herbert Wallace Daly. The wedding will take place Dec. 2.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 3 --Ways of raising the level of elementary and secondary school instruction in the state, to narrow the gap between school aims and achievements, were discussed here today at the closing session of the annual meeting of the Council of School Superintendents.
Snow-thatched and mellowed in his eightieth year, Richard E. Enright decided yesterday that a Police Commissioner's lot is not a happy one, and never was. He quit the post a quarter-century ago.
CHICAGO, Oct.3--Profit taking resulted in an irregular close in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, with little attention raid to news developments.

Rafael Druian the Russian-born, Cuban and American-trained concertmaster of the Minneapolis Symphony, showed in his first New York recital last night at Town Hall that he is a young violinists whose heart is in the right place.
BOONTON MANOR, N.J., Oct. 3--Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Somerset Hills won the first Women's Metropolitan senior golf championship with a carts of 43, 43--86 over the Knoll Country Club course today.

In case anyone asks you, the hop crop in upstate New York is excellent this year. Those greenish shaggy blossoms from long vines that add flavor and a preservative to beer have been a product of the Empire State for more than a century.

DETROIT, Oct. 3--The wildcat strike of fewer than 1,000 rolling mill workers at the Ford Motor Company, rounding out its second day, threatens to suspend the jobs of 88,000 employes in the Detroit area before the end of the week, Del S. Harder, vice president in charge of manufacturing, said tonight.

What happens to a jet-fighter pilot when he is suddenly exposed to the rarefied atmosphere at 30,000 feet was described yesterday by Lieut. Charles Robert Hearn at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 3-- The United States economic and technical program for Thailandi under the recently concluded ThaiAmerican aid agreement will begin to function this month. A number of basic projects already have been approved by Thai and American officials in joint consultation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)--Ten Missouri and Arkansas private power companies went to court today in an effort to block construction of two government-financed steam-power generating plants in Missouri.

Edward Corsi, Republican candidate for Mayor, combined last night an attack on Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora's record as a prosecutor with a charge that graft and corruption in New York was far more widespread than yet disclosed.

Sol Schindel, operator, resold to a client of Irwin Stein the six-story apartment house for sixty-one families on plot 152 by 100 feet at 835 Riverside Drive, near West 158th Street, for cash over mortga ges amounting to $273,500.

LAKE SUCCESS Oct. 3--Australia quietly brought into the open today the touchy question whether the Government of President Syngman Rhee should take over all Korea, or whether a new government should be constituted under United Nations auspices.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 (AP)--The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company and all its subsidiaries, in trusteeship for seventeen years, today are one step closer to reorganization under a new corporate set-up.

So complete is the understanding between patients in Presbyterian Hospital's premature baby ward and Miss Yvonne Shannon, assistant head nurse, that she expresses their sentiments for them in cartoons.

The Rev. Joseph T. Keating, who had been treasurer of Fordham University for thirty-eight years, died unexpectedly yesterday afternoon in his room on the campus. He was 79 y ars old. Father Keating retired in June, 1948.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3--Two orders, one fixing a maximum percentage of output that a steel producer can be compelled to devote to defense production and the other giving the steel producer a minimum time to adjust operations to priority orders, are due to issue from the National Production Authority soon.

The apartment house at 2800 University Avenue, the Bronx, accommodating eighty families, has been sold by Gerson T. Margolish and William M. Shacknow to the I. M. Holding Company. Sam Rosen was the broker. Title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

The Canadian dollar continued to gain in value against the American dollar in a free market yesterday. In a day of active trading in spot contracts, the Canadian currency unit added about of a cent more to the gain of nearly 4 cents registered on Monday, the first day of freedom from a fixed official rate.

ROME, Oct. 4--Government circles, disconcerted by criticism of Italy's fiscal policy by the Marshall Plan mission here, appeared to have been mollified after James C. Dunn, United States Ambassador, and Premier Alcide de Gasperi had conferred today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 4--The Indonesian Republic's military action against Amboina, the most important of the islands that proclaimed themselves the Republic of the South Moluccas last April, is causing great concern here.

Backing to the full the first military enforcement action of the United Nations for the suppression of armed aggression, the Political Committee of the General Assembly has adopted by an overwhelming majority a resolution which endorses the present operations of the United Nations forces in Korea and calls for a peace settlement that will assure the creation of a united, independent and democratic Korean Government and state.
NEWARK, Oct. 4--Union officials today set 6 A.M. Friday as the time for a strike of 10,000 New Jersey telephone operators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission said today an engineer's failure to follow operating signals led to the railroad wreck near Coshocton, Ohio, Sept. 11 that killed thirtythree Pennsylvania National Guardsmen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--If the ejection of some North Korean invaders of South Korea and the dispersal of others to the hills should be allowed, because of the dispute in the United Nations over what to do next, to fade into a Pyrrhic victory, the United Nations is likely to become a political liability in this country that neither major party will venture much longer to assume.

North Korean Communists were reported reinforcing Wonsan and Pyongyang as South Korean troops drove ten miles farther beyond the Thirty-eighth Parallel. The United States Third Infantry Division arrived in Asia. [1:8; map P. 2.]
Charles I. Mandel, retired Brooklyn builder, who was active in welfare causes in the borough, died Monday night at his home, 570 Ocean Parkway, after an illness of several years. He was 79 Years old.

ST. BONAVENTURE, N.Y., Oct. 4--St. Bonaventure College, a 94-year-old Franciscan institution, formally became St. Bonaventure University today at a convocation attended by church dignitaries and educators.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4--If the reaction of the other Whiz Kids to their opening loss to the Yankees and Vic Raschi's two-hit pitching today is anything approaching that of Jim Konstanty, then the Phils may bounce back and give the Bombers more trouble than they anticipate.

Prices of most commodity futures continued higher on the Exchanges here yesterday, with rubber and tin scoring the largest gains. The volume of trading, except in rubber, however, was comparatively light.

Steel unionists, traveling to a meeting of their wage policy committee in Atlantic City yesterday, found the trains that carried them from Pittsburgh and other steel centers also loaded with eastbound steel executives.

An eleven-minute wire recording of a teacher's refusal to answer nine questions by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, asto whether he was a Communist party member was played into evidence yesterday at the teacher's departmental trial.

The nation's alcoholic beverage control administrators for monopoly states yesterday approved a plan to compile the first national survey of all regulatory practices applying to purchases of alcoholic beverages by minors.

Dr. Howard A. Rusk, associate editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, expressed satisfaction here yesterday over the announcement that President Truman had appointed the committee, which he will head, to advise Selective Service on the drafting of physicians and dentists.
TOKYO, Oct. 4--The Communist army of North Korea today moved to reinforce its threatened positions at Wonsan, on the east coast, and at the capital of Pyongyang, in the west, as United Nations ...

POLAND SPRING, Me., Oct. 4 --Dean Erin N. Griswold of the Harvard Law School asserted tonight that a Supreme Court decision in favor of the State of Connecticut in the so-called Spector case could result in a victory "fraught with great dangers" to the national economy.
The Manhattan matron who hung her Red Cross volunteer uniform at the back of the closet after V-J Day is about to be the target of an urgent appeal to don it again for active duty.
The stock market snapped back yesterday with renewed vigor and resumed its upward trend.

Acting Mayor Impellitteri refused last night the request of Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the City Planning Commission, that he call a special meeting of the Board of Estimate to provide $9,750 for printing 2,000 copies of the Harrison, Ballard Allen report on rezoning the city.

The reluctance of the Atlantic community to stretch its vital strategic lines as far as the Eastern Mediterranean has now been partly overcome. Turkey is to be "associated" with the North Atlantic Treaty organization, and no doubt the association of Greece will soon follow.
Dade County, Fla., yesterday designated Oct. 25 as the date of sale for $12,500,000 or bonds of Special Tax School District No. 1. Dated Dec. 1, 1950, the bonds will come due Dec. 1, 1952 to 1969.

U.S. 8TH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Korea, Thursday, Oct. 5--Intelligence officers reported today five United States officers and between 1,000 and 2,000 Korean civilians had been killed Sunday night at Wonju by North Korean troops.

WOLF LODGE, Clarendon, N.B., Oct. 4--After a ten hour stroll through the spruces and hardwoods with Gil Ogden in search of the elusive deer, which are just as elusive and no less plentiful tonight, we are convinced that we should have come here next month.

A movement is growing in Switzerland to end her stand of neutrality and ally herself on the side of the freedom-loving nations, Mrs. Hiram C. Houghton, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, declared here yesterday.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 4-- New York State is threatened with mounting local taxes under the Republican administration of Governor Dewey, Representative Walter A. Lynch, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, warned here tonight.
PARIS, Oct. 4--The French will be engaged in the next three weeks in a double negotiation with Washington that will affect the whole outlook for the Western defense program.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 4--Two Foreign Ministers sat together in the delegates' lounge this afternoon, left instructions that they were not to be disturbed and talked over a world problem.
It is now three and one half years since I talked with you in a conference at the Kremlin at the conclusion of which you informally invited me to confer again in the future.

From the outside looking in, the new world capital of the United Nations is solid glass, but to many of the employes who have unpacked to stay, the mirrored facades are an optical illusion.

James E. Reardon, a 33-year-old golf-playing former New York City patrolman now living in a substantial house in Westport, Conn., testified for more than two hours yesterday afternoon before the holdover Kings County grand jury investigating relationships between bookmakers and policemen.

Immediate rearmament of Western Germany was urged here yesterday by former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson and Senator Burnet R. Maybank, South Carolina Democrat, as an essential step in the defense of Europe and the Western world.
The New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads have been negotiating with large western railroads in an effort to initiate through coast-to-coast service of complete passenger trains.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 (AP)-- Curt Simmons came home to the Philies today and writhed in despair as his teammates lost a heart-breaking 1-0 game to the Yankees.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Next Move, making her last Eastern appearance of the year, ran off with first money of $20,700 and ran her earnings past the $200,000 mark in the eightieth edition of the Ladies Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. It was easy. She won with fire and a half lengths to spare.
Dudley G. Layman has been appointed executive vice president of William Whitman Company, Inc., textiles concern. In addition to his new duties he will continue as treasurer of the company.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4--the pitching of Big Jim Konstanty was not the only surprise at Shibe Park this afternoon as the world series opened. There was an even more stunning surprise from the crowd. For, notwithstanding the life and death struggle for tickets to the series, seats yawned emptily in sections on the flanks of the outfield through the game.
Increases in highway accidents could become a serious impediment to national defense, Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Under-Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, declared here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 4--Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that if a United Nations Commission were formed to study the problem of Formosa, it should be empowered to visit the island and Communist China and consult whoever it deemed necessary.

Showings by two designers yesterday centered on festive millinery for holiday wear. At his East Fifty-third Street salon Walter Florell featured two-color felt hats, silhouettes with front width, saucy designs with sweeping feather trims, lilting little creations to wear with high-collared coats and an enchanting series for evening called Moon Coifs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--Turkey has accepted a role as consultant to the North Atlantic Treaty organization on problems of defense pertaining to the Mediterranean area. A proposal for similar association with the Atlantic Pact defense effort, ...

Mrs. Mary Scielzo, 30-year-old mother who had pleaded guilty to starving to death her 3-year-old son, Guy, Jr. in a squalid room of their East Harlem flat, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to serve five to ten years in state prison. On her plea last June to the first degree manslaughter charge she had faced a possible maximum sentence of twenty years.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 4--United Nations delegates cast a thumping 47 to 5 vote tonight in favor of an eight-power resolution on Korea carrying indirect but clear authorization for Gen. Douglas MacArthur to move across the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

WALLINGFORD, CONN., Oct. 4 --This year Choate school's football team is being called the "MidCentury" squad. This, because fifty years ago the Blue And Gold's first gridiron combination was fielded. The conditions, then were vastly different from the ideal ones under which the current Choate players operate.

ALL this morning's books are meant for pleasure, and if you also find in them the contagions of wisdom that should lurk in the best entertainment, why, we shall come that much closer to the practically perfect state of literary affairs on a singularly restless planet.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4--It took the Phillies thirty-five long years to make their second appearance in a world series, but when they finally did, it looked as though they still didn't believe it.

Foreigners have recovered during the last year about twofifths of the gold and dollar assets which they liquidated during the first three years of the post-war period, according to an estimate made by the National City Bank's October letter, to be published today.
George Miller, president and chairman of the board of I. Miller Sons, Inc., manufacturers of women's shoes, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 101 Central Park West. His age was 61.

"Pardon Our French," the Olsen and Johnson lavish musical offering, employing about seventy-five performers and put together at a cost of $250,000, will be unfolded this evening at the Broadway Theatre. PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4--A weary, highly satisfied Vic Raschi was lionized in the Yankee clubhouse at Shibe Park today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4--War materials and armed forces supplies were moved expeditiously to Korea from West Coast ports without the "fumbling period" that followed the attack on Pearl Harbor, the annual convention of the American Association of Port Authorities was told today by Brig. Gen. Frank S. Besson Jr., assistant Chief of Army Transportation in Washington.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 4-- The Federal Government's policy of "cheap money" and the prospects that it will continue presage a "grim" future for savings banks, it was asserted here today by Perrin L. Babcock, president of the New York State Savings Banks Association.
Grapes of almost every hue of the rainbow are arriving here now as the season for the fruit reaches its peak.

Joseph E. O'Grady, director of the city's Division of Labor Relations, resigned his $15,000 post yesterday in a letter to Acting Mayor Impellitteri in which he charged that the latter's candidacy for Mayor as an independent would aid the Republicans and hurt the local and state Democratic tickets.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 4--Recreation directors from every part of the country were urged this evening to take the lead in establishing new community programs for service men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--Harold E. Stassen, president of the University of Pennsylvania, revealed today that he has written to Premier Stalin suggesting that they confer on steps that need be taken to achieve "a just world peace."

A four-story building, occupied by the General Electric Company, at 21-45 Forty-fourth Avenue, Long Island City, has been sold by a client of Maurice Katzenstein to an investor represented by A.J. Goldstein Co., brokers. Queens Industrials and Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., were the brokers. The structure, which has about 40,000 square feet of space, is used by General Electric for their metropolitan district service and repair depot for small appliances.

Willard V. Merrihue yesterday called for establishment of a joint American Management Association-Armed Services Committee to develop immediately a clear-cut uniform set of rules governing security and loyalty clearances for employes working on classified projects for the military.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Thursday, Oct. 5--On the basis of incomplete --in some cases fragmentary--returns in Brazil's Presidential election, Getulio Vargas, former dictator, not only led Gen. Eduardo Gomes of the National Democratic Union by a margin of nearly two to one, but also was ahead in every one of the thirteen states, one territory and the Federal district heard from so far.

Exporters will adhere to present credit terms covering shipments to most world markets, neither tightening nor liberalizing them as a result of the successful outcome of the Korean war, according to a consensus yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Statler Hotel.

FRANKLIN, N.J., Oct. 4--This one-industry town received a new lease on its economic life tonight when the Franklin Industrial Commission announced it had signed a contract with a shirt manufacturer to build a plant on Route 23 here.

Poor old TV! After laying out $800,000 to go to the world series, it was plagued at yesterday's opening game by a number of technical mishaps, which were climaxed by Jim Britt's determined assurances that television really was advancing. All that is needed now is someone to figure out how the darn thing works.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 2--The United States team has finished second to Israel in the track and field competition of the world Jewish sports festival here. Americans won the quarter-mile and mile relays, the pole vault and discus throw today to pass South Africa for second place.

TETERBORO, N.J., Oct. 4--The first round-trip flight in a light plane between the United States and Europe was completed today when Max Conrad, a 47-year-old Minneapolis pilot, landed at Teterboro Airport shortly after noon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UP)-- The Federal Trade Commission today dropped false advertising complaints against three companies making widely used medical preparations after they agreed to label their products to warn customers against "excessive use."

OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 4--Governor Dewey said here tonight that former Mayor William O'Dwyer's proposal to legalize gambling, made to the Legislature last winter, was the official attitude of New York City Democratic leaders.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4--The United States Government has no intention of providing so-called "free dollars" to help Britain finance her three-year rearmament program, Federal financial authorities said today.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Oct. 4-- The French command here today announced the evacuation of Caobang, on a main highway from China and for years one of the main French defense posts along the Chinese border.
TORQUAY, England, Oct. 4-- Ninety-one sets of negotiations for new tariff agreements have now been scheduled for the first month of the United Nations tariff conference at Torquay.

KANSONG, North Korea, Oct. 4 --Thousands of South Korean soldiers poured through this small seaport today, many of them wearing flowers offered by the children of men they expect to meet in battle tomorrow or the next day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)--In twin moves brought on by the scanty United States cotton crop, the Government today clamped down on the export of cotton linters and cotton pulp, and authorized the importation of an additional 1,500,000 pounds of long staple cotton.

The three-man emergency panel set-up on Tuesday by President Truman to help settle the strike by 2,300 railway express drivers reported the situation as "hopeful" yesterday after all-day exploratory talks with both sides.
MARGATE, England, Oct. 4-- The struggle for power between the Left and the Right in Britain's Labor party ended in a draw today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 4-- Sacrifices by everyone will be required to increase our military and economic strength, President Truman declared today in a message to the Jewish War Veterans.

"Don Giovanni" had its first performance of the season at the City Center last night. Since the Mozart opera was introduced into the repertory several years ago, it has had twenty performances at the City Center. Evidently it has delighted thousands of people. After all, it is Mozart's finest opera and, for some tastes, an opera that has not been surpassed.

Hugh Devore, upon whom has fallen the job of putting football at New York University back on its feet, has no grandiose illusions as to the prospects of his first Violet squad, which will make its debut against Kings Point at the Merchant Marine Academy's Tomb Field in Great Neck, L.I., on Saturday.
