LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7--A sharp controversy developed tonight between officials of the American Legion and the Los Angeles public school system over a projected series of Legion lectures in schools on universal military training.
Final approval of United Nations military action throughout Korea was voted yesterday by the General Assembly in a one-sided ballot that found only the Soviet bloc in opposition.

With the passing of about $11,000,000,000 of new 1 per cent notes direct from the United States Treasury to the investment portfolio of the Federal Reserve System a finis has been written to an unusual anti-inflation maneuver in central banking, and now that the move is on the record, it may never happen again.

As of this writing, Christopher T. Chenery's 3-year-old Hill Prince is the horse of the year. At Belmont Park yesterday, in his last Eastern race of 1950, he moved up to become the No. 1 claimant of the title when he gave Mrs. Charles

ELIZABETHTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 1 7--The marriage of Miss Nancy Nash Brewster, daughter of Associate Justice O. Byron Brewster of the New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, and Mrs. Brewster, to James Stanley Carter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carter of Albany, took place here this afternoon in St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church.
The paradox that our national parks are rapidly increasing in popularity yet are suffering from a shabby state of disrepair is pointed up in a report of the House Public Lands Committee.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 7 (AP)--A desperate passing attack covering 65 yards and capped by a 4-yard touchdown run by Leon Heath with 37 seconds remaining, nabled Oklahoma to beat the Texas Aggies, 34--28, here today.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 7--Two fleet long shots--I Will and Eagle River--hit the line not even a quivering lip apart today to finish in a dead heat in the ninth running of the $10,000-added Princeton Handicap at Garden State Park.

TORQUAY, England, Oct. 7-- Britain's tariff negotiations with the United States during the third round of the World Tariff Conference underway here are going to be both important and difficult, it now appears.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--When the New York Giants make their 1950 home debut next Sunday at the Polo Grounds, opposing the Pittsburgh Steelers, Steve Owen will proudly present the National Football League's only unbeaten and untied eleven.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 8-- Immediate and sustained help is imperative for the continuation of service by American higher education, Dr. Raymond Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati, said her this afternoon before a class of eighty-six at Lehigh University's seventy-second annual Founder's Day exercises.

Although Aldous Huxley is a professional man of letters, he is an amateur on the stage. "The Gioconda Smile," which opened at the Lyceum on Saturday evening, is beneath the level on which he works in other mediums.

Formal approval of the merger of three left-wing unions into a new organization known as the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers of America was announced yesterday. Arthur Osman, president of the combined group, estimated the union's membership at 80,000, with 45,000 of that number in New York.
The Brookhattan-Galicia eleven gained a decisive victory in its American Soccer League game with the New York Americans at Sterling Oval yesterday, winning by 3 to 0.

It must always be good news when the apple crop is high. Most of this fruit is ripening now, and in numbers to fulfill our heritage of cornucopia. This year more than 119,000,000 bushels are expected to tumble down all over the country--a rich profusion of red, green and yellow wonders: clear,...

Dr. Alan Valentine, newly appointed Administrator of Economic Stabilization, has taught English to college undergraduates, has been a university president, has served as a director of a number of business corporations, has...

Philip Singer, department manager of women's and misses' active sportswear for Macy's New York, has been promoted to the new position of merchandise counselor of all budget and better sportswear. Clayton Zahn, senior assistant department manager of women's and misses' better sport coats, has been named department manager of budget sportswear.

A lamp that tilts, a lamp that grows and a lamp with well over a dozen small individual enameled shades sprouting full-grown from its base are among the whimsical novelties just arrived from Italy. These unusual and fantastic lighting tools were imported from Milan by Lightolier, 11 East Thirty-sixth Street, and are available through decorators from that showroom.

Parks Commissioner Robert Moses sought official approval yesterday for a nine-year plan to place artificial topsoil on seven reclaimed park areas at a total cost of $2,784,400. In a report to... Acting Mayor Impellitteri, Mr. Moses said conventional topsoil on the 1,900 acres of park land would cost $8,550,000. By using artificial topsoil of sewage sludge, clay and earth, the city could save $5,765,600, he estimated.

Governor Dewey will resume his up-state campaigning this morning, starting from Albany on a three-day tour that will end at Oswego. The schedule calls for appearances in ten counties, which will bring to twenty-eight the number he has toured in three weeks.

LONDON, Oct. 8--In the last week the City has had much to occupy its mind and it has not been easy to assess the possible effect on business and economic conditions of events that have occurred in this brief period. Foremost have been the freeing of the Canadian dollar and publication of the quarterly statement of the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves.
The Brooklyn holdover gambling grand jury will make today a presentment designed to hold up the pensions of policemen who refuse to waive immunity.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 8 --Dr. Nathaniel H. Ives of 175 Park Avenue, dean of the medical profession in Mount Vernon and a prominent Protestant Episcopal layman, died today in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 77 years old.
The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, 14 Wall Street, granted more than $800,000 to medical schools and other educational institutions in the academic year ended last June 30.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 9--Gen. Douglas MacArthur, in the name of the United Nations, called on the North Koreans today, "for the last time," to lay down their arms and cease hostilities. It was his second warning to the enemy.
Striking express drivers voted unanimously yesterday to continue the fifteen-day-old strike that has forced an embargo on express operations in the metropolitan area.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 8-- Jogendra Nath Mandal, Minister for Law and Labor and the only Hindu in the Pakistan Central Cabinet, has resigned his office, the All-India radio said tonight.
Frank Sinatra walked off the television high dive on Saturday might (9 P.M. on C.B.S.), but unfortunately fell into the shallow end of the pool.

Max Ascoli, editor and publisher of the magazine The Reporter, denied last night a charge by Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, that the publication was "loaded" with material favorable to the Chinese Communists. The Senator made the charge Saturday in criticizing the State Department for circulating issues of the magazine among its posts abroad.
SCITUATE, Mass., Oct. 8--Dr. Percy Brown, pioneer radiologist who was internationally known in his field, died today at the age of 74.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8-- Paramount has signed Joan Fontaine for the chief feminine role, done by Ethel Barrymore on Broadway in 1905, in the studio's projected screen version of Sir James Barrie's play, "Alice Sit-by-theFire," which will be filmed under the title "Rendezvous."
Nine new films, including importations from England and France, are scheduled to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

A hit in Dallas doesn't necessarily mean one on Broadway. That's the lesson conveyed by "Southern Exposure," which vacates the Biltmore on Saturday night. Presented by Margo Jones (she also directed), Tad Adoue and Manning Gurian, the Owen Crump comedy will have had a run of twenty-three performances, enough to insure the picture rights.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 8--Two proposals, both aimed at gearing the United Nations to act more swiftly to counter aggression, will be presented tomorrow in the Political Committee of the General Assembly.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved higher last week. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 43 to 98 points, with the nearby December delivery strongest. In the preceding week there were net losses of 85 to 146 points.
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 9 (AP)--Release 536, issued by General MacArthur's headquarters at 10:50 A.M., Monday (8:50 P.M., Sunday, Eastern standard time):
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 8 (AP)-- Purdue's 13,000 students had a colossal emotional hangover today after spending most of the night whooping about their team's 28-14 football upset over Notre Dame.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 8 --The time to stop the Communist world threat "is now," Admiral William F. Halsey told the fiftyfifth National Convention of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States here today.

In its program to improve the nation's schools the American Association of School Administrators holds that community action is essential. Complete public support is necessary; unless the citizens themselves become enthusiastic about their schools, the chances are that the educational system will go downhill.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP)--Passer Johnny Lujack turned into a running demon in a neat about-face today to steer the Chicago Bears to a 27-6 victory over their South Side rivals, the Cardinals, in a rain-drenched National Football League game.

After General MacArthur had called on the North Koreans "for the last time" to surrender, forces of his United Nations Command went forward on offensives north of the Thirtyeighth Parallel. The United States First Cavalry Division had a regiment spearheading action on the west. The South Korean Third Division was five miles from the east coast port of Wonsan. [1:8, map P.2.]

The text of Secretary Acheson's address here last night follows: Public life in America is a rough school. It is no place for anyone who is thin-skinned, or who can work only in an atmosphere of approbation.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 8--Revaluation of the Canadian dollar created a demand on the stock market for securities with a Canadian interest and for all sterling securities against which dollar issues were rather heavily offered.

DES MOINES, Oct. 8--The largest number of young men in the history of the United Lutheran Church in America are preparing for the Christian ministry, according to figures released here today at the seventeenth bennial convention of the church.

NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Oct 8-- Dr. Lewis Thorne, psychiatrist on the Yale faculty, was shot fatally and his wife was wounded critically tonight in their home here by an assailant described by State Police as "apparently insane."

Graham Peck, author of "Through China's Wall," has a second book about China on Houghton Mifflin's list for Oct. 24 publication. "Two Kinds of Time" is a personal account of China's people, their economy and customs, and the great contrasts among them.

The marriage of Miss Mary Ellen Heller, daughter of Mrs. Eleanor Heller and Herbert C. Heller of New York and Nantucket, Mass., to Wilton Linder Jaffee, son of Mrs. Jonas Reiner of Ossining, N.Y., and Wilton L. Jaffee of Bucks County, Pa., took place yesterday at Sherry's. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark.

The recent sharp increase in demand for accommodations on long cruises this winter is the result of renewed public confidence growing out of the favorable turn of events in Korea, in the opinion of Harold F. Borer, United States general manager of the Cunard Line. Mr. Borer is just back from a visit to the home office in Liverpool.

As an aid to business concerns faced with a critical shortage of managerial and office personnel in the present emergency, the City College Midtown Business Center announced publication yesterday of a comprehensive guide covering job structures in a wide range of industries.

Manfred Hecht, young Viennaborn baritone, has been around town for some eight years, singing in opera, oratorio and on the radio. Yesterday afternoon he made his first recital appearance before a large audience in Town Hall.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 8--The Soviet Union was warned tonight by United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy not to underestimate the power or the determination of the
Children's clothes are frequently pretty, but few of them are distinctive. We think the three styles that Patterns of the Times offers this week are both distinctive and pretty.

All is not well in newly independent Indonesia. A substantial part of the people of the Amboina group of islands in the eastern part of the archipelago are in revolt against the authority of the Republic and have proclaimed their independence.

A flat charge that the independent candidacy for Mayor of Acting Mayor Impellitteri is being financed at least partly by Republicans was made last night by Aaron L. Jacoby, campaign manager for Ferdinand Pecora, the Democratic and Liberal party nominee for Mayor.

Secretary of State Dean Acheson envisioned last night the possibility of "a peaceful adjustment" of differences with the Soviet Union when the present great military inequality between East and West was reduced.

Talk of the world series and the 1950 campaign dominated so thoroughly by Casey Stengel's Yankees was dying down yesterday, following a victory celebration in the Hotel Biltmore that rolled noisily all through Saturday night.

PARIS, Oct. 8--The recent rise in rubber on the international market and notably in London where it went from 42 d per pound to 45 between Sept. 29 and Oct. 6 is causing concern among Government experts and in financial circles here.
Hernan Santa Cruz of Chile, president of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, said yesterday the Council would reconvene Thursday to take up its role in the reconstruction of Korea.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 8--In, a northeast gloomy chill, with the wind up to twenty-five miles, and a sea splash, the final of the postseason contests was held today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

The study of history and the Fortunes of the New York Yankees baseball team remain the private pursuits of Dr. David Saville Muzzey, the noted American historian, whose "American History" has been read by well over 4,000,000 grade and high school students throughout the country.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 8 --In the Church-in-the-Highlands (Congregational) here this afternoon Miss Irene Angeline Davenport, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack B. Davenport of North Patchogue, L.I., was married to...
The subway alumni have holed up for a long, dreary winter. With them, countless fans the country over have been cast into gloom. Notre Dame has fallen, crushed by Purdue's high-spirited sophomores.

Registration in this city for the November election opens today. Booths in each election district will be open from 5 to 10:30 P.M. today through Friday, and on Saturday, the final day, from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. No one who has not registered will be eligible to vote in the general election.

A proposed 1951 capital budget of $485,510,728 was made public yesterday by the City Planning Commission as the basis for an all-day public hearing at City Hall next hionday. As required by the City Charter, the budget contained the proposed allocation of funds to city departments and agencies for construction of permanent public works to be financed by city bonds.

The Lasaral Realty Corporation, Jacob Mark, president, which plans a ten-story apartment house covering the blockfront on the east side of York Avenue from East Eighty-ninth to Ninetieth Street, in the Gracie Square section, has obtained a combined building loan and permanent mortgage of 1,250,000 from the East New York Savings Bank.

WITH KOREAN REPUBLICAN FORCES, South of Wonsan, Oct. 8 --A sudden burst of machine gun fire at 3:40 P.M. today temporarily interrupted the steady advance of South Korean troops toward the North Korean seaport of Wonsan.

WARSAW, Oct. 8--The sudden reversal in fortune of the North Korean army has posed a formidable problem for the official Polish propagandists, who have not yet informed the public of the loss of Seoul and the pocketing of the Red forces in southwestern Korea.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 8-- Three young men were killed at 2:26 A.M. today, when their car veered out of control on Lake Avenue and struck a tree.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democratic-Liberal nominee for reelection, will make the second of his series of Monday night speeches at 6:15 over a state-wide network for the Columbia Broadcasting System. It will be devoted largely to foreign policy.

WEST POINT, Oct. 8--Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York and Military Vicar of the Armed Forces of the United States, presided today at a solemn high mass at the Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity in celebration of the chapel's fiftieth anniversary.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 8--One of the basic disagreements within the Defense Committee of the North Atlantic Treaty organization has come into the open as a result of the public assertion of Netherlands officials that they will not bow to pressure to reduce the Dutch Navy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8--A Government loan of $1.47 a bushel, national average for the 1950 corn crop, was announced by the Department of Agriculture late last week, or 7 cents above that for the previous crop.

There were quite a few gratifying features about the two-piano debut recital of Josette and Yvette Roman last night in Town Hall. Both are good technicians, their tones match beautifully, and their ensemble is a thing to marvel at.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 8--A new devaluation of Finnish currency, the finnmark, is held unavoidable before the end of the year in financial and political circles here. With wages and the cost of living climbing steadily since spring, production costs have reached the point where only further devaluation can maintain the Finnish lumber and paper mills in world competition, many advocates of devaluation say.

Governor Dewey, Gen. Lucius D. Clay and exiled anti-Communist statesmen from eastern Europe called yesterday for mobilization of the forces of truth to pierce the Iron Curtain and defeat the "Big Lie" of Communism.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 (AP)--At least thirteen producers including several large ones, raised steel prices last week, but general increases throughout the industry are unlikely until after settlement of the wage question, Steel magazine said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--The Defense Department reported today that the Army had increased its buying of tanks, guns and other "major" equipment items by 500 per cent since the outbreak of the Korean war. At the same time, purchasing for Army equipment to be shipped to Atlantic Pact allies has been increased about 400 per cent under recent rearmament planning.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 8 --The first Locust Valley Music Festival, one of modest pretensions but of highly distinctive interest, was held here this afternoon and evening at the music shed of Mrs. Alma Morgenthau's house on the Lattington Estate.

The Rev. Dr. John Ellis Large of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, declared yesterday that a resurgence of agnosticism in higher education threatened American morality.

DETROIT, Oct. 8 (AP)--Strongarmed Bobby Layne found the murkiness and sogginess of Briggs Stadium to his liking today as he ran and passed the Detroit Lions to a 24-7 decision over the San Francisco Forty-Niners.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8--The nation is making headway in its fight against juvenile delinquency but the battle is slow because of the lack of warm, understanding persons to carry on the work with children, Dr. Walter C. Reckless, one of the country's leading authorities on juvenile delinquency, declared today.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 8--Grover Theis, Miami newspaper man and publicity agent and a former member Of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff, died in a Hospital here today after an illness of several months. He was 54 years old.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 8 (AP)--Cornell University has developed a method of prospecting for precious stones, metals and oil merely by studying airplane photos taken from an altitude of a mile or two.

Edward Corsi, Republican candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that J. Raymond Jones, Deputy Commissioner of Housing and a Tammany leader of the Thirteenth Assembly District, had demanded a $1,000 contribution to the 1949 O'Dwyer campaign fund as a consideration for getting city patients for the Mount Morris Park Hospital.

A seven-story building containing 52,000 square feet of storage space in the Terminal Warehouse group of buildings in the block bounded by West Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets, Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues, has been leased to Macy's department store by Webb Knapp.

JAFFREY, N.H., Oct. 8 (UP)-- Dr. William T. Foster, president of the Pollak Foundation for Economic Research and former president of Reed College, Portland, Ore., died here today at his summer home. He was 71 years old.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 8--Representative Walter A. Lynch, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, today accepted crime versus clean government as an issue in the state campaign. He thus took up Governor Dewey's challenge of last Friday.

The fortieth anniversary of the consecration of St. Patrick's Cathedral was observed yesterday with a pontifical mass of thanksgiving offered by Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, cathedral administrator.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)-- Charles C. Ralls, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, today accused the Department of Agriculture of "an apparent effort to flood the country with United Nations flags" to take the place of Old Glory over the nation's schools.

DALLAS, Oct. 8 (AP)--Sheriff Bill Decker said a former San Diego, Calif., union official had been shot to death by a deputy early today after the man had tried to take over a bus and then had run amok in a hospital.

VIENNA, Oct. 8--By manufacturing "people's radios" without short-wave bands, by substituting piped-in programs by "radiofication stations" and loudspeakers in place of radios and by making listening in to Western broadcasts virtually a criminal offense the regimes of the "people's democracies" have this year gone far toward making the Iron Curtain impervious to radio waves.
The first cold snap of the autumn brings all of the windows down with a sudden bang. They will have to be washed; that much is immediately obvious. With all vision to the...

Upward of 135 newspaper women officially start today on their seventh annual gastronomical adventure--the Newspaper Food Editors' Conference. With pencils, pads and primed palates they have arrived for five days at the Wal-...

Foreign exchanges moved more erratically last week than at any time since last fall when devaluation of British sterling, joined by all of the major currencies of the world, touched off a long period of irregularity.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)--The military and civilian arms of the Federal Government have pooled their traffic know-how for the first time.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 8--The third Maccabiah, which attracted top Jewish athletes from eighteen countries, ended today at Ramat Gan Stadium.
On this week's art program at metropolitan galleries are several one-man and group shows.

Despite the recent protest by the Polish Government that such action was discriminatory, the liner Batory was again subjected to a thorough security check on her arrival here yesterday from Gdynia, Copenhagen and Southampton.

A week ago this column was devoted to a discussion of the seventy-fifth annual convention of the American Bankers Association, which had just then been concluded. Like the first assemblage of that organization, it was observed, the convention of 1950...

Less than 9 per cent of about 4,000 small business men responding to a survey of financial needs by the National Association of Manufacturers expressed the belief that the Federal Government should facilitate loans to business.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)--The heaviest casualty list of the Korean campaign, released today by the Department of Defense, contains n--ames of 1,211 members of the United States armed services.

Miss Harriet Carroll Aikins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Carroll Colby Aikins of Rekadom Ranch, Naramata, B.C., will be married today to Arnold S. Beichman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Beichman of New York, at Rekadom Ranch.
IT was the night before the world series opened and Bob Carpenter, the youthful owner of the youthful Phillies, dropped a random observation.

The Brand Names Foundation has issued a roster listing 2,438 brand names of products made by manufacturer-members. The reference book, the first of its kind issued by the association, lists 271 different types of products. Brand names in food and grocery products totaled 634, outnumbering any other category.
TEHERAN, Oct. 8--Premier Ali Razmara demanded an unexpected vote of confidence today in the Iranian Parliament and received ninety-seven votes from the 106 Deputies present in the chamber.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 8 (AP)-- The sprightly New York Yanks defeated the Green Bay Packers, 44--31, today before 23,871 fans at City Stadium in a National Football League game.

ATHENS, Oct. 8--Arguments against a reduction in Greek Army strength to a proposed 80,000--it is now about 125,000--as a means of cutting the national budget, appeared in today's issue of Stratiotika Nea, publication of the Greek General Staff.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 8--Cornell University has adopted a balanced budget for 1950-51, Acting President Cornelis W. de Kiewiet disclosed today in an annual report to the university's 70,000 alumni.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8--The United Steelworkers of America C.I.O., headed by Philip Murray, will begin its efforts tomorrow to win a "very healthy and substantial" wage increase for its 1,000,000 members.

In a reverent and moving spectacle at the Polo Grounds last night, Cardinal Spellman led the Holy Name Societies of the Archdiocese of New York through the ceremony of their annual pledge against profanity and obscenity and of respect for civil and spiritual authority.

Promotional items, special orders and fill-in merchandise were requested here last week, but buying activity in most wholesale markets tapered off slightly, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Interest was shown in early spring and cruise lines and orders were placed in moderation for November delivery.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 8--With the attitude of the Soviet Union still undisclosed, the United Nations Security Council will hold a closed meeting tomorrow to decide whether to recommend the re-election of Trygve Lie as Secretary General.

PARIS, Oct. 8--Progress in normal production can be made at same time as defense production expands if there is effective European cooperation and sufficient external aid to insure financial stability, Giuseppe Pella, Italian Finance Minister, said yesterday in an interview. Signor Pella was in Paris for a meeting of the European Marshall Plan Council.

The nation's shipping policy with respect to the "essential trade route" concept of the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 was defended yesterday by the National Federation of American Shipping in answer to an attack by the Association of American Ship Owners.

IT was unseasonably hot that June. People mopped their heads and complained and asked each other if it was hot enough for them. Even the children in the backyard of the big old house where the Rowans had lived for ten years seemed subdued. In the kitchen Mary, the cook who insisted that she was a housekeeper and not a servant, was fretful and irritable.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--Representative Walter A. Lynch of the Bronx, Democratic-Liberal candidate for governor of New York, has scored 100 per cent in American Federation of Labor ratings of House members.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--Big city gangsters may get the headlines but the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today that crime continued to rise at a faster pace in rural areas.

The aims and methods of American foreign policy in a world of peril, in which the consequences of error may be death, have been outlined anew by Secretary Acheson in his speech accepting the Freedom House award of 1950. Mr. Acheson did not say anything that has not been said a thousand times before, but what he did say...
BERLIN, Oct. 8 (AP)--The Polish military mission here rejected today West Germany's protest against the Polish-East German agreement ratifying the OderNeisse border between the two countries.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8--At the rate steel was being produced in the nation last week a new alltime record is expected to be established this month. Steel ingot output last week was up point to 101 per cent of rated capacity.
BRIARCLIFF, N.Y., Oct. 8-- The "professional guest from Briarcliff" deplored here today the reputation he has earned among social circles in Westchester County as "the man who came to bathe."

DETROIT, Oct. 8 (AP)--Ted Lindsay and Terry Sawchuck combined their talents tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a lopsided 7-1 decision over the National Hockey League's All-Star squad before 11,058.

PARIS, Oct. 8--Official ceremonies of welcome to Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef, Sultan of Morocco, who arrived at Bordeaux aboard a French cruiser today for a state visit of one week, were marred when North African Communists attempted to disrupt the cortege of automobiles.

Friedrich Gulda, 20-year-old Austrian pianist, has been interned on Ellis Island since early Saturday morning. Whether he will be released in time to give his American debut recital, sched uled for Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, will depend on an interpretation by the Department of Justice of part of the recently passed Internal Security Act.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UP)-- The Government reported today it had invented something to "save time and money" for housewives-- a new type of grocery store counter.
LONDON, Oct. 8--Two dramas with an identical plot, one real and one make-believe, are now being enacted in London--at 10 Downing Street and the Prince's Theatre.

A light haze hung over Flushing Meadow on Saturday. The air outside the draughty corridors was blurred by the pleasant vagueness of autumn. Inside the Assembly chamber, however, the proceedings were unusually clearcut and decisive. If anybody there...

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 8 --With Stephen (Laddie) Sanford pacing a second-half spurt that produced six goals, a Westbury side defeated the Jericho poloists, 9--7, in a spirited match on rainsodden Bostwick Field Today.

ZURICH, Oct. 8--Why the Swiss Federal Council strongly recommends that Switzerland should forthwith ratify the agreement signed in Paris Sept. 19 establishing the European Payments Union is explained fully in an eighty-onepage "message to Parliament" dated Sept. 22, whose full text has just been released.

Roland Petit's Ballets de Paris returned last night for their second New York season, this time at the National Theatre, under the auspices of the Messers. Shubert, S. Hurok and Arthur Lesser, which seems like a lot of auspices for so small and modest a company.

Edward L. Bernays, publicist, Gypsy Rose Lee and other residents of East Sixty-third Street joined yesterday in protesting that the proposed widening of the street would strip it of its old and beautiful trees.
Uncle Miltie served notice again yesterday that he is a horse not to be scorned, despite the players' insistence on picking against him.

Despite the pleas of candidates, New Yorkers did not make too impressive a showing yesterday in registering for the election to be held on Nov. 7. A total of 295,129 residents in the five boroughs went to the polling booths to qualify as voters.
Cotton trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday and closing prices were 30 to 93 points net lower, virtually at the lows of the day.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service announced yesterday that it was holding 127 aliens on Ellis Island to determine whether they should be excluded under the new Internal Security Act.

NEWARK, Oct. 9--United States Senator Alexander N. Smith, Republican, and three Republican Representatives from this state have sponsored "phony bills designed only to sidetrack the national health insurance program," it was charged today by Carl Holderman, state president of the Congress of Industrial Organization.

Despite Columbia's two decisive victories in as many games, Coach Lou Little refused to be optimistic as he sent his charges through a light contact workout at Baker Field yesterday in preparation for the encounter with Yale at New Haven on Saturday.
Women's Court was deserted yesterday afternoon. The blinds were drawn and the doors were closed as if it was midnight. But this was midday in a normally busy court.

Dr. William E.B. DuBois, American Labor party candidate for United States Senator, attacked the foreign policy position of the Democratic and Republican parties in a talk broadcast last night over WMCA.

DETROIT, Oct. 9--Francis Adams Truslow, president of the New York Curb Exchange, declared here today that brokerage compensation "is far too low to spread the ownership of American enterprise as far as it can and should be spread."

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York opened a campaign, for $20,000,000 last night with special ceremonies at Temple Emanu-El, Sixty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, president of Columbia University, was the principal speaker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9--The Supreme Court denied to the University of Maryland today a review of a Maryland Court of Appeals decision that the university must admit Esther McCready, a Negro, to the institution's white School of Nursing.
Essex County, N.J., designated yesterday Oct. 26 as the date for receiving bids on an issue of $4,682,000 of bonds dated Nov. 1, 1950, and due on Nov. 1, 1951 to 1990.

Fifty thousand American seamen will receive an increase of 6.38 per cent in their base pay and other benefits as the result of agreements reached here yesterday by negotiators for Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators, the National Maritime Union, C.I.O., and the Seafarers International Union, A.F.L.

Douglas MacArthur's headquarters and the Defense Department of the protest as a matter of course.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 10-- Announcement was made here today of the impending consolidation of the First National Bank and Trust Company of this city and the Shelton Trust Company of Shelton. The directors of the two institutions have approved and confirmation by stockholders is awaited.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Net sales of manufacturing corporations in the second quarter of this year reached a record figure of $43,500,000,000, or about 13 per cent more than in the first...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10, (AP)-- Hired farm workers are getting an average of 59 cents an hour, or 2 cents more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department reported today. Farm employment was down about 1,000,000 workers from a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Government agencies today clamped stricter curbs on credit available for the construction of one and two family housing units to check inflationary aspects of home building.

Mrs. Walter S. Fischer, chairman of the New York Junior League ball for provisional members of the organization, gave a tea yesterday afternoon in the Palm Court of the Ritz-Carlton for her aides serving in behalf of the forthcoming event. Proceeds from the ball, to be held on Nov. 22 in the grand ballroom of the RitzCarlton, will be donated to the needs of ten local philanthropies.

John D. Bierwirth, president and director of the National Distillers Products Corporation and also a director of the New York Trust Company, was erroneously identified yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES as president and director of the New York Trust Company.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 10 (AP)--The Indonesian Government informed the United Nations Commission today that Indonesia was unable to comply with the commission's appeal to stop military operations against rebel Amboina.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct 10 (AP)--Officials of the Department of the Interior said today that Col. Paul Magliore had won 99 per cent of the vote in Haiti's presidential election of last Sunday.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Oct. 10-- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fitch Shedden have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Margery, to Neil Wilson Currie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil Currie Jr of Schenectady, N.Y. The wedding will take place on Nov. 25.

James Pease will sing the role of Hans Sachs in the New York City Opera Company's first production of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger" at the City Centre on Friday night. Hans Beirer will be the Walther and Frances Yeend the Eva.
HAVANA, Oct. 10--Cuba celebrated today the eighty-second anniversary of the start of the first war of independence against Spain.

The New York PhilharmonicSymphony's deficit for the 1949-50 season was $173,157.39, which was almost four times the deficit for 1948-49, Floyd G. Blair, treasurer, revealed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York at Steinway Hall.

Organization of Joy Finance Corporation as a wholly owned subsidiary of Joy Manufacturing Company was announced yesterday. The new concern, which will have authorized capital of $2,000,000, will purchase all installment...

Warfare among teen-age street gangs in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn again has risen to fever pitch since the understaffed Kings County probation department was forced to abandon successful mediation work among the feuding groups.
At least 400,000 allergy victims in the city receive no medical treatment for afflictions that may result in severe illnesses in later years.
The election of three new directors of The Home Insurance Company to succeed directors recently deceased was announced yesterday by Harold V. Smith, president.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10-- Jerry Wald and Norman Krasna, R.K.O. producers, today concluded a verbal deal for Al Jolson to play himself in their projected "Stars and Stripes Forever," a film about a U.S.O. troupe in the South Pacific.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture, in a near-harvest-time report, estimated today this year's corn crop at 3,117,967,000 bushels.

YONKERS, Oct. 10--Emmett Burke of Yonkers, a high school teacher and the Democratic nominee for State Senator against Senator William F. Condon, Republican, sent a telegram to Governor Dewey today asking him to close ...

TOKYO, Oct. 9--An analysis of the North Korean occupation of South Korean territory, including the capital city of Seoul, has revealed that although the Soviet Union guided the Communists' military bid for control of all Korea the Russians themselves remained conspicuously absent during the nearly three months this effort was under way.

Registration in New York City picked up yesterday as compared with the two-day totals last year, but there was a sharp falling off when the figures were compared with the number of residents who qualified during the two-day period in 1948 and in 1946.

RELATIONS between Notre Dame and Army on the football field ended in 1947 but the rivalry between them carries on. It is a rivalry between not only the teams but also their coaches, whose success has transcended all others' since Earl Blaik went to West Point and Frank Leahy to South Bend in 1941.

Dillard Morrison and Robert E. Lee, defendants in a Federal narcotics case, were held in $100,000 bail each here yesterday, accused of having shot and wounded Harry Knowles, the chief Government witness.

We have been asked a puzzling question. Where is the White Wing? He can't be on the streets we frequent, because there is the litter and the dust, obviously untouched. We supposed that he must be around the corner, but we went around the corner.
Events tonight: Friedrich Gulda, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:40 o'clock; Dorothy Eustis, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Rosalyn Tureck, piano, Lexington Avenue Y.M. and Y.W.H.A., 8:40.

Two new full-hour comedy-variety programs are being added to the Columbia Broadcasting System's afternoon video schedule, beginning next week. Under the expanded schedule, Garry Moore will be presented at 1:30, to be followed at 2:30 by the Robert Q. Lewis show, Mondays through Fridays.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10--After weeks of concentrated fire on the Administration's foreign policy as a key issue in the campaign, Senator Robert A. Taft came back to the domestic level tonight with the charge that organized labor, which he said already controlled President ...

COPENHAGEN, Oct. 10--At a dinner given by the Government tonight at Christianborg Castle, Winston Churchill, Britain's wartime Prime Minister, received a check for the equivalent of $14,300 for his contributions to European culture. The award was made from the fund of the late Danish philapthropist and author, C.J. Sonning.

The A.W. Kroessler Company, manufacturer of special condenser winding machines, has leased the one-story industrial building at 32-20 Thirty-seventh Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, from Russell Spera and will occupy it as its factory and offices. Queens Industrials was the broker.

LONDON, Oct. 10--This Parliament, now in recess, will end on the day King George VI opens the new House of Commons, reconstructed from the ruins of the one destroyed in the blitz. The date for both the prorogation of Parliament by the King and the ceremonies celebrating the opening of the new chamber has been set for Oct. 26.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP)--The International Association of Machinists' Executive Council today unanimously recommended reaffiliation of the 600,000-member independent union with the American Federation of Labor, which it left five years ago as the result of a jurisdictional dispute with the Carpenters' union.

Rebuilding of the armed forces offers an encouraging prospect of increased sales of frozen foods, both to military and civilian consumers, members of the Eastern Frosted Foods Association were told yesterday.
Many parties were given at the dinner dance in behalf of the East Side Settlement, held last night at the formal opening for this season of the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The general index of basic commodities, based on the August, 1939, level, increased from 323.1 on Sept. 29 to 326.6 on Oct. 6, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Greater aid to children in underprivileged rural areas of the United States and in six war-devastated European countries was urged yesterday at the nineteenth annual meeting of the Save the Children Federation.

Edward Corsi, Republican candidate for Mayor, quoted Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, his Democratic-Liberal rival, last night as having advised Tammany district leaders in 1930 to refuse to waive immunity if called as witnesses in the Seabury investigation.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Oct. 10-- For the second year in a row the Upper Montclair team of Chester Sanok and Stephen Berrien won the New Jersey Golf Association best-ball low gross trophy with a six under par 33, 32--65 over the Forest Hill Field Club course today.

The probability that a second sophomore will join Sam Coppola in the Fordham backfield was raised yesterday as Coach Ed Danowski tested Dick Sharry at fullback in a heavy contact scrimmage with the freshmen. Coppola took over the right halfback assignment Monday.

EASTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 10 (AP)--Directors of United Elastic Corporation have announced a stock dividend, of one share for each two outstanding, payable on Nov. 1 to stockholders of record at the close of business Oct. 16.

The state started action in Supreme Court yesterday to dissolve the Cancer Welfare Fund, Inc., of 350 Fifth Avenue, on the ground that it had violated its charter and abused its privilege of collecting donations to aid cancer victims.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 10-- Price controls were favored by an overwhelming majority of delegates to the three-day conference here a of the National Institute of Governmental Purchasing in a test vote today.

The marriage of Miss Muriel Merle Freedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Freedman of West Orange, N.J., to Philip Irwin Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Wolf of New York and Phileidor Farm, Carmel, N.Y. took place here yesterday afternoon at Sherry's.

Stocks of slab zinc held by smelters dropped to the lowest level in nearly twenty-five years, at the end of September, it was reported yesterday by the American Zinc Institute. At the end of last month stocks held totaled 10,267...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Pennsylvania Railroad and the Seaboard Air Line Railroad today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to refuse to consider a complaint involving alleged discrimination because of race segregation on a reserved-seat train en route to Florida.
Frank F. Kolbe, president of the United Electric Coal Companies, announced the election of C.H. Burgess as treasurer of the company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Louisiana Power and Light Company of New Orleans applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for registration of $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, series due Nov. 1, 1980.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 10 (AP) --The Oklahoma Natural Gas Company today voted to acquire all the outstanding capital stock of four Oklahoma utilities. At a special meeting of stockholders, the company was authorized to issue 32,200 additional shares of $15...

Trustees of the Long Island Rail Road has requested permission of the Federal Court to buy twelve more Diesel-electric passenger locomotives. Acquisition of the new Diesels would permit the retirement of seventeen steam locomotives and completely Dieselize the passenger serivce in nonelectrified territory. The Long Island now operates eighteen Diesels.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 10 (U.P.)-- Earl E. Robertson, vice president of The Kansas City Star, died tonight at his home after a long illnesss. His age was 64. He was national advertising, manager of the newspaper for forty years.

HARRISVILLE, R.I., Oct. 10-- A post office built with private funds will be turned over to the Federal Government during Columbus Day exercises here Thursday. Formal presentation of the Colonial-style edifice will be made by Austin T. Levy, textile manufacturer.

Two new films will open in first-run theatres this morning. At the Capitol, the attraction is "A Life of Her Own," a romantic drama produced by Metro-GoldwynMayer and starring Lana Turner and Ray Milland.
Plans are being advanced rapidly for the annual fashion show and tea dance for the benefit of the Judson Health Center, which will be held on Dec. 8 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Dr. Walter Wood King, a retired medical director in the United States Public Health Service, died yesterday at the Marine Hospital Baltimore. He was 74 years old.

Joseph H. Himes of Washington, D.C., yesterday was elected chairman of the stockholders' committee of Pantepec Oil Company C.A., a Venezuelan corporation. Mr. Himes is a special partner of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and a director of Electric Boat Company, Acacia Mutual Life Insurance Company, Washington, and Canadair, Ltd., Montreal..

BOSTON, Oct. 10--The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company announced today it had agreed to give wage rises totaling $5,000,000 to 27,000 employes in Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New Hampshire, Vermont and Maine.
AUCKLAND, Oct. 10 (AP)--Freeing of the Canadian dollar has left New Zealand importers with insufficient funds for orders placed with Canadian manufacturers.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10--The International Typographical Union, A.F.L., today revoked the charter of the Pittsburgh Mailers Union, Local 22. The wage strike of the 177 members of the local has halted publication of this city's three daily newspapers for nine days and brought idleness to more than 2,300 other employes.

BISMARCK, N.D., Oct. 10-- There are some observers, political and otherwise, who maintain that the Democrats have a chance to pick up a seat in the United States House of Representatives in traditionally Republican North Dakota.

The two-family dwelling at 372 Sheffield Street, West New Brighton, S.I., has been sold by Donald L. Campbell to Sebastian Grasso through Kolff Kaufmann, Inc. The brokers also reported the sale of the one-family house at 576 Bement Avenue, West New Brighton, for Mrs. Irene J. Toppin to Walter K. Koch.

The Ziegfeld Club, a non-profit and non-sectarian organization started fifteen years ago to assist indigent performers, decided at its monthly meeting yesterday afternoon to hold the annual "Ziegfeld Ball" on Nov. 18 at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Gertrude Vanderbilt, assisted by Lillian Shaw, heads the committee arranging the details.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 10-- America's top-ranking Protestant leaders have completed plans for a concerted, country-wide campaign to oppose the establishment of diplomatic relations between the United States Government and the Vatican "or any other religious group."
Sharp gains in the commodity futures markets were registered here yesterday with such important war materials as natural rubber and nonferrous metals leading the way.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10--A Government estimate of the grain and soybean crops issued after the markets closed today was so close to trade expectations that it is not expected to have much effect as a price making factor tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Central of Georgia Railway Company today briskly attacked a protest which the Georgia Railroad Banking Company had lodged with the Interstate Commerce Commission against a proposed loan of $2,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Central of Georgia.
HAINESVILLE, N.J., Oct. 10 (AP)--A private plane crashed near this Delaware River town last night, killing the pilot, Dr. Boardman Marsh Bosworth of Bronxville, N.Y.

Governor Dewey accepted with regret yesterday the resignation of Irving T. Bergman as executive secretary of the State Labor Relations Board. Mr. Bergman, who was praised by the Governor for having done "a fine job in the public interest," has returned to the private practice of law with the firm of Hartman, Sheridan Tekulsky.

President Truman will meet General MacArthur over the week-end at an undisclosed Pacific point to discuss "the final phase of United Nations action in Korea" and "other matters" within the General's "responsibility."
Ralph E. Smiley has been admitted to partnership in Booz, Allen and Hamilton, management consultants. He has been in charge of the Washington office two years and will continue in that capacity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--President Truman today appointed Cyrus S. Ching chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, a nine-man body recently established by Executive order in the Economic Stabilization Agency. Other members of the board have not been named.

Just as a $50,000,000 bank credit expired yesterday, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., made arrangements with the same group of fourteen banks for a $90,000,000 one-year credit, effective on Monday, Oct. 16.

Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., will complete the modernization of its East Boston terminal this fall to provide a streamlined and more efficient operation to meet the needs of the approaching heating season, it was announced yesterday.
Breakfast with Kellogg's, luncheon with Campbell Soup and dinner with Bird's Eye yesterday assured 130 newspaperwomen of adequate food, including some for thought, too.

ALBANY, Oct. 10--Lawrence E. Gerosa, president of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce and New York City contractor, has been appointed regional governor of the New York Good Road Association, Charles H. Sella, executive director of the associatiion, announced today. Mr. Gerosa will direct association activities in the Bronx and New York and Richmond Counties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)--A collective bargaining agent election has been ordered among employer at the Keuffel Esser Company of Hoboken, N.J., the National Labor Relations Board announced today. Robert D. Hill has been elected vice president of Taylor-Wharton Iron and Steel Company. In addition to his new duties, he continues as treasurer.

GENEVA, Oct. 10--Complete solution of the displaced persons' problem, inherited by the Western world from World War II, is in sight, J. Donald Kingsley, Director General of the International Refugee Organization, said today.

TRENTON, Oct. 10--Enlargement of the state police force was ordered today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to meet increasing demands on the constabulary for racketeering investigations, traffic law enforcement and calls to military service.

In a sweeping enforcement of the new Internal Security Act, Immigration inspectors yesterday sent ninety-five arriving aliens to Ellis Island and detained on board ship virtually the entire crews of the liners Vulcania and Italia.

The American Radio Association, C.I.O., yesterday accepted tentatively a wage rise of 6.38 per cent. This was in line with action the previous day by the Seafarers International Union, A.F.L., and the National Maritime Union. C.I.O.

TOKYO, Oct. 10--Kim Il Sung, Communist Premier of North Korea, has rejected Gen. Douglas MacArthur's demand in the name of the United Nations that the North Korean troops lay down their arms and cease hostilities immediately.

Eighty non-profit voluntary hospitals, members of the United Hospital Fund in all boroughs, are seeking to raise $3,500,000 to be prepared at all times to treat the ills of a population of 8,000,000 people. Today we salute:
Joey Scarlato, promising Harlem lightweight, will receive the biggest test of his career tonight when he battles Brooklyn's Paddy De Marco in a ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct.10--Modern cost and time-saving methods of shipping industrial products were discussed and displayed today at the opening of the fifth annual Industrial Packaging and Handling Exposition in Convention Hall here.

The sale of two memberships on the New York Stock Exchange for $50,000 each, up $1,000 from the price paid in the last previous sale, was announced yesterday. Seats are quoted at $52,000 asked, $43,000 bid.

Three million American homes are now equipped with electric oven roasters, it was reported yesterday by James E. Howard, vice president and treasurer of Nesco, Inc. The figure was disclosed at a showing of Nesco's new lines of electric roasters and decorative kitchen ware.

HAVANA, Oct. 10--Charles Sawyer, United States Secretary of Commerce, arrived today by plane from Haiti for a brief visit as the guest of the Cuban Government. He was accompanied by several officials of the United States Commerce and Interior Departments on the last leg of a trip around the Carribean.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 (AP)--The purchase of Pete Whisenant, a 21year-old outfielder, from the Denver Western League club, was announced tonight by General Manager John Quinn of the Boston Braves. He will join the Tribe for spring training next March.

The Metropolitan Opera box office will be opened to the general public today for the sale of tickets for a special subscription series of three operas--"Don Carlo" on the opening night of the season and the first presentations of "Fledermaus" and "Fidelio."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 10-- Representative Walter A. Lynch, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, asserted here tonight that Governor Dewey as Distinct Attorney of New York County gave the Democrats a crime-ridden city "far worse than it is today."

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 10-- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Foreign Minister, today denounced a United States proposal to enable the United Nations General Assembly to recommend the use of armed force against aggression.

New York is host this week to the largest and most distinguished gathering of Latin-American editors who have ever come at one time to the United States. A thousand balloons went sailing into the air from the eightysixth-floor observatory of the Empire State Building yesterday when they were released by the Crusade for Freedom. They were cut loose at 2:30 P.M. to coincide with the departure of a ten-ton Freedom Bell destined for dedication in Berlin on United Nations Day, Oct. 24.
Inflation is the greatest danger that faces this country, today, Dr. Edward F. Willett, associate Professor of Economics at Smith College, said yesterday.

The three metropolitan chapters of the fraternity, Phi Epsilon Pi, that had voted to disaffiliate from the national organization, voted Sunday to give the Grand Council one more opportunity to reverse its ruling barring a Negro from its Connecticut University chapter, before taking further steps.
Strong buying orders for nonferrous metals exceed the ability of smelters and refiners to deliver from stocks in this area, trade sources reported yesterday.

Raymond J. Wood, freight traffic manager of the Pennsylvania Railroad, has been named chairman of the Broadway Association's traffic committee, to succeed Frederick A. Burdett. Mr. Wood is a director of the association.

In the high-ceilinged former Reid mansion at 15 East Eightyfourth Street, an ancient Jewish custom was revived yesterday. A three-man board convened to hear a former inmate of a German concentration camp charge another member of the Jewish faith with having caused the death of the accuser's brother in 1945.

As a result of several forest fires and the threat occasioned by extremely dry conditions in the woods, the hunting has been suspended in the Province of New Brunswick until sufficient rain has fallen to eliminate the existing danger.

LOS ANGELES, Oct.10--An instrument said to stop loud sudden noises from reaching the ear drum but admitting conversational tones has been put on the market. The Sigma Sales Corporation, the manufacturer, said that the device, known as the Lee Ear-Valv, had been tested by various Federal agencies and by the Armed Forces.

A gift of 255 volumes in the fields of European and American history has been received by the City College Library. The gift was presented by Leon Huhner, attorney and author, an alumnus of the college, in memory of his brother, Dr. Max Huhner.

Large retailers, pointing up their purchases for January promotions and holiday selling are buying in sufficient quantity to lift soft goods sales out of the, doldrums, according to Henry Rosenfeld, dress manufacturer.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 11--The Imperial Court announced today that Mohamed Pahlevi, Shah of Iran, was engaged to Marry Miss Soraya Esfandjari of the Iranian aristocratic family of Bakhtiari.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10--The Soviet press again chose as the major theme today the Soviet Union's cause of peace, presenting quotations from Premier Stalin and Lenin designed to demonstrate an unswerving desire by the Russians for peaceful collaboration with the United States and the rest of the capitalist world.
BERLIN, Oct. 10 (AP)--Allyn Baum, chief of the Acme News Picture Service in Germany, was arrested by East German police today with his German driver, West Berlin police reported.

The United Corporation's net income for the third quarter of this year amounted to $750,208, a gain of $347,714 over the $402,494 reported in the same period a year ago. The report will be released this morning.
Free and truthful journalism is an essential weapon in the struggle to extend human freedom and defeat communism, Bernard M. Baruch said yesterday in an address at Columbia University.

Sir Thomas Beecham and the members of the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra will arrive here tomorrow on the liner Queen Mary for a tour of the United States that will include fifty concerts. The orchestra never before has played in this country.

Herbert Bayard Swope as chairman of the "God Bless America" Fund received yesterday the "Thanks Badge" of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, Inc., highest award offered by the organization, which began its drive to raise $500,000 for 1950.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (AP)-- The Raymond A. Garbarina Memorial Post 1523 of New York won the American Legion national drum-and-bugle corps contest for the second straight year last night.

Ignoring charges that it was playing, politics, the City Council, by a vote of 23 to 1 yesterday passed two bills decreasing the contributions of policemen and firemen to their pension systems and increasing the city's share.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 10--A Florida youth barely old enough to vote but who already has earned $45,000 from agriculture was named Star Farmer of America tonight. He is Forrest Davis Jr. of Quincy. He was the recipient of a $1,000 check at the national convention of the Future Farmers of America.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10--A Pennsylvania Republican today healed another scar from the fierce G.O.P. factional feud in the May primary.

PARIS, Oct. 10 (Reuters)--The pound sterling was quoted on the Paris black market today above the official rate for the first time in eighteen months, in spite of official denials yesterday of impending revaluation. The black market rate today was 985 francs, five francs above the official rate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Personal income in the United States attained a new peak in August when earnings ran at the rate of $223,400,000,000 annually, the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce reported today.

Paperboard production for the week ended Oct. 7 was 14.9 per cent above the like week last year, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. New orders were down 0.3 per cent and unfilled orders up 73.3 per cent.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was irregular yesterday, and the October delivery fell 52 points. Other old-crop months were off 13 to 21 points, and the 1951 month. 18 to 21 points higher than on Monday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 10--Indifference of Democratic officials to vice and corruption in municipal government has seriously injured this country's position as the moral leader of the free world, Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley, Republican candidate for Senator, charged today.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday he would call to his office for questioning any person "who can shed any light" on a charge that a Tammany leader had demanded a $1,000 campaign contribution last year as the price for arranging admission of city patients to Mount Morris Hospital.

LONDON, Oct. 10--Within the next three or four weeks major decisions on the composition and cost of the integrated forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be made in London and Washington.

Vaughn Monroe, the stylized baritone and orchestra conductor, came in with a winning "sleeper" on television at 9 over C.B.S. Without anyof the usual advance fanfare, he presented a relaxing and remarkably well-produced musical presentation. Mr. Monroe succeeded by being unpretentious yet tasteful in one of the most difficult types of shows to do.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. will offer to investors today $8,000,000 of 2 7/8 per cent first mortgage bonds of Utah Power and Light Company due in 1980. The bonds are priced at 100.501 to yield about 2.85 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 10--The United Nations Interim Committee on Korea began its work in closed session today and forthwith was confronted with perhaps its most delicate problem, bearing as it does on the future of the present South Korean regime.
BERLIN, Oct. 10 (Reuters)-- Soviet sector authorities tonight pitted loudspeakers against West Berlin's newest anti-Communist weapon--a 30-foot high electric newsboard staring into the Soviet sector.

Miss Harriet M. Newhall has been appointed child placement supervisor in the displaced persons department of the Church World Service at 214 East Twenty-first Streett. In making public Miss Newhall's appointment yesterday,

An eight-room ranch-style house in Redding Ridge, Conn., has been purchased by S. Earl Honig from Morris Schachter, through Connecticut Homestead Agency, Inc. A six-acre lake is on the property. Mr. Honig also bought an adjoining tract of 110 acres through the same brokers.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 10--Assigned to lead the South African delegation to the General Assembly of the United Nations when India's complaint of racial discrimination is discussed, Dr. Theophilus E. Donges, Minister of the Interior, sailed from Capetown today for New York.

Acting Mayor Impellitteri, in a Columbus Day statement issued yesterday, wished his fellow Americans of Italian ancestry "happiness on a day which traditionally is one of pride and celebration for all of us." He is to be a guest tonight at a dinner to be given at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Columbus Citizens Committee to raise $50,000 for scholarships for high school students.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 10 --The Cabinet of Dr. Konrad Adenauer is faced tonight with a number of conflicting problems arising out of German rearmament and the Western Allied reinforcement in this country.

BOMBAY, India, Oct. 10 (Reuters)-Shipping interests will impose a surcharge of 10 per cent on freight to Australia from Indian ports, it was learned today. Effective in the third week of October, it results from delay in Australian ports caused by dock labor disputes.

Anyone who likes the idea of staying in bed while the coffee cooks and the windows close-- automatically--will find this dream made true in a model house at Plandome, L.I., which will be open to the public on Sunday.

The Roman Catholic Church has almost disappeared in Soviet-dominated nations; and in Rumania, with all Bishops imprisoned or under house arrest, it is under constant attack, Eugene Cardinal Tisserant, Secretary of the Sacred Congregation for Eastern Churches, declared yesterday.

Any more to "throttle" commodity exchanges with controls under present circumstances will only aid monopolists "who aspire to obtain a death grip" upon the American consumer, George C. Schutte, president of the New York Cocoa Exchange, declared last night.

Work at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island shipyard was halted again yesterday as officials of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America; C.I.O., sought to end the unsanctioned walkout that be gan last Thursday afternoon.

TORREON, Mexico, Oct. 10 --A 19-year-old farm youth who rode half naked on an airliner's tail through icy winds at 12,000 feet was in jail tonight. He is waiting to see if the authorities will release him as a lucky daredevil or make an exampe of him to discourage future aerial hitchhikers.

LUCKNOW, India, Oct. 10-Indian and Pakistani delegates to the eleventh international conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations impugned United States motives in Europe and Asia today in a manner that provoked British and Canadian as well as the United States delegates to shocked rebuttal.

Intercepted telephone conversations showed that bets amounting to "over $50,000" were placed with Harry Gross in a single afternoon at the bookmaker's raided Inwood, L.I., telephone headquarters, Kings County District Attorney Miles F. McDonald disclosed yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Clement Hart Reynolds of Nantucket, Mass., have announced here the engagement and forthcoming marriage of Mrs. Reynolds' daughter, Miss Randy Sloan Mebane, to Edward Charles McDonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alois Joseph McDonald of Chicago, formerly of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
NEWARK, Oct. 10 (AP)--Diana Barrymore, actress, applied for a marriage license today with Robert W. Wilcox, actor. Miss Barrymore is the daughter of the late John Barrymore.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 10-- "Scattered Showers," first in a program series of plays for parents dealing with family problems, will be presented tonight at 8:30 in the Rochambeau School Auditorium, Fisher Avenue, under the direction of the American Theatre Wing's Community Plays.
LONDON, Oct. 10 (AP)--French Squadron was backed down to 9to-1 favoritism tonight to win the Cesarewitch tomorrow over two and one-quarter miles at Newmarket.

MONTREAL, Oct. 10 (AP)--Horace C. Grout, until last year president of the Minneapolis, St. Paul and Sault Ste. Marie Railroad Company (Soo Line), died in a hospital here tonight at the age of 69. He was a native of Wausau, Wis.

CANBERRA, Oct. 10 (AP)--Australia produced 487,916 fine ounces of gold in the seven months ended July 31, the latest period for which figures are available. Commonwealth Statistician Roland Wilson reported the yield was 27,723 ounces less than in the same period last year and 408,851 ounces less than in the first seven months of 1939.

The final enrollment count for students registered in day session classes at City College is 10,173, according to Robert L. Taylor, chief registrar. Of this number 6,804 students are attending the main center and 3,369 are enrolled for classes at the commerce center.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 10 (AP) --The Studebaker Corporation announced today that factory list prices for its 1951 Champion models would be increased by $50, while 1951 models of its higher-priced Commander series will be reduced to $110.

The announcement that President Truman will meet General MacArthur somewhere in the Pacific next weekend has caused surprise and started numerous speculations. But such a meeting is by no means unprecedented in view of the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen today pledged its aid to the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen in seeking a general wage increase for railway employes.

The five-story apartment house at 2355 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by O.T. Carter from Michael Newman. The building, on a plot about 62 by 100 feet, contains ninety-eight rooms in suites of three and four rooms. Nehring Brothers were the brokers.

BOWIE Md., Oct. 10--Bowie fans saw one of the largest place and show prices ever posted on a mutuel board today when Merry Nymph, who finished second behind Great Hope in the second event, paid $371.80 to place and $126 to show.

Switching from their provocative dramas, such as "Tomorrow the World" and "Deep Are the Roots," to comedy for the first time, James Gow and Arnaud d'Usseau have collaborated on "Legend of Sarah," which opens at 8 o'clock this evening at the Fulton.
The fact that traditional furniture can be timeless is skillfully demonstrated in a series of room settings which go on view today at Charak, 444 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--President Truman tonight named Lieut. Gen. Nathan F. Twining as the new Vice Chief of Staff of the Air Force and gave to Lieut. Gen. Lauris Norstad, youngest threestar general in the Air Force, the important command of United States Air Forces in Europe.
A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Norman Printz of 172 West Seventy-ninth Street on Oct. 2 in Doctors Hospital.

ROME, Oct. 10--Msgr. Peter Goidic, Bishop of Presov, Slovakia, has disappeared from his See and all efforts to find him have failed, Vatican circles said today. In the same region more than 100 priests of the Byzantine rite have been arrested recently by Communist authorities, they added.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 10 (AP)-- A sufficient number of creditors have voted in favor of a reorganization plan for the Sterling Engine Company to put it into effect, Federal Judge John Knight has been told.

NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 10--A recapitalization plan for the New Rochelle Trust Company was approved this afternoon at a special meeting of stockholders. It eliminates restrictions imposed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and restores local control of dividend distributions.

Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., advertising agency, has named David J. Mahoney a vice president. Mr. Mahoney joined the agency in 1946 after service in the Army as an infantry officer. He prepared for the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania at LaSalle Military Academy.

LONDON, Oct. 10--The demand for British Government securities continued to dominate the stock markets here today. Although interest slackened toward the close, prices generally rose one-eighth or one-quarter point.
Martin Biavaschi Co., Inc., sportswear and playtogs manufacturer, has appointed Al Michaelson sales manager. Mr. Michaelson formerly was a manufacturer of playclothes, sportswear and blouses.
PARIS, Oct. 10 (U.P.)--An important ring which has been counterfeiting modern paintings was uncovered here today with the arrest of a German art dealer, Walter Klein of Berlin.

Jones of Scarsdale, N.Y., has completed plans for her marriage to Edward Bertrand de Selding, son of Mr. Edward Fitzgerald de Selding of Darien and the late Mr. de Selding.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 10-- Governor Dewey emphasized a new technique in state campaigning here tonight when he used television in answering the most serious of the charges made against him by Representative Walter A. Lynch, his Democratic opponent for the Governorship.

The annual report of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and subsidiaries for the year ended on July 29, 1950, released yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president, showed that net profit was 5 per cent less than the earnings of the previous fiscal year, although net sales increased 4 per cent over sales of the previous year.

With the plan for consolidation of the Long Island Lighting Company with its two subsidiaries completed, Edward F. Barrett, president, announced yesterday that shares of the new company will be exchanged for the old on Oct. 24.
George D. Busher, vice president of the Eugene J. Busher Company, Inc., real estate, has been elected a trustee of the Bronx Savings Bank, it was announced yesterday.
Columbia's football squad went through an intense scrimmage against Yale plays yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10--If this country really wants to rehabilitate its prisoners, it must put an end to the "let the punishment fit the crime" philosophy, John R. Ellingston, specialist in crime and delinquency prevention, declared today.
CLARENDON, Vt., Oct. 10-- Otis Warren Barrett, a well-known agriculturist, entomologist and botanist, died here Friday at the home of his brother, Percy. His age was 78.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 10-- Coach Charlie Caldwell attempted to build insurance for his offensive ace, Dice Kazmaier, by working reserve tailbacks in the first team backfield today as Princeton continued tuning up for Navy Saturday.

One hundred and fifty thousand workers in the men's clothing industry will receive a wage increase terms of an agreement reached of 12 cents an hour under the yesterday by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, C.I.O., and the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States.

Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle presented Firemanship Merit badges to two boy scouts yesterday in recognition of their interest in fire prevention. He commended the boys, John Sedlecky, 16 years old, of 23-17 Thirtyfifth Street, Long Island City, Queens, and Robert Fleming, 13, of 1353 Albany Avenue, Brooklyn, for their familiarity with methods of fire prevention and rescue.

Five more hospitals, with a total capacity of 749 beds and 134 bassinets to care for 23,000 patients, would be needed in Brooklyn alone if it were not for the Visting Nurse Association, J.W. Hooper, president of the Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--The Army today asked Selective Service to deliver 40,000 additional recruits into training camps in December and thus raised to 210,000 the new "draft" troops to be in uniform by the end of the year.

Seven mortgage loans amounting to $1,031,508 on apartment houses in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn have been sold by the Investors Diversified Services Inc., to the Greenpoint Savings Bank, through the Sohnenblick-Goldman Corporation, brokers.

Net income of Riegel Textile Corporation for the thirty-six weeks ended Sept. 9 increased 235 per cent over the sales volume of the corresponding period of the previous year, while net sales were 25 per cent more than a year ago, according to the report released yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (U.P.)--A two-car Pacific Electric train hit a stalled freight train in the fog on an elevated right of way today, injuring thirty-five workbound passengers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 10 (AP)--Frankie Sodano, 123 , of Philadelphia won a unanimous eight-round decision over Henry Gault, 118 , of Spartanburg, S.C., tonight in the feature fight at the community center.

The annual Thanksgiving dinner dance in aid of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind will be held on Nov. 22 at the WaldorfAstoria. Joseph F. Berlinger is president of the organization.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 (AP)--Jack Huesman has been sold to Rochester of the International League by Winston-Salem of the Carolina League, his father said last night. Huesman, a 21-year-old shortstop, batted .260 for Winston-Salem in 1950.
Common stock of the Pacific Power Light Company will be offered to the general investing public today for the first time since the company was founded in 1910.

A one-day Far East trade conference will be held here by the Far East-America Council of Commerce and Industry, Inc., on Oct. 20. Participants will be United States and Far East Government officials and business men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized Kansas City, Shreveport and Gulf Terminal Company to extend the maturity date on $150,000 of its first mortgage bonds for twenty-five years. The bonds, due on Aug. 1, 1950, will be redated to mature on Aug. 1, 1975.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 (AP)-- Taxes will be increased in 1951 more than most people realize on a pay-as-you-go defense program, Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said tonight.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11--With a championship New York City drum and bugle corps in the lead, the American Legion today staged its thirty-second national convention parade over a six-mile route through downtown Los Angeles.

PROBABLY the most remarkable escape effort by Allied prisoners in the second World War took place in March, 1944, at the prison camp for Air Force officers known as Stalag Luft III. For more than a year some 600 prisoners out of a total of 800 in the camp worked together in the "X Organization."

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 10--Gordon Gray, former Secretary of the Army, was installed as president of the consolidated University of North Carolina today with a public declaration that Communists were not welcome at the three schools comprising the university system.

The Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation yesterday reported a net profit of $1,069,784 for the three months ended Aug. 31, 1950, and a net profit of $5,536,311 for the nine months ended on the same date.
