Miss Elizabeth Ellen Cadwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Marsh Cadwell of 18 East Sixtyeighth Street and Grosse Pointe, Mich., has completed plans for her marriage, to William Henry O. Dance, son of Dr. and Mrs. Clifton Louis Dance of Brooklyn and Spring Lake, N.J. The wedding will take place on Oct. 21 in Grosse Pointe.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (U.P.)-- The nation's churches were urged today to begin a drive to increase the influence of religion on members of the armed services.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP)-- The Government ordered a cut of nearly 50 per cent in cotton exports today and rationed the balance among foreign purchasers.

A new Professor of Military Science and Tactics and Coordinator of the Joint Army and Air Force Reserve Officers Training Corps unit has taken up his duties at Fordham University. He is Col. Ernest A. Merkle, U.S.A.

Gerrymander, F. Ambrose Clark's 3-year-old son of Challedon, won the New York Turf Writers Cup at Belmont Park yesterday. The hurdle handicap featured the opening day's card of the United Hunts Racing Association's two-day meeting and was witnessed by a crowd of 15,725.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad reported yesterday that it has requested bids from car building companies on the construction of 2,000 steel hopper cars to augment its coal-hauling fleet.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct.10 (UP) Miss Alice Bauer of Midland, Tex., and Mrs. H.C. Riedel of Dallas turned in upset victories today in opening-round matches of the women's Texas open golf tournament.
ONEONTA, N.Y., Oct. 10 (AP)-- Dr. Charles W.Hunt resigned yesterday as president of Oneonta State Teachers College, effective next Jan. 1, and announced he would enter educational research.

MONTREAL. Oct.10 (AP)--Frank Selke of the Montreal Canadiens, managing director, announced tonight that Paul Masnick, 19-yearold forward, has been signed to a two-year contract. Selke also announced that goalie Gordon Bell and defenseman Rolly McLenahan, obtained recently from Hershey, have been optioned to Buffalo of the American Hockey League.

With the opening of the annual appeal for funds of the Girl Scouts, New Yorkers will have an opportunity to aid a community enterprise whose sole aim is to produce secure, self-reliant individuals who are helpful, contributing members of society.

TOKYO, Oct. 9--The dietary habits and small size of some United Nations troops in Korea are causing the United States Army Quartermaster Corps here a series of headaches. This was brought to light in the last few days as an advance party of troops from Thailand arrived in Korea.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 10 (U.P.)--Food rationing has been reintroduced in Hungary because of serious shortages, the official Communist organ Borba reported here today.
An advance of $5 at retail for men's spring worsted suits may be followed by an additional advance of $3.50 to $5 on suits for fall, 1951, on the basis of present costs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--The Department of Agriculture's sharp reduction of cotton exports yesterday stirred up a storm in the cotton-growing South today.

GROTON, Mass., Oct. 11--Groton School's football squad got off to a rousing start this season by capturing its opening games against Governor Dummer and English High. Five contests still remain on the program, however, and Coach Larry Noble finds himself wondering whether the team's good fortune will continue.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11--Back from Berkeley, where it lost to California's conference champions by no more than a touchdown, the Pennsylvania football team was sent through a rugged offensive drill today. It had scrimmage yesterday also, and there will be more of same on the defense tomorrow.

Short skirts for gala nights, modeled in chic theatre suits, dinner and evening frocks, provided the theme for Russeks' showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--Plans for international regulation of the cost and availability of defense materials in which critical shortages are developing under the United States-sponsored rearmament program have been under discussion here in connection with the visit of Hugh Gaitskell, Britain's Minister of Economic Affairs.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 12-- United Nations forces have broken through the Communist defenses at three points on the west and in the center of the enemy line in Korea and are driving northward toward their ultimate objective-- the North Korean capital at Pyongyang.

Addressing a noon-hour Liberal party rally of 500 garment workers at Thirty-sixth Street and Seventh Avenue yesterday, Ferdinand Pecora cited his own record of investigating and prosecuting fraud and corruption in high and low places.
Because of the possibility of serious traffic congestion, the City Planning Commission rejected yesterday an application for permission to build a drive-in theatre in Brooklyn.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 11-- On the eve of Columbus Day Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley tonight promised a group of Americans of Italian descent that he would bring his "unceasing efforts" to bear in working for admission of Italy to the United Nations.

Middleground, the King Ranch's 1950 winner of the Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes, reached the end of the racing trail yesterday. He fractured both right front sesamoid bones in a freak accident during the morning workout period at Belmont Park. One fracture was severe, the other slight.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Oct. 11-- The power displayed by the Chinatrained and equipped Vietminh troops in the last weeks in the China frontier battle between Caobang and Thatkhe has emphasized how serious the future prospects are for the French in Indo-China. The grave outlook not only applies to the military sphere but encompasses the political situation as well.

COPENHAGEN, Oct. 11--Denmark's economic plight justifies the Government's drastic fiscal and import restraint proposals, Labor Premier Hans Hedtoft said today in an interview. Discussing his country's economy, the Premier took the grave view of the present situation, but was optimistic regarding long-term prospects.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11--Hedging sales in soy beans more than offset removal of hedges against export sales today and closing trades were about the bottom with losses of to 2 7/8 cents, July leading. Wheat finished cent lower to cent higher; corn, to 7/8 cent higher; oats, to 3/8 cent higher, and rye, cent higher. Lard was 5 cents higher to 5 cents lower per 100 pounds.

The toll of aliens caught in the web of the strictly enforced Internal Security Act rose to 272 yesterday as immigration authorities reported that seventy-eight had been detained Tuesday on three ships in addition to ninetyfive taken off the liners Italia and Vulcania and others previously seized.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--William O'Dwyer, former Mayor of New York was sworn in as Ambassador to Mexico today. He made it plain that his New York experience was behind him and he would have nothing to say about politics or the police graft investigation unless he were asked officially.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--Secretary of State Dean Acheson assured drought-stricken Yugoslavia today that she would receive food from the United States within the near future.

The declaration of Samuel Seabury, father of the La Guardia era of civic reform, in favor of Ferdinand Pecora for Mayor caused a furor yesterday in political and reform quarters. Mr. Seabury, in a statement issued through the City Fusion party Tuesday night, announced his support of Justice Pecora as the best qualified candidate for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--The Army Engineer Corps today announced that fifty-seven flood control and waterway projects throughout the country this year would cost $618,564,650. This was $50,000,000 less than the amount originally approved by Congress.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 11--Uppermost in President Truman's mind tonight, as he arrived here from Washington on the first leg of a journey to a rendezvous with Gen. Douglas MacArthur, is the reconstruction of a free Korea.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 11 --The pre-election picture in Minnesota shows an apathetic electorate, a behind-the-scenes but damaging split in the DemocraticFarmer-Labor party, and an absence of any pervading or dramatic issues.

Due largely to increased production of synthetic rubber planned under the mobilization program, nearly all forms of plastic will be in short supply early next year, members of the Plastic Club of the United States were told yesterday.
DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings took up where they had left off last season as they beat the New York Rangers, 3--2, tonight in the opening game of the National Hockey League season.

The nation's steel mills poured more raw steel during September and in the first nine months of 1950 than in any other corresponding periods previously, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The lowest bid for the preparation of contract plane, specifications and working plans for the proposed national defense type 20-knot cargo ship was submitted to the Federal Maritime Administration by W.C. Nickum Sons, naval architects of Seattle, Wash., it was announced yesterday.

A revision of America's tariff policies to provide for a "parity of imports" with domestic products, based on higher wage standards in this country, was asked here yesterday by O.R. Strackbein, chairman of the National Labor Management Council on Foreign Trade Policy.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 (AP)-- Admiral Ben Moreell president of Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation, called today for an upward revision of steel prices to bring them into line with the general economy.

ALBANY, Oct. 11--Charges that the Feinberg Anti-Communist Teacher Law represents a gradual encroachment by the Government on the freedoms guaranteed by the Constitution were made before the Court of Appeals today by attorneys for three groups challenging its constitutionality.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Oct. 11-- Control of the Massachusetts Legislature in 1951, it appeared today, was developing priority in top-level strategy of both Democratic and Republican camps in the present campaign.

VERACRUZ, Mexico, Oct.11 (UP) --The most powerful hurricane to hit Mexico in ten years sank ten small coastal steamers and fishing boats in the Gulf of Mexico today and roared on southward down the coast.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 11 --A new mobile blood-processing laboratory for fractionating human blood into its multifarious lifegiving components and for preserving them in the interest of national health and security, was demonstrated here today at the annual autumn meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

Columbia's football team may face Yale without the service of five regular performers. Lou Little revealed yesterday as he drove his squad through another day of intensive workouts against a simulated Eli split-T attack at Baker Field.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 11--The United Nations received a warning today from its watch-dog Committee on the Balkans that Poland and Albania were actively helping Greek guerrillas to re-enter Greece and carry out "subversive activities" against the Athens Government.

GENEVA, Oct. 11--The General Council of the International Refugee Organization approved today a resolution, providing for extention of the I.R.O.'s resettlement activities to 55,000 "new refugees" from behind the Iron Curtain.

In the face of persistent rumors that the Polish liner-Batory, subject of special attention by Immigration and Customs 'officials in recent months, was about to be withdrawn from service, the Gdynia America Line released yesterday the ship's proposed 1951 sailing schedule.

A chance to take undisputed possession of first place in the National Football League's National Conference is presented to the New York Yanks tonight, when Red Strader's high-scoring squad makes its debut at Yankee Stadium against the San Francisco Forty-Niners. The kick-off is scheduled for 8:30 P.M.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 11 (UP) --Brazil's automobile market bubble was punctured today. There will be no more paid vacations for Americans who were offered free round trips here if they brought cars with them.

We took the city adminstration sharply to task in a recent editorial for not insisting that a private contractor repair promptly broken light bulbs and fixtures in the public parks. We said then that "discovery that a city department was not doing its job properly was not made within the city administration itself. The discovery originated in newspaper articles."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--The Federal Communications Commission today authorized the Columbia Broadcasting System to begin commercial color television operations on Nov. 20. The commission, which split 5 to 2 on the decision, acted to protect future buyers against sets that might become outdated.

Marion Bauer's "Dance Sonata" received its first performance last night in Town Hall at the hands of Dorothy Eustis. Structurally the work revealed itself as the product of an experienced and skilled composer. The work has its roots in French impressionism, but an impressionism of a strikingly modern sort, with a free use of dissonance.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Oct. 11--Former Supreme Court Justice William F. Bleakley of Yonkers told 400 Rockland Republican County Committeemen and leaders from the five counties of the Ninth Judicial District tonight why Children's Court Judge George W. Smyth, Westchester Republican, had been refused the Supreme Court nomination by his party.
TOKYO, Oct. 11--General MacArthur's headquarters today maintained an official silence regarding the forthcoming week-end meeting between the United Nations Commander and President Truman.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)-- Casualties in the Korean war rose to 24,163 today, an increase of 3,407 in a week.

Negotiators for the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, C.I.O., tentatively agreed yesterday to accept a 6.38 per cent wage increase, becoming the fourth maritime union to accept this pattern in the last three days.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11--The American Legion today called for the immediate internment of all members of the Communist party and their trial as traitors or spies.

Pauline Lord, the actress, who made her big success in the title role of Eugene O'Neill's "Anna Christie," died early yesterday of a heart ailment in Alamogordo, N.M., according to word received here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP)-- W. Somerset Maugham today described as "merely a curiosity" the original rough draft of what was to become his best-selling novel, "Of Human Bondage."

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 11 (AP)-- Olin T. McIntosh Jr., chairman of the Naval Stores Section of the Savannah Cotton and Naval Stores Exchange, declined today to comment on the Government's antitrust action against the exchange.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--Retail food prices rose 1.4 per cent in the last two weeks of September, making a net rise of 2.7 per cent since the Korean fighting began.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--Credit restrictions governing apartment house construction and the financing of commercial buildings were being worked over today by the Federal Reserve Board in the wake of the home building mortgage curbs it imposed under Regulation X yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I, Oct. 11-- Llewellyn W. Jones, for many years treasurer and a director of the Grinnell Corporation, who was a tax expert and prominent horticulturist, died in his eighty-first year this morning at his home in nearby Barrington.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Rivoli, the attraction is "Two Flags West," a historical Western produced by Twentieth Century-Fox, with Joseph Cotton, Linda Darnell, Jeff Chandler and Cornel Wilde heading the cast.

The news from India these days is shocking to Americans, especially to American friends of India, and there is no reason why this should not be said frankly and without equivocation. COPENHAGEN, Oct. 11--winston Churchill called tonight for a united Europe as a first step toward a peaceful world order.

Directors of the Western Maryland Railway have approved a recapitalization plan which would eliminate the accrued dividends on the 7 per cent cumulative first preferred stock by payment in capital stock, Eugene S. Williams, president, yesterday informed stockholders.

The three major candidates for Mayor of New York City are reasonably well qualified for the office and of good moral character. Justice Pecora is a man of mature judgment, with an estimable record on the bench and in other legal capacities.

PARIS, Oct. 11--Taxicabs did everything but climb over each other as they struggled in a traffic snarl spreading half a mile around the Place d'Etoile today when the Sultan of Morocco visited the Unknown Soldier's Tomb under the Arc de Triomphe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--The organization of a temporary interagency committee to start a survey of the natural resources development possibilities of New England and New York State was ordered today by President Truman.
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 12 (AP) --An Air Force C-119 Flying Boxcar crashed and burned at a Southern Japan base today, killing three airmen and injuring five other persons.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11--Gigantic commitments by the United States for arms, money, and other assistance all over the world makes it clear that Americans "are going to live in a garrison state for five, ten or fifteen years," Claude A. Putnam, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said today.

There was no let-up in Fordham's program yesterday as the coaching staff ordered another day of scrimmage for the football squad. Before the practice session was over, Coach Ed Danowski announced some changes in the backfield that will start against Boston College tomorrow night at Braves Field.

At the forty-fifth and best attended annual meeting of the Electric Bond and Share Company yesterday, about 265 stockholders heard George G. Walker, president of the $172,000,000 utility, announce that net income for the twelve months to Sept. 30 had increased $3,148,675.

VIENNA, Oct. 11--The struggle between the Socialists and Communists for control of Austrian labor unions has not ceased with the failure last week of the Communist general strike attempt, nor has Russian interference on the side of the Communists against the Austrian Government.
Materials and productive capacity for shoes are ample to meet all foreseeable civilian and military requirements without rationing, according to Harry Volk, president of the National Shoe Institute.

Operations of New York State commercial banks and trust companies during the first half of 1950 brought about shifts of almost onethird of a billion dollars into highyielding assets, a midyear report of Superintendent of Banks William A. Lyon disclosed yesterday, Total resources declined seasonally by $366,000,000 to $19,985,000,000.

The Citizens Budget Commission branded as "shocking" yesterday the action of the City Council on Tuesday, when it jammed through two local bills to cut the contributions of policemen and firemen to their pension funds.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 11 --The three Western powers de nied today the legitimacy of the Soviet zone elections this Sunday and the East German regime and urged the Russians to consider the Western Republic's demand for free all-German elections.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 11-- "Angels in the Outfield," a baseball comedy written for the screen by the Rev. R.F. Grady, Roman Catholic priest, has been acquired by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a vehicle for Spencer Tracy, the studio announced today.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Oct. 11 --In advance of formal decisions, Marshall Plan officials, in cooperation with the Bonn Government, are shifting the rehabilitation effort here to a frank program for gearing the West German economy to West European defense needs.
LONDON, Oct. 11--The tone of Communist China's repeated warning to the United States to keep out of North Korea unsettled the stock markets here today and caused prices to fall.

Restrictions on freedom of the press still exist in many of the twenty-four nations of the Americas, although in the last year the situation "has experienced an encouraging change," a committee on press freedom reported yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 11 --New Federal curbs effective tomorrow on house financing will cut deeper into new construction than Washington anticipates and will result in an increase in the value of existing houses, Eugene Mortlock, vice president of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York, told the Westchester County Realty Board this afternoon.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11--There was a growing disposition in Moscow today to believe that the North Koreans were adopting the "tactics of prolonged war" mentioned in an Oct. 1 address by Chou En-lai, Premier of Communist China.

First priorities received by New York industrialists yesterday under the "D.O." defense order plan were handled with a minimum of confusion because of advance preparations for such activities. In major defense industries, such as communications, purchasing agents obtained prompt delivery of scarce steel items, according to steel warehousemen.

ALBANY, Oct. 11--Arthur W. Dawes, dean of chemists at the Rensselaer, (N.Y.) plant of General Aniline Film Corporation of 230 Park Avenue, died at his home here last night after being ill for more than a year.

Republican Senator Charles W. Tobey of New Hampshire took a slap at Governor Dewey yesterday for not cracking down on gambling at Saratoga. The Senator made his critical statement here as the Senate Crime Investigating Committee delved into big-time gambling in upstate New York and Bergen. County, N. J.

PARIS, Oct. 11--After a Cabinet meeting today, Premier Rene Pleven cabled Defense Minister Jules Moch, representing France in the Washington arms talks, to urge on Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall the necessity of accelerated United States military material aid to Indo-China.

A plea freedom of the artist was made yesterday by William Schuman, president of the Juilliard school of Music, who spoke at the convocation ceremonies marking the opening of the school's forty-sixth Year.
SEATTLE, Oct. 11 (AP)--A warehouse full of dried eggs, imported from Communist China when the Government already owns $115,000,000 worth, produced protests and explanations today.

Lehman was in danger because of the independent candidacy of Acting Mayor Impellitteri for the office he now holds, Alex Rose, a vice chairman of the Liberal party, called yesterday on pro-Lehman voters to bring out the largest registration possible and "debunk" the Impellitteri candidacy.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 11--Representative Walter A. Lynch, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, tonight told what he called "the evil story" behind Governor Dewey's decision to seek re-election, and the events that allegedly led to the removal of Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley as the party's first gubernatorial candidate.

The six-day wildcat strike of 1,650 workers at the Staten Island shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Company has postponed launching of the second of three ferryboats being constructed there for the city. The ceremony originally was scheduled for Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--Secretary of State Dean Acheson today pledged full cooperation with the British Commonwealth program of assistance for Southeast Asia, but he did not commit the United States to any particular line of action.

Sales of downtown lofts and two business properties in the midtown section of Manhattan were announced yesterday by Henry Goelet, the operator. The parcels have a total asessed valuation of close to $700,000.

One of the hardest-working groups that support the United Nations will be out of a home at 5 P.M. tomorrow. Six banking syndicates yesterday submitted bids ranging from $78,997 to $193,923 to underwrite Ohio Edison Company's eighteenday offer of 396,571 new shares of stock to the company's stockholders at a price 2 points below yesterday's closing price.
One of the most highly publicized musical offerings of this or, for that matter, any other theatrical season opens on Broadway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Oct. 11-- Coroner L.C. Gray said today he would publish a list of twelve persons, most of them known racketeers, involved in the shortage of more than $600,000 at the First National Bank of Cecil. John F. Wagner, cashier of the bank, was a suicide Sept. 18.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 11--The United States today reassured United Nations member states that it would not advocate the termination of essential child-feeding or relief supply function by the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund. This Government has been the chief supporter of the fund, which is now being reestablished by the General Assembly on a permanent basis.

LAKE SUCCESS, Thursday, Oct. 12--The United Nations Commission for Indonesia told the Security Council early today that it had exhausted all its efforts to end the fighting between Indonesian troops and rebel forces in Amboina.
The National Conference of Christians and Jews presented an illuminated citation yesterday to Louis J. Horowitz, chairman of the Louis J. and Mary E. Horowitz Foundation.

HONG KONG, Oct. 11--Communist China has warned the United States through an unnamed Foreign Office spokesman that it regards the North Korean situation as especially "serious" now that United States troops have crossed the Thirty-eighth Parallel. The spokesman added the Peiping regime "cannot stand by idly" under those circumstances.
ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 11 (AP)-- The new president of the Medical Society of Virginia promised the organization here today that the fight for admission of Negroes to full membership was not yet finished.

James E. Reardon, a former plainclothes patrolman, was taken into protective custody and placed under a twenty-four-hour police guard yesterday after disclosure of some of the testimony he had given before the Kings County Grand Jury investigating illicit relations between policemen and bookmakers.

Monday will be doctors' day in Selective Service. Col. Candler Cobb, New York director, made public yesterday the times and places where medical men must report and explained who is required to report and the few who are exempt.

Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey visited the Port of New York Authority at 111 Eighth Avenue yesterday afternoon to discuss with the commissioners the projects in which the agency and his state are jointly engaged.

IS Joe DiMaggio, the greatest, all-around ball player since Babe Ruth, through? Since no one is better qualified to answer this question than the man himself, it was put directly to him yesterday. Another athlete might have resented so pointed a query, but like the champion he has been throughout his career with the Yankees, DiMaggio was--well, DiMaggio was DiMaggio, honest, forthright and ever friendly.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 11--George S. Case, chairman of the executive committee of the Lamson Sessions Company, who was recognized as one of the country's foremost engineers in the bolt and nut industry, died today at the age of 67.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct 11(UP)--Four members of the British and American branches of the Soicety of Friends said tonight that they had visited Archbishop Aloysius Stepinatz in his drab jail cell at Lepoglava and that he had appealed for world-wide prayers for peace.

Romulo, Foreign Secretary of the Philippines, today defended against Soviet attack the United States proposal to strengthen the powers of the United Nations General Assembly in dealing with any future aggression.
NOW that gentle rain has fallen over a large part of the province, New Brunswick has reopened the hunting season, with the ban lifted on all counties except Restigouche and Gloucester.

A one-family home on a lot 40 by 100 feet at 2018 East Fourth Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Clara Spear to Sarah and Virginia Sultan in a deal negotiated by Slomka Brothers, brokers. It is assessed at $13,000.

Dealer orders to manufacturers and distributors of television receivers in September increased from 100 to 250 per cent compared with previous record volume in the corresponding month last year. A canvass yesterday disclosed that some portion of these gains was due to a lastminute buying rush of dealers to avoid the price consequences of the forthcoming 10 per cent excise tax.

Lehman, Democratic-Liberal candidate, on the ground that he is needed in the Senate to support President Truman's foreign policy and to press for liberal legislation on domestic matters, was urged last night by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. Mrs. Roosevelt spoke from radio station WNBC and her speech was rebroadcast later from WMCA.

A threat of "injuctive proceedings" by the Pilot Radio Corporation and strong objection by the Radio Corporation of America were among the immediate reactions yesterday to the decision of the Federal Communications Commission granting final approval to the color television method of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Natural crude rubber futures after hitting new seasonal highs on the Commodity Exchange in early dealings yesterday reacted sharply on trade and commission house selling. The commission on Wednesday authorized C.B.S. to start commercial transmissions in color on Nov. 20, but the network indicated it might not start regular programming until mid-December.

ROME, Oct. 12--Proclamation of the dogma of corporeal assumption of the Virgin Mary to heaven will be made by Pope Pius on the morning of Nov. 1 during a special ceremony of unprecedented solemnity, Vatican officials said today.
